7.text:
{{italic title}} {{taxobox |name = ''Alnus oblongifolia''
Arizona Alder |image = Alder 2 (PSF).png |regnum = [[Plant]]ae |unranked_divisio = [[Angiosperms]] |unranked_classis = [[Eudicots]] |unranked_ordo = [[Rosids]] |ordo = [[Fagales]] |familia = [[Betulaceae]] |genus = ''[[Alder|Alnus]]'' |subgenus = ''Alnus'' |species = '''''A. oblongifolia''''' |binomial = ''Alnus oblongifolia'' |binomial_authority = [[John Torrey|Torr.]] |range_map = Alnus oblongifolia range map 1.png |range_map_caption = Natural range of ''Alnus oblongifolia'' |}} '''''Alnus oblongifolia''''' ('''Arizona alder''') is a large [[alnus|alder]], [[birch]]-family tree up to {{convert|72|ft|m}}, from the [[southwestern United States]] and northern [[Sonora]], [[Mexico]].Little. ''Atlas of United States Trees, Volume 3, Minor Western Hardwoods'', Map 12, ''Alnus oblongifolia'' It grows across [[Arizona]] into western [[New Mexico]] mountain ranges. In central Arizona its range extends across the [[Arizona transition zone|transition zone]] to the [[White Mountains (Arizona)|White Mountains]] region of eastern Arizona–western New Mexico border. Besides the range extension from central Arizona, elsewhere in New Mexico it occurs only in scattered mountain range locales.Little. Map 12, ''Alnus oblongifolia''. In southern Arizona south of the Mogollon Rim, also in two mountain regions, and in neighboring Sonora in regions at the north of the [[Sierra Madre Occidental]] cordillera near Arizona's southeast [[Madrean Sky Islands|Madrean Sky Island]] ranges of [[sky island]]s. Isolated mountain locales also occur in a region of southwest [[Chihuahua (state)|Chihuahua]] and neighboring northwest [[Durango]], part of the eastern Sierra Madre Occidentals.Little. Map 12, ''Alnus oblongifolia''. ==See also== *''[[Alnus incana]]'' ==Notes== {{reflist}} ==References== *Little. ''Atlas of United States Trees, Volume 3, Minor Western Hardwoods'', Little, Elbert L, 1976, US Government Printing Office. Library of Congress No. 79-653298. Map 12, ''Alnus oblongifolia''. ==External links== *[http://www.wildflower.org/plants/result.php?id_plant=ALOB2 Lady Bird Johnson database] *[http://www.efloras.org/florataxon.aspx?flora_id=1&taxon_id=233500037 Flora of North America]; [http://www.efloras.org/object_page.aspx?object_id=5479&flora_id=1 RangeMap] *[http://plants.usda.gov/java/profile?symbol=ALOB2 NRCS: USDA Plants Profile] *[http://www.plantmaps.com/nrm/alnus-oblongifolia-arizona-alder-native-range-map.php Interactive Distribution Map of ''Alnus oblongifolia''] [[Category:Alnus|oblongifolia]] [[Category:Flora of Arizona]] [[Category:Flora of New Mexico]] [[Category:Trees of Sonora]] [[Category:Trees of Chihuahua (state)]] [[Category:Trees of Durango]] [[Category:Trees of the Southwestern United States]] [[Category:Trees of the South-Central United States]] {{-}} {{fagales-stub}}

8.text:
{{italic title}} {{taxobox | name = ''Aralia spinosa'' | image = Aralia spinosa, Georgia, USA.jpg | image_caption = Clump of ''Aralia spinosa''
[[Georgia (U.S. state)|Georgia, USA]] | regnum = [[Plantae]] | unranked_divisio = [[Angiosperms]] | unranked_classis = [[Eudicots]] | unranked_ordo = [[Asterids]] | ordo = [[Apiales]] | familia = [[Araliaceae]] | genus = ''[[Aralia]]'' | species = '''''A. spinosa''''' | binomial = ''Aralia spinosa'' | binomial_authority = [[Carl Linnaeus|L.]] | range_map = Aralia spinosa range map 1.png | range_map_caption = Natural range of ''Aralia spinosa'' }} '''''Aralia spinosa''''', commonly known as '''Devil's Walkingstick''', is a woody species of plants in the genus ''[[Aralia]]'', family [[Araliaceae]], native to eastern [[North America]]. The various names refer to the viciously sharp, spiny stems, petioles, and even leaf midribs. It has also been known as '''Angelica-tree'''.{{cite book | last =Keeler | first =Harriet L. | title =Our Native Trees and How to Identify Them | publisher =Charles Scriber's Sons | year =1900 | location =New York | pages =165–168 }} This species is sometimes called '''Hercules' Club''', '''Prickly Ash''', or '''Prickly Elder''', common names it shares with the unrelated ''[[Zanthoxylum clava-herculis]]''. For this reason, ''Aralia spinosa'' is sometimes confused with that species and mistakenly called the ''Toothache Tree'',{{cite web | url=http://www.fs.fed.us/global/iitf/pdf/shrubs/Aralia%20spinosa.pdf | publisher=International Institute of Tropical Forestry | title=Aralia spinosa | author=Kristina Connor | work = Wildland Shrubs of the United States and its Territories: Thamnic Descriptions, General Technical Report IITF-WB-1, Edited by John K. Francis | accessdate = 2008-08-24 }} but it does not have the medicinal properties of ''Zanthoxylum clava-herculis''. ''Aralia spinosa'' is occasionally cultivated for its exotic, tropical appearance, having large lacy compound leaves. It is closely related to the Asian species ''[[Aralia elata]]'', a more commonly cultivated species with which it is easily confused. ==Description== ''Aralia spinosa'' is an aromatic spiny [[deciduous]] [[shrub]] or small tree growing {{convert|2|–|8|m|ft|abbr=on}} tall, with a simple or occasionally branched stem with very large bipinnate [[leaf|leaves]] {{convert|70|–|120|cm|in|abbr=on}} long. The trunks are up to {{convert|15|–|20|cm|in|abbr=on}} in diameter, with the plants umbrella-like in habit with open crowns. The young stems are stout and thickly covered with sharp spines. The plants generally grow in clusters of branchless trunks, although stout wide-spreading branches are occasionally produced. The [[flower]]s are creamy-white, individually small (about 5 mm or 0.2 in across) but produced in large composite [[panicle]]s {{convert|30|–|60|cm|in|abbr=on}} long; flowering is in the late summer. The [[fruit]] is a purplish-black [[berry (botany)|berry]] {{convert|6|–|8|mm|in|abbr=on}} in diameter, ripening in the fall. The roots are thick and fleshy. The doubly or triply compound leaves are the largest of any temperate tree in the continental United States, often about a meter (three feet) long and 60 cm (two feet) wide, with leaflets about {{convert|5|–|8|cm|in|abbr=on}} long. The petioles are prickly, with swollen bases. In the autumn the leaves turn to a peculiar bronze red touched with yellow which makes the tree conspicuous and attractive. The habit of growth and general appearance of ''Aralia spinosa'' and related tree-forming ''Aralia'' species are unique. It is usually found as a group of unbranched stems, rising to the height of {{convert|3.5|–|6|m|ft|abbr=on}}, which bear upon their summits a crowded cluster of doubly or triply compound leaves, thus giving to each stem a certain tropical [[palm (plant)|palm]]-like appearance. In the south it is said to reach the height of {{convert|15|m|ft|abbr=on}}, still retaining its palm-like aspect. However, further north, the slender, swaying, palm-like appearance is most characteristic of younger plants that have not been damaged by winter storms. [[File:Aralia spinosa.jpg|thumb|The trunk, showing the bark, leaf scars, and spines.]] * Bark: Light brown, divided into rounded broken ridges. Branchlets one-half to two-thirds of an inch in diameter, armed with stout, straight or curved, scattered prickles and nearly encircled by narrow leaf scars. At first light yellow brown, shining and dotted, later light brown. * Wood: Brown with yellow streaks; light, soft, brittle, close-grained. * Winter buds: Terminal bud chestnut brown, one-half to three-fourths of an inch long, conical, blunt; axillary buds flattened, triangular, one-fourth of an inch in length. * Leaves: Clustered at the end of the branches, compound, bi- and tri-pinnate, three to four feet long, two and a half feet broad. The pinnae are unequally pinnate, having five or six pairs of leaflets and a long stalked terminal leaflet; these leaflets are often themselves pinnate. The last leaflets are ovate, two to three inches long, wedge-shaped or rounded at base, serrate or dentate, acute; midrib and primary veins prominent. They come out of the bud a bronze green, shining, somewhat hairy; when full grown are dark green above, pale beneath; midribs frequently furnished with prickles. Petioles stout, light brown, eighteen to twenty inches in length, clasping, armed with prickles. Stipules acute, one-half inch long. * Flowers: July, August. Perfect or [[polygamomonoecious]], cream white, borne in many-flowered umbels arranged in compound panicles, forming a terminal racemose cluster, three to four feet in length which rises, solitary or two or three together, above the spreading leaves. Bracts and bractlets lanceolate, acute, persistent. * Calyx: Calyx tube coherent with the ovary, minutely five-toothed. * Corolla: Petals five, white, inserted on margin of the disk, acute, slightly inflexed at the apex, imbricate in bud. * Stamens: Five, inserted on margin of the disk, alternate with the petals; filaments thread-like; anthers oblong, attached on the back, introrse, two-celled; cells opening longitudinally. * Pistil: Ovary inferior, five-celled; styles five, connivent; stigmas capitate. * Fruit: Berry-like drupe, globular, black, one-fourth of an inch long, five-angled, crowned with the blackened styles. Flesh thin, dark. ==Distribution and habitat== ''Aralia spinosa'' is widespread in the eastern [[United States]], ranging from [[New York (state)|New York]] to [[Florida]] along the Atlantic coast, and westward to [[Ohio]], [[Illinois]], and [[Texas]]. It prefers a deep moist soil. The plants typically grow in the forest [[Understory]] or at the edges of forests, often forming [[vegetative reproduction|clonal]] thickets by sprouting from the roots. This tree was admired by the [[Iroquois]] because of its usefulness, and for its rarity. The Iroquois would take the saplings of the tree and plant them near their villages and on islands, so that animals wouldn't eat the valuable fruit. The fruit was used in many of the natives' foods. The women would take the flowers and put them in their hair because of the lemony smell. The flowers could also be traded for money. ==Uses== The young leaves can be eaten if gathered before the prickles harden. They are then chopped finely and cooked as a [[potherb]]. ''Aralia spinosa'' was introduced into cultivation in 1688 and is still grown for its decorative foliage, prickly stems, large showy flower [[panicle]]s [clusters], and distinctive fall color. These plants are slow growing, tough and durable, do well in urban settings, but bear numerous prickles on their stems, petioles, and leaflets. These plants can be propagated from seeds or root cuttings.[[Janet Meakin Poor|Poor, Janet Meakin]], and Nancy P. Brewster. 1994. ''Plants that merit attention Vol 2, Shrubs''. Portland, OR: Timber Press. ISBN 0-88192-347-8 Page 34. ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== {{Commons category|Aralia spinosa}} *[http://www.cas.vanderbilt.edu/bioimages/species/frame/arsp2.htm ''Aralia spinosa'' images at bioimages.vanderbilt.edu] * Grieve, M. Mrs. (1931) ''[http://www.botanical.com/botanical/mgmh/a/angel038.html A Modern Herbal: Aralia spinosa]'' United States Department of Agriculture Web page: * [http://plants.usda.gov/java/profile?symbol=ARSP2] [[Category:Aralia|spinosa]] [[Category:Trees of the Northeastern United States]] [[Category:Trees of the North-Central United States]] [[Category:Trees of the Southern United States]] [[Category:Trees of the Southeastern United States]] [[Category:Trees of the South-Central United States]] [[Category:Leaf vegetables]] [[Category:Trees of the United States]] [[Category:Plants described in 1753]] [[Category:Trees of the Great Lakes region (North America)]]
8.title: Aralia spinosa

'''''Arbutus xalapensis''''', commonly known as the '''Texas madrone''', '''naked Indian tree''' or '''Texas madroño''', is a species of [[flowering plant]] in the [[Erica|heather]] family. It is native to [[Mexico]], [[Central America]], and the [[southwestern United States]] (western [[Texas]] and [[New Mexico]]).<ref>[http://bonap.net/MapGallery/County/Arbutus%20xalapensis.png Biota of North America Program 2014 county distribution map]</ref><ref>[http://swbiodiversity.org/seinet/taxa/index.php?taxon=17908 SEINet, Southwestern Biodiversity, Arizona chapter] photos, description, distribution map</ref> It is found in canyons and mountains, on rocky plains, and in oak woodlands, at altitudes of up to 3,000 m (10,000 feet) in the south of the range, but lower, down to 600 m (1800 feet) in the north of the range.

''Arbutus xalapensis'' is a large [[shrub]] or small to medium-sized [[evergreen]] [[tree]] growing to 5–25 meters (17-84 feet) tall with a trunk up to 50 cm (20 inches) in diameter, with smooth orange-brown bark peeling in thin sheets. The size varies regionally with available rainfall, with small, shrubby plants in dry areas such as western Texas and New Mexico, and larger trees in moister areas of Mexico; plants in Texas, New Mexico, and the far northeast of Mexico are distinguished as a variety, ''A. xalapensis'' var. ''texana'', or even a distinct species ''A. texana'', by some botanists, but others do not regard these as distinct.<ref name=tammy>[http://www.efloras.org/florataxon.aspx?flora_id=1&taxon_id=250092310 Flora of North America, ''Arbutus xalapensis'' Kunth, 1819.  Texas madrone ]</ref>

The [[leaf|leaves]] are oblong to lanceolate, 5–17 cm (2.0-6.8 inches) long and 1.5–5 cm (0.6-2.0 inches) broad, with an entire or serrated margin. The [[flower]]s are bell-shaped, white or pale pink, 5–10 mm long, produced in loose [[panicle]]s. The [[fruit]] is a rough-surfaced edible red [[Berry (botany)|berry]] 1 cm (0.4 inches) in diameter, containing numerous small [[seed]]s.<ref name=tammy/>

<gallery>

10.text:
{{about|the common pawpaw of eastern North America|the unrelated tropical papaya fruit often called 'papaw' or 'pawpaw'|Carica papaya|other uses|Paw Paw (disambiguation)}}
{{Refimprove|date=July 2012}}
{{speciesbox
| image = Asimina_triloba3.jpg
| image_caption = ''Asimina triloba'' in fruit
| genus = Asimina
| species = triloba
| authority = ([[Carl Linnaeus|L.]]) [[Michel Félix Dunal|Dunal]]
| range_map = Asimina triloba range map 1.png
| range_map_caption = Natural range of ''Asimina triloba''
}}

'''''Asimina triloba''''', the '''papaw''',<ref>[[Merriam-Webster's Collegiate Dictionary]] (2009), as its main entry.</ref> '''pawpaw''', '''paw paw''', '''paw-paw''', or '''common pawpaw''', is a small [[deciduous tree]] native to the eastern United States, producing a large, yellowish-green to brown [[fruit]]. It belongs to the genus ''[[Asimina]]'' in the same plant family (the [[Annonaceae]]) as the [[custard-apple]], [[cherimoya]], [[Sugar-apple|sweetsop]], [[ylang-ylang]] and [[soursop]].

The pawpaw is a [[cloning|patch-forming (clonal)]] [[understory]] tree found in well-drained, deep, fertile bottom-land and hilly upland habitat, with large, simple leaves. Pawpaw fruits are the largest edible fruit [[Indigenous (ecology)|indigenous]] to the United States (not counting [[gourd]]s, which are typically considered [[vegetable]]s rather than fruit for culinary purposes, although in [[botany]] they are classified as fruit).<ref name="KSU"/>

Pawpaw fruits have a sweet, custardish flavor somewhat similar to [[banana]], [[mango]], and [[cantaloupe]], and are commonly eaten raw.

==Names==
This plant's [[binomial nomenclature|scientific name]] is ''Asimina triloba.'' The genus name ''Asimina'' is adapted from the [[Indigenous peoples of the Americas|Native American]] (probably [[Miami-Illinois language|Miami-Illinois]]<ref name=Chamberlain>{{cite journal|last = Chamberlain|first = Alexander F.|author-link = Alexander Francis Chamberlain|title = Algonkian Words in American English: A Study in the Contact of the White Man and the Indian.|journal = The Journal of American Folklore|volume = 15|issue = 59|pages = 240–267|publisher = American Folklore Society|date = 1 December 1902|issn = 0021-8715|jstor=533199|doi=10.2307/533199}}</ref>) name ''assimin'' or ''rassimin''<ref name=Werthner>{{cite book|last=Werthner|first=William B.|title=Some American Trees: An intimate study of native Ohio trees|year=1935|publisher=The Macmillan Company|location=New York|pages=xviii + 398 pp.}}</ref> through the [[French colonization of the Americas|French colonial]] ''asiminier.''<ref name=Sargent>{{cite book|last=Sargent|first=Charles Sprague|title=Manual of the trees of North America (exclusive of Mexico)|year=1933|publisher=Houghton Mifflin Company: The Riverside Press Cambridge|location=Boston and New York|pages=xxvi + 910}}</ref> The epithet ''triloba'' in the species' scientific name refers to the flowers' three-lobed [[calyx (botany)|calices]] and doubly three-lobed [[Corolla (flower)|corollas]],<ref name=Werthner/> the shape not unlike a [[tricorne|tricorne hat]].

The common name of this species is variously spelled '''pawpaw''', '''paw paw''', '''paw-paw''', and '''papaw.''' It probably derives from the Spanish ''[[papaya]],'' an American tropical fruit (''Carica papaya'') sometimes also called "papaw",<ref>{{OEtymD|papaya|accessdate=2012-10-28}}</ref><ref>{{OEtymD|papaw|accessdate=2012-10-28}}</ref> perhaps because of the superficial similarity of their fruits.{{Citation needed|date=July 2011}} (In some parts of the world, such as Australia, New Zealand and South Africa, the name Paw Paw is commonly used for a variety of Papaya.) ''Asimina triloba'' has had numerous local common names including: ''wild banana'', ''prairie banana'', ''Indiana banana'', ''Hoosier banana'', ''West Virginia banana'', ''Kansas banana'', ''Kentucky banana'', ''Michigan banana'', ''Missouri banana'', ''the poor man’s banana'', ''Ozark banana'', and ''banango''.

==Description==
[[File:Asimina triloba kz1.jpg|thumb|right|Flowers]]

''Asimina triloba'' is a large [[shrub]] or small [[tree]] growing to a height of 35 feet (11 m) (rarely to 45 feet or 14 m) with a trunks 8-12 inches (20–30 cm) or more in diameter. The large leaves of pawpaw trees are clustered symmetrically at the ends of the branches, giving a distinctive imbricated appearance to the tree's foliage.<ref name=Werthner/><ref name=Keeler />

The [[leaf|leaves]] of the species are simple, alternate and spirally arranged, entire, [[deciduous]], [[lanceolate|obovate-lanceolate]], 10-12 inches (25–30 cm) long, 4-5 inches (10–13 cm) broad, and wedge-shaped at the base, with an acute apex and an entire margin, with the midrib and primary veins prominent. The [[Petiole (botany)|petioles]] are short and stout, with a prominent adaxial groove. Stipules are lacking. The expanding leaves are conduplicate, green, covered with rusty tomentum beneath, and hairy above; when fully grown they are smooth, dark green above, and paler beneath. When bruised, the leaves have a disagreeable odor similar to a green [[bell pepper]]. In autumn the leaves are a rusty yellow, which make spotting pawpaw groves possible from a long distance.<ref name="KSU"/><ref name=Werthner/><ref name=Keeler>{{cite book
 | last =Keeler
 | first =Harriet L.
 | title =Our Native Trees and How to Identify Them
 | publisher =Charles Scriber's Sons
 | year =1900
 | location =New York
 | pages =20–23 }}</ref>

Pawpaw [[flower]]s are [[Perfect flower|perfect]], about 1-2 inches (3–5 cm) across, rich red-purple or maroon when mature, with three sepals and six petals. They are borne singly on stout, hairy, axillary peduncles. The flowers are produced in early spring at the same time as or slightly before the new leaves appear, and have a faint fetid or yeasty smell.<ref name="KSU"/><ref name=Werthner/><ref name=Keeler/><ref name=Georgia>{{cite web|title=Pawpaw|url=http://extension.uga.edu/publications/detail.cfm?number=B992#title14|publisher=University of Georgia Cooperative Extension, College of Agricultural & Environmental Sciences, Athens, GA|date=2012|accessdate=19 October 2016}}</ref>

[[File:Pawpaw-fruit.jpg|thumb|right|Fruit]]

The [[fruit]] of the pawpaw is a large, yellowish-green to brown [[Berry (botany)|berry]], 2–6 in (5–16 cm) long and 1–3 in (3–7 cm) broad, weighing from 0.7–18 oz (20–500 g), containing several brown/black [[seed]]s 1/2 to 1 in (15–25 mm) in diameter embedded in the soft, edible fruit pulp. The conspicuous fruits begin developing after the plants flower; they are initially green, maturing by September or October to yellow or brown. When mature, the heavy fruits bend the weak branches down.<ref name="KSU"/><ref name=Werthner/><ref name=Keeler/>

Other characteristics:
* Calyx: Sepals three, valvate in bud, ovate, acuminate, pale green, downy.<ref name=Werthner/><ref name=Keeler/>
* Corolla: Petals six, in two rows, imbricate in the bud. Inner row acute, erect, nectariferous. Outer row broadly ovate, reflexed at maturity. Petals at first are green, then brown, and finally become dull purple or maroon and conspicuously veiny.<ref name=Werthner/><ref name=Keeler/>
* Stamens: Indefinite, densely packed on the globular receptacle. Filaments short; anthers extrorse, two-celled, opening longitudinally.<ref name=Keeler/>
* Pistils: Several, on the summit of the receptacle, projecting from the mass of stamens. Ovary one-celled; stigma sessile; ovules many.<ref name=Keeler/>
* Branchlets: light brown, tinged with red, marked by shallow grooves.<ref name=Keeler/>
* Winter buds: Small, of two kinds, the leaf buds pointed and closely appressed to the twigs, and the flower buds round, brown, and fuzzy.<ref name=Werthner/>
* Bark: Light gray, sometimes blotched with lighter gray spots, sometimes covered with small excrescences, divided by shallow fissures. Inner bark tough, fibrous. The bark with a very disagreeable odor when bruised.<ref name=Werthner/><ref name=Keeler/>
* Wood: Pale, greenish yellow, sapwood lighter; light, soft, coarse-grained and spongy. Sp. gr., 0.3969; weight of cu ft 24.74 lb.<ref name=Werthner/><ref name=Keeler/>

== Range and ecology ==
[[File:PawPaw bark.jpg|thumb|upright|Bark]]

''Asimina triloba,'' the pawpaw, is native to the Eastern, Southern, and Midwestern [[United States]] and adjacent southernmost [[Ontario]], [[Canada]], from [[New York (state)|New York]] west to southeastern [[Nebraska]], and south to northern [[Florida]] and eastern [[Texas]].<ref name="FNA A. triloba">{{cite book |url=http://www.efloras.org/florataxon.aspx?flora_id=1&taxon_id=220001231|author=Robert Kral |series=[[Flora of North America]] |volume=3 |title=Magnoliophyta: Magnoliidae and Hamamelidae |chapter=Annonaceae |editor=Flora of North America Editorial Committee |publisher=[[Oxford University Press]] |year=1997 |location=New York, NY |isbn=978-0-19-511246-7}}</ref><ref name="KSU">{{cite web|title=Pawpaw Description and Nutritional Information|url=http://www.pawpaw.kysu.edu/pawpaw/cooking.htm|accessdate=14 July 2011| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110719225834/http://www.pawpaw.kysu.edu/pawpaw/cooking.htm| archivedate= 19 July 2011 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref>

The tree commonly grows in [[floodplain]]s and shady, rich bottomlands, where it often forms a dense, [[clonal colony|clonally spreading]] undergrowth in the forest, often appearing as a patch or thicket of individual small slender trees. Pawpaws are not the first to colonize a disturbed site (arriving roughly four years after a [[clearcutting|clearcut]]), but may become dominant and slow the establishment of [[Quercus|oaks]] and [[Carya|hickories]]. Although shade-tolerant, pawpaws do not persist in undisturbed [[old growth forest]]. Pawpaws spread locally primarily by root suckers; sexual reproduction by seed does also occur, but at a fairly low rate.<ref name="fire"/>

Pawpaw flowers are insect-[[pollination|pollinated]], but fruit production is sometimes limited as few if any [[pollinator]]s are attracted to the flower's faint, or sometimes non-existent scent.<ref name="apios"/> The flowers produce an odor similar to that of [[decomposition|rotting]] [[meat]] to attract [[Calliphoridae|blowflies]] or [[carrion beetle]]s for cross pollination. Other insects that are attracted to pawpaw flowers include scavenging [[Tephritidae|fruit flies]], [[Calliphoridae|carrion flies]] and [[beetle]]s. Because of irregular fruit production, some believe pawpaw plants are self-incompatible, requiring cross-pollination between trees of different clones (patches).<ref name="apios">{{cite web|url=http://apiosinstitute.org/asimina-triloba-pawpaw|title=''Asimina triloba'' - pawpaw|publisher=Apios Institute}}</ref>

The fruits of the pawpaw are eaten by a variety of [[mammal]]s, including raccoons, gray foxes, opossums, squirrels, and black bears.<ref name="fire">[http://www.fs.fed.us/database/feis/plants/tree/asitri/all.html Asimina triloba], Fire Effects Information System, U.S. Department of Agriculture, Forest Service, Rocky Mountain Research Station, Fire Sciences Laboratory</ref>

The disagreeable-smelling leaves, twigs, and bark of pawpaws contain natural insecticides known as [[acetogenin]]s.<ref name="Sampson">B. J. Sampson, J. L. McLaughlin, D. E. Wedge. 2003. PawPaw Extract as a Botanical Insecticide, 2002. Arthropod Management Tests, vol.28, p. L.</ref> Pawpaw leaves and twigs are seldom consumed by [[rabbit]]s, [[deer]], or goats,<ref name=CRFG/> or by many insects.<ref name="KSU"/> However, [[mule]]s have been seen eating pawpaw leaves in [[Maryland]].<ref name=Bilton>{{cite web|last=Bilton|first=Kathy|title=Pawpaws: A paw for you and a paw for me|url=http://www.fred.net/kathy/pawpaws.html|accessdate=21 July 2011<!--DASHBot-->}}</ref>

Larvae of the [[zebra swallowtail]] (''[[Protographium marcellus]]''), a [[Lepidoptera|butterfly]], feed exclusively on young leaves of ''Asimina triloba'' and various other pawpaw (''[[Asimina]]'') species, but never occur in great numbers on the plants.<ref name=CRFG/> Chemicals in the pawpaw leaves confer protection from [[predation]] throughout the butterfly's life, as trace amounts of acetogenins remain present, making them unpalatable to birds and other predators.<ref name=Zebra/>

==Conservation status==
On a global (range-wide) scale, the common pawpaw (''Asimina triloba'') has a [[GRANK|NatureServe global conservation rank]] of G5 (very common).

In the United States, the species has a [[NRANK|NatureServe national conservation rank]] of N5 (very common), but is considered a [[threatened species]] in [[New York (state)|New York]], and an [[endangered species]] in [[New Jersey]].

In [[Canada]], where the species is found only in portions of southern [[Ontario]], it has a [[NRANK|NatureServe national conservation rank]] of N3 (vulnerable), and a [[SRANK|NatureServe subnational conservation rank]] of S3 (vulnerable) in Ontario. The [[Ministry of Natural Resources (Ontario)|Ontario Ministry of Natural Resources]] has given the species a general status of "Sensitive", and its populations there are monitored.

In areas in which [[white-tailed deer|deer]] populations are dense, pawpaws appear to be becoming more abundant locally, since the deer avoid them but consume seedlings of most other [[woody plant]]s.<ref name=Bilton />

==History==
A candidate for the natural distribution of the common pawpaw (''Asimina triloba'') in North America, prior to the Ice Ages and lasting until roughly 10,000 years ago, were extant but now extinct [[megafauna]].<ref name="Anachronistic">{{ Cite web | title =Anachronistic Fruits and the Ghosts Who Haunt Them | author = Connie Barlow |  url=http://arnoldia.arboretum.harvard.edu/pdf/articles/618.pdf|publisher=Harvard University Arboretum|date=2001|accessdate=5 December 2012}}</ref> Such animals became extinct during the [[Quaternary extinction event]], and with the arrival of humans and subsequent extinction of such megafauna for distributing ''Asimina triloba'', the probable distribution of these large fruit bearing plants was by humans.<ref name=Anachronistic/>

The earliest documented mention of pawpaws is in the 1541 report of the [[Spain|Spanish]] [[Hernando de Soto (explorer)|de Soto]] expedition, who found [[Native Americans in the United States|Native Americans]] cultivating it east of the [[Mississippi River]].<ref name=CSM/> The [[Lewis and Clark Expedition]] consumed pawpaws during their travels.<ref name=CSM>{{Cite news|title=America’s forgotten fruit: The native pawpaw tastes like banana and grows close to home. |author=Craig Summers Black |newspaper=The Christian Science Monitor |date=February 4, 2009 |url=http://features.csmonitor.com/gardening/2009/02/04/americas-forgotten-fruit/ |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090314052335/http://features.csmonitor.com/gardening/2009/02/04/americas-forgotten-fruit/ |archivedate=March 14, 2009 }}</ref> Chilled pawpaw fruit was a favorite [[dessert]] of [[George Washington]],<ref name=Georgia/><ref name=CSM/> and [[Thomas Jefferson]] planted it at [[Monticello]], his home in [[Virginia]].<ref name=CSM/>

==Cultivation==
In cultivation, lack of successful pollination is the most common cause of poor fruiting. Cross-[[pollination]] of at least two different [[genotype|genetic varieties]] of the plant is recommended,<ref name="KSU"/> and growers often resort to hand pollination or to use of [[pollinator]] attractants such as spraying fish emulsion or hanging chicken necks or other meat near the open flowers to attract pollinators. While pawpaws are larval hosts for the [[zebra swallowtail butterfly]], these caterpillars are usually present only at low density, and not detrimental to the foliage of the trees.<ref name=CRFG/>

Pawpaws have never been cultivated for their fruits on the scale of [[apple|apples (''Malus domestica'')]] or [[peach|peaches (''Prunus persica'')]], primarily because pawpaw fruits ripen to the point of [[Fermentation (food)|fermentation]] soon after they are picked, and only frozen fruit will store or ship well. Other methods of preservation include [[dehydration]], production of [[Fruit preserves#Jam|jams]] or [[Fruit preserves#Jelly|jellies]], and pressure [[canning]] (using the numerical values for bananas).

In recent years, cultivation of pawpaws for fruit production has attracted renewed interest, particularly among [[organic farming|organic growers]], as a native fruit with few to no pests, successfully grown without [[pesticide]]s. The commercial cultivation and harvesting of pawpaws is strong in southeastern Ohio<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ohiopawpawfest.com/|title=The 15th Annual Ohio Pawpaw Festival|publisher=Ohio Pawpaw Festival|accessdate=2013-08-09}}</ref> and also being explored in [[Kentucky]]<ref name="KSU"/> and Maryland,<ref name=Bilton /> as well as various areas outside the species' native range, including [[California]],<ref name=CRFG>{{cite web|title=Pawpaw|url=http://www.crfg.org/pubs/ff/pawpaw.html|publisher=California Rare Fruit Growers|accessdate=15 July 2011| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110720235418/http://www.crfg.org/pubs/ff/pawpaw.html| archivedate= 20 July 2011 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> the [[Pacific Northwest]].,<ref name=CRFG /> and [[Massachusetts]]<ref name=Damrosch />

The pawpaw is also gaining in popularity among [[landscaping|landscapers]] and backyard [[gardener]]s because of the tree's distinctive growth habit, the appeal of its fresh fruit, and its relatively low maintenance needs once established. However, only container-grown pawpaws should be transplanted; use of bare-rooted pawpaws is not recommended, since their fragile [[root hair]]s tend to break off unless a cluster of moist soil is retained on the root mass.<ref name=Georgia/>

<gallery>
[[File:First leaf.jpg|thumb|First pawpaw leaf forming on stem above ground.]]
</gallery>

===Propagation===
{{refimprove section|date=May 2016}}
Trees are easily grown from seed. Germination is [[hypogeal germination|hypogeal]] and cotyledons remain within the seed coat. Strictly speaking, hypogeal means the cotyledons stay in the soil, acting as a food store for the seedling until the plumule emerges from the soil on the epicotyl or true stem. However, pawpaw seeds have occasionally been observed to emerge from the ground and form the true stem and plumule above ground. Desirable kinds ([[cultivar]]s) of pawpaw are propagated by [[chip budding]] or whip [[grafting]].

Seeds will lose viability if they dehydrate to 5% moisture.<ref name="propagation">{{cite web|url=https://www.researchgate.net/publication/237403049_Propagation_of_Pawpaw_Asimina_triloba|title=Propagation of Pawpaw (Asimina triloba)|publisher=International Plant Propagators' Society. Combined Proceedings of Annual Meetings|date=2000|accessdate=17 May 2016}}</ref>{{citation needed|date=May 2016}} The seeds need to be [[Stratification (botany)|stratified]], achieved by storage for 9 weeks at 5 degrees C, losing their viability if stored for 3 years or more. Some seeds survive if stored for 2 years.<ref name="propagation" />

In one study, [[Vegetative reproduction#Artificial vegetative propagation|propagation using cuttings]] was not successful.<ref name="propagation" />

===Habitat restoration===
Pawpaws are sometimes included in [[restoration ecology|ecological restoration plantings]] since this tree grows well in wet soil and has a strong tendency to form well-rooted [[Clonal colony|colonial thickets]]. The pawpaw is particularly valued for establishing fast-growing [[habitat|vegetation]] in areas where frequent flooding might produce [[erosion]], since their root systems help hold streambanks steady.{{Citation needed|date=October 2010}}

==Uses==
[[Image:Asimina triloba red fern farm.jpg|thumb|''Asimina triloba'' is often called ''wild banana'' or ''prairie banana'' because of its banana-like creamy texture and flavor.]]
{{Infobox nutritional value
| name           = Paw paw, raw with skin
| protein        = 1.2 g
| fat            = 1.2 g
| carbs          = 18.8 g
| fiber          = 2.6 g
| calcium_mg     = 63
| iron_mg        = 7
| magnesium_mg   = 113
| phosphorus_mg  = 47
| potassium_mg   = 345
| zinc_mg        = 0.9
| manganese_mg   = 2.6
| vitC_mg        = 18.3
| thiamin_mg     = 0.01
| riboflavin_mg  = 0.09
| niacin_mg      = 1.1
| vitA_ug        = 87
| note           = [http://www.pawpaw.kysu.edu/pawpaw/cooking.htm#a2 Analysis from Table 2, Kentucky State University Pawpaw Program]
}}

===Fruits===
As described by [[horticulture|horticulturist]] Barbara Damrosch, the fruit of the pawpaw "looks a bit like mango, but with pale yellow, custardy, spoonable flesh and black, easy-to-remove seeds."<ref name=Damrosch>{{cite news|last=Damrosch|first=Barbara|title=Return of the Native? Pawpaws' Proponents|newspaper=The Washington Post (Local Living, p.9)|date=8 Sep 2011}}</ref> Wild-collected pawpaw fruits, ripe in late August to mid-September, have long been a favorite treat throughout the tree's extensive native range in eastern North America, and on occasion are sold locally at [[farmers' market]]s.<ref name="KSU"/><ref name=Damrosch /> Pawpaw fruits have a sweet, custardish flavor somewhat similar to [[banana]], [[mango]], and [[cantaloupe]],<ref name="KSU"/><ref name=Werthner/><ref name="Paw Paw Tunnel">{{cite web|title=Paw Paw Tunnel|url=http://www.pawpawwv.com/local-attractions/paw-paw-tunnel|publisher=Town of Paw Paw, West Virginia|accessdate=15 July 2011}}</ref> varying significantly by source or cultivar,<ref name="KSU"/> with more [[protein]] than most fruits.<ref name="KSU"/> Nineteenth-century American agronomist [[Edward Lewis Sturtevant|E. Lewis Sturtevant]] described pawpaws as <blockquote>... a natural custard, too luscious for the relish of most people<ref name=Bilton /></blockquote> Ohio botanist William B. Werthner noted that <!-- This is a quote from his book, please do not reword.--><blockquote>The fruit ... has a tangy wild-wood flavor peculiarly its own. It is sweet, yet rather cloying to the taste and a wee bit puckery – only a boy can eat more than one at a time.<ref name=Werthner/></blockquote>

Fresh fruits of the pawpaw are commonly eaten raw, either chilled or at room temperature. However, they can be [[shelf life|kept]] only 2–3 days at room temperature, or about a week if refrigerated.<ref name=Georgia/> The easily bruised pawpaw fruits do not ship well unless frozen.<ref name="KSU"/><ref name=Damrosch /> Where pawpaws grow, the fruit pulp is also often used locally in baked dessert recipes, with pawpaw often substituted with volumetric equivalency in many [[banana]]-based recipes. Pawpaws may also be blended into [[ice cream]]<ref name=Georgia/> or included in [[pancake]]s.<ref name=Georgia/>

Due to its potential for allergic reaction causing [[contact dermatitis]] and possible presence of pesticides,<ref>{{cite journal|pmid=8365150|year=1993|author1=Avalos|first1=J|title=Guinea pig maximization test of the bark extract from pawpaw, Asimina triloba (Annonaceae)|journal=Contact Dermatitis|volume=29|issue=1|pages=33–5|last2=Rupprecht|first2=J. K.|last3=McLaughlin|first3=J. L.|last4=Rodriguez|first4=E}}</ref> pawpaw consumption may be harmful to humans.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.drugs.com/npp/pawpaw.html|title=Pawpaw uses, benefits & dosage|publisher=Drugs.com|date=2016|accessdate=2016-08-18}}</ref><ref name=neurotoxic/>

===Nutrition===

According to a report from the [[Kentucky State University]] Pawpaw Program (right table), raw pawpaw (with skin) in a 100 gram amount provides 80 [[Calories]] and is a rich source (20% or more of the [[Daily Value]], DV) of [[vitamin C]] (22% DV), [[magnesium]] (32% DV), [[iron]] (54% DV) and [[manganese]] (124% DV). The fruit also contains a moderate amount (10–19% DV) of [[vitamin A]] (11% DV).

=== Phytochemicals ===
[[File:AbbotV1Tab04AA.jpg|thumb|upright|Zebra swallowtail butterflies (''[[Eurytides marcellus]]'') with pawpaw foliage]]

[[Phytochemical]] [[extract]]s of the leaves and fruit contain [[acetogenin]]s, including the [[neurotoxin]], [[annonacin]].<ref name="neurotoxic">{{cite journal|pmid=22130466|year=2012|author1=Potts|first1=L. F.|title=Annonacin in Asimina triloba fruit: Implication for neurotoxicity|journal=NeuroToxicology|volume=33|issue=1|pages=53–8|last2=Luzzio|first2=F. A.|last3=Smith|first3=S. C.|last4=Hetman|first4=M|last5=Champy|first5=P|last6=Litvan|first6=I|doi=10.1016/j.neuro.2011.10.009|url=https://neurosciences.ucsd.edu/centers/movement-disorders/Documents/Litvan%20Article%20Annonacin.pdf}}</ref> The seeds and bark contain the chemical [[asimitrin]]<ref>{{cite journal |author1=Eun Jung Kim |author2=Kyung Mi Suh |author3=Dal Hwan Kim |author4=Eun Joo Jung |author5=Chang Seob Seo |author6=Jong Keun Son |author7=Mi Hee Woo |author8=Jerry L. McLaughlin |title=Asimitrin and 4-hydroxytrilobin, new bioactive annonaceous acetogenins from the seeds of ''Asimina triloba'' possessing a bis-tetrahydrofuran ring |journal=[[Journal of Natural Products]] |volume=68 |issue=2 |pages=194–197 |date=February 2005 |pmid=15730242 |doi=10.1021/np040184l}}</ref> and other acetogenins, including [[asimin]], [[asiminacin]] and [[asiminecin]].<ref name=neurotoxic/><ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1021/jm00039a009 |author1=Geng-Xian Zhao |author2=Laura R. Miesbauer |author3=David L. Smith |author4=Jerry L. McLaughlin |title=Asimin, asiminacin, and asiminecin: novel highly cytotoxic asimicin isomers from ''Asimina triloba'' |journal=[[Journal of Medicinal Chemistry]] |volume=37 |issue=13 |pages=1971–1976 |date=June 1994 |pmid=8027979}}</ref>

===Effect on insects===
Due to the presence of acetogenins, the leaves, twigs, and bark of pawpaw trees can be used to make an organic [[insecticide]].<ref name="Sampson"/> The one notable exception is the zebra swallowtail butterfly (''[[Eurytides marcellus]]''), whose [[larva]]e feed on the leaves of various species of ''Asimina,'' conferring protection from [[predation]] throughout the butterfly's life, as trace amounts of acetogenins remain present, making them unpalatable to birds and other predators.<ref name=Zebra>{{cite journal |author1=John M. Martin |author2=Stephen R. Madigosky |author3=Zhe-ming Gu |author4=Dawei Zhou |author5=Jinn Wu |author6=Jerry L. McLaughlin |title=Chemical defense in the zebra swallowtail butterfly, ''Eurytides marcellus'', involving annonaceous acetogenins |journal=[[Journal of Natural Products]] |volume=62 |issue=1 |pages=2–4 |date=January 1999 |pmid=9917274 |doi=10.1021/np980308s}}</ref>

===Historical uses===
The tough, fibrous inner bark of the pawpaw was used by [[Indigenous peoples of the Americas|Native Americans]] and [[settler]]s in the [[Midwestern United States|Midwest]] for making [[rope]]s, [[fishing net]]s, [[mat]]s,<ref name=Werthner/><ref name=Bilton /> and for stringing fish.<ref Name=Sargent />

Pawpaw logs have been used for [[split-rail fence]]s in [[Arkansas]].<ref name=Werthner/>

The hard, brown, shiny lima-bean-sized seeds were sometimes carried as [[Touch piece|pocket pieces]] in Ohio.<ref name=Werthner/>

==Cultural significance==

===Old song===
A traditional [[American folk music|American folk song]] portrays wild harvesting of pawpaws; Arty Schronce of the [[Government of Georgia (U.S. state)|Georgia Department of Agriculture]] gives these lyrics:<ref name=Georgia/><blockquote>
Where, oh where is dear little Nellie?<br />
Where, oh where is dear little Nellie?<br />
Where, oh where is dear little Nellie?<br />
Way down yonder in the pawpaw patch<br />
<br />
Pickin' up pawpaws, puttin' 'em in your pocket<br />
Pickin' up pawpaws, puttin' 'em in your pocket<br />
Pickin' up pawpaws, puttin' 'em in your pocket<br />
Way down yonder in the pawpaw patch</blockquote>

He notes that "picking up pawpaws" refers to gathering the ripe, fallen fruit from beneath the trees, and that the "pocket" in the song is that of an [[apron]] or similar tie-on pocket, not a modern [[trousers|pants]] or [[Jeans|blue jeans]] pocket, into which pawpaws would hardly fit.<ref name=Georgia/> A "pawpaw patch" refers to the plant's characteristic patch-forming [[clonal colony|clonal]] growth habit.

===Place names===
The pawpaw (''Asimina triloba'') is the basis for various place and school names in the United States, almost all using the older spelling variant "paw paw".

===Art===
Nineteenth-century [[naturalist]] and [[artist|painter]] [[John James Audubon]] included pawpaw foliage and fruits in the background of his illustration of the [[yellow-billed cuckoo]] (''Coccyzus americanus'') in his classic work, ''[[The Birds of America]]'' (1827–1838).

Pawpaw fruits and a pawpaw leaf are featured in the painting
[http://jama.ama-assn.org/content/300/15/1734.extract ''Still Life with Pawpaws''] (c. 1870-1875) by [[Edward Edmondson, Jr.]] (1830–1884), at the [[Dayton Art Institute]] in [[Dayton, Ohio]].

===Other===
* The [[Paw Paw Formation]], an [[Cretaceous|Early Cretaceous]] geological formation in [[Texas]] where the ''[[Pawpawsaurus]]'' (pawpaw lizard), a herbivorous Cretaceous dinosaur, was found in Texas.<ref>Weishampel, David B; et al. (2004). "Dinosaur distribution (Early Cretaceous, North America)." In: Weishampel, David B.; Dodson, Peter; and Osmólska, Halszka (eds.): The Dinosauria, 2nd, Berkeley: University of California Press. Pp. 553-556. ISBN 0-520-24209-2.</ref>
* The [[Paw Paw Tunnel]] in [[Maryland]] on the historic [[Chesapeake and Ohio Canal]], a 3118-foot (950-m) canal tunnel completed in 1850 bypassing the six-mile-long [[Paw Paw Tunnel|Paw Paw Bends]] in the [[Potomac River]] near the town of [[Paw Paw, West Virginia]], all ultimately named after the pawpaw tree.<ref name="Paw Paw Tunnel"/>
* The [[Paw Paw Railroad]] (1857–1887), which constructed and operated a 4-mile (6.4 km) rail line between Lawton and Paw Paw, in Van Buren County, Michigan.<ref>{{cite web|title=RRHX - Railroad History Time Line - 1860|url=http://www.michiganrailroads.com/RRHX/Timeline/1860s/TimeLine1860sBackUp.htm|publisher=RRHX: Railroad History of Michigan|accessdate=6 August 2011| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110723193351/http://www.michiganrailroads.com/RRHX/Timeline/1860s/TimeLine1860sBackUp.htm| archivedate= 23 July 2011 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref>
* ''[[Paw Paws]]'' (or ''Paw Paw Bears''), a 1985–1986 television cartoon series.<ref>{{cite web|title=IMDb - Paw Paws (TV Series 1985)|url=http://www.imdb.com/title/tt0283769/|publisher=Internet Movie Database|accessdate=6 August 2011}}</ref>
* The pawpaw (''Asimina triloba'') was designated as [[Ohio]]'s state native fruit in 2009.<ref>[[Ohio Revised Code]] [http://codes.ohio.gov/orc/gp5.082 5.082]</ref>
* Since 1999, The Ohio Pawpaw Growers' Association has sponsored an annual [[Pawpaw Festival|Ohio Pawpaw Festival]] at Lake Snowden, near [[Albany, Ohio]].<ref>[http://www.ohiopawpawfest.com/ Ohio Pawpaw Festival]</ref>
* Since 2012, Delaware's [[Alapocas Run State Park]] has hosted an annual Pawpaw Folk Festival featuring tastings of the fruit.<ref>{{cite web|title=Pawpaw Folk Festival set for Aug. 20 at the Blue Ball Barn|url=http://news.delaware.gov/2016/08/15/pawpaw-folk-festival-set-for-aug-20-at-the-blue-ball-barn/|accessdate=9 December 2016}}</ref>

11.text:
{{taxobox |image = Avicennia-germinans.jpg |image_caption = Black mangrove growing in [[Guanacaste Province]], [[Costa Rica]] |status = LC |status_system = iucn3.1 |regnum = [[Plant]]ae |unranked_divisio = [[Flowering plant|Angiosperms]] |unranked_classis = [[Eudicots]] |unranked_ordo = [[Asterids]] |ordo = [[Lamiales]] |familia = [[Acanthaceae]] |genus = ''[[Avicennia]]'' |species = '''''A. germinans''''' |binomial = ''Avicennia germinans'' |binomial_authority = ([[Carl Linnaeus|L.]]) L. |synonyms = ''Avicennia africana'' [[Palisot de Beauvois|P.Beauv.]]
''Avicennia nitida'' [[Nikolaus Joseph von Jacquin|Jacq.]]
''[[Bontia]] germinans'' L.{{cite web |url=http://www.ars-grin.gov/cgi-bin/npgs/html/taxon.pl?70116 |title=''Avicennia germinans'' (L.) L. |work=Germplasm Resources Information Network |publisher=United States Department of Agriculture |date=1999-07-12 |accessdate=2010-05-20}} |range_map = Avicennia germinans range map 3.png |range_map_caption = Distribution of ''Avicennia germinans'' |}} The '''black mangrove''' ('''''Avicennia germinans'''''), is a shrub in the acanthus family, [[Acanthaceae]].{{cite web|url=http://eol.org/pages/579832/details|title= Avicennia germinans_EOL }} It grows in [[Tropics|tropical]] and [[Subtropics|subtropical]] regions of the [[Americas]], on both the [[Atlantic Ocean|Atlantic]] and [[Pacific Ocean|Pacific]] [[coast]]s, and on the Atlantic coast of [[tropical Africa]], where it thrives on the [[sand]]y and muddy [[shore]]s that [[seawater]] reaches. It is common throughout coastal areas of [[Texas]] and [[Florida]], and ranges as far north as southern [[Louisiana]] and coastal [[Georgia (U.S. state)|Georgia]] in the [[United States]]. Like many other [[mangrove]] species, it reproduces by [[vivipary]]. [[Seed]]s are encased in a [[fruit]], which reveals the [[Germination|germinated]] seedling when it falls into the water. Unlike other mangrove species, it does not grow on [[Aerial root#Aerial roots as supports|prop roots]], but possesses [[Aerial root#Pneumatophores|pneumatophores]] that allow its roots to breathe even when submerged. It is a hardy species and expels absorbed salt mainly from its leathery leaves. The name "black mangrove" refers to the color of the trunk and [[Wood#Heartwood and sapwood|heartwood]]. The leaves often appear whitish from the [[salt]] [[Halophyte|excreted]] at night and on cloudy days. It is often found in its native range with the red mangrove (''[[Rhizophora mangle]]'') and the white mangrove (''[[Laguncularia racemosa]]''). White mangroves grow inland from black mangroves which themselves grow inland from red mangroves. The three species work together to stabilize the shoreline, provide buffers from [[storm surge]]s, trap debris and [[detritus]] brought in by [[tide]]s, and provide feeding, breeding, and nursery grounds for a great variety of [[fish]], [[shellfish]], [[bird]]s, and other wildlife. ==Habitat== [[Image:Black mangrove-everglades natl park.jpg|left|thumb|A black mangrove tree growing in shallow water in [[Everglades National Park]]]] [[Image:Avicennia germinans-flowers2.jpg|left|thumb|Black mangrove flowers]] The black mangrove grows just above the high [[tide]] in coastal [[lagoon]]s and [[brackish water]] [[Estuary|estuaries]]. It is less tolerant of highly saline conditions than certain other species that occur in mangrove ecosystems.World Wildlife Fund. 2010. [http://www.eoearth.org/article/Petenes_mangroves?topic=49597 ''Petenes mangroves'']. eds. Mark McGinley, C.Michael Hogan & C. Cleveland. Encyclopedia of Earth. National Council for Science and the Environment. Washington DC It can reach {{convert|10|–|15|m|ft|abbr=on}} in height, although it is a small [[shrub]] in cooler regions of its range. The [[seed]]s [[Germination|germinate]] in midsummer, but may be seen all year on the trees. The seeds can remain viable for over a year once released. ==Wood== The [[Wood#Heartwood and sapwood|heartwood]] is dark-brown to black, while the [[Wood#Heartwood and sapwood|sapwood]] is yellow-brown. It has the unusual property of having less dense heartwood than sapwood. The sapwood sinks in water while the heartwood floats. The wood is strong, heavy, and hard, but is difficult to work due to its interlocked grain and is somewhat difficult to finish due to its oily texture. Uses include posts, pilings, [[charcoal]], and [[Firewood|fuel]]. Despite growing in a marine environment, the dry wood is subject to attack by marine borers and [[termite]]s. Like many species, it contains [[tannin]] in the bark and has been used to [[Tanning (leather)|tan]] [[leather]] products. ==See also== {{Portal|Trees}} *[[List of honey plants]] *[[:Category:Mangrove ecoregions|Mangrove ecoregions]] == References == {{reflist}} ==Further reading== * {{cite book | last = Haehle | first = Robert | year = 1999 | title = Native Florida Plants | publisher = Gulf Publishing Company | location = Houston | isbn = 0-88415-425-4 }} * McKee, Karen L., Irving A. Mendelssohn, and Mark W. Hester. "Reexamination of pore water sulfide concentrations and redox potentials near the aerial roots of Rhizophora mangle and Avicennia germinans." American Journal of Botany (1988): 1352-1359. ==External links== {{commonscat-inline|Avicennia germinans|''Avicennia germinans''}} *[http://www.plantmaps.com/nrm/avicennia-germinans-black-mangrove-native-range-map.php Interactive Distribution Map of ''Avicennia germinans''] {{WestAfricanPlants|Avicennia germinans}} {{wikispecies-inline}} [[Category:Avicennia|germinans]] [[Category:Mangroves]] [[Category:Halophytes]] [[Category:Plants described in 1764]] [[Category:Flora of Cameroon]] [[Category:Flora of Equatorial Guinea]] [[Category:Flora of Gabon]] [[Category:Flora of Ghana]] [[Category:Flora of Guinea]] [[Category:Flora of Guinea-Bissau]] [[Category:Flora of Mauritania]] [[Category:Flora of Nigeria]] [[Category:Flora of Senegal]] [[Category:Flora of Sierra Leone]] [[Category:Flora of Togo]] [[Category:Trees of the Southeastern United States]] [[Category:Trees of the South-Central United States]] [[Category:Trees of Mexico]] [[Category:Trees of Belize]] [[Category:Trees of Costa Rica]] [[Category:Trees of El Salvador]] [[Category:Trees of Guatemala]] [[Category:Trees of Honduras]] [[Category:Trees of Nicaragua]] [[Category:Trees of Panama]] [[Category:Trees of Antigua and Barbuda]] [[Category:Trees of the Bahamas]] [[Category:Trees of Bermuda]] [[Category:Trees of Cuba]] [[Category:Trees of Guadeloupe]] [[Category:Trees of Hispaniola]] [[Category:Trees of Jamaica]] [[Category:Trees of Martinique]] [[Category:Trees of Puerto Rico]] [[Category:Trees of French Guiana]] [[Category:Trees of Guyana]] [[Category:Trees of Suriname]] [[Category:Trees of Venezuela]] [[Category:Trees of Brazil]] [[Category:Trees of Colombia]] [[Category:Trees of Ecuador]] [[Category:Trees of Peru]] [[Category:Trees of Africa]]

{{taxobox |image = File:Bauhinia lunarioides.jpg |regnum = [[Plant]]ae |unranked_divisio = [[Angiosperms]] |unranked_classis = [[Eudicots]] |unranked_ordo = [[Rosids]] |ordo = [[Fabales]] |familia = [[Fabaceae]] |genus = ''[[Bauhinia]]'' |species = '''''B. lunarioides''''' |binomial = ''Bauhinia lunarioides'' |binomial_authority = [[Asa Gray|A.Gray]] ex [[Sereno Watson|S.Watson]] |synonyms = ''Bauhinia congesta'' (Britton & Rose) Lundell
''Casparia congesta'' Britton & Rose{{cite web |url=http://www.ars-grin.gov/cgi-bin/npgs/html/taxon.pl?313153 |title=Taxon: ''Bauhinia lunarioides'' A. Gray ex S. Watson |work=Germplasm Resources Information Network |publisher=United States Department of Agriculture |date=1997-04-10 |accessdate=2010-10-21}} |}} '''''Bauhinia lunarioides''''' is a species of [[flowering plant]] in the family [[Fabaceae]], native to Southwestern [[Texas]] in the [[United States]] and Northern [[Mexico]]. Common names include '''Texasplume''',{{PLANTS|id=BALU|taxon=Bauhinia lunarioides|accessdate=22 January 2016}} '''Anacacho orchid tree''', and '''pata de vaca'''. It is a small [[deciduous]] tree growing to 4 m tall. The [[leaf|leaves]] are 2-5 cm long and broad, rounded, and bilobed at the base and apex. The [[flower]]s are small, white or (rarely) pink, with five petals. The [[fruit]] is a [[legume|pod]]. Though limited in range in the wild, it has become increasingly available in nurseries.{{cite web |url=http://aggie-horticulture.tamu.edu/ornamentals/nativeshrubs/bauhinialunarioid.htm |title=Anacacho Orchid Tree ''Bauhinia lunarioides'' (''B. congesta'') |work=Benny Simpson's Texas Native Shrubs |publisher=Texas A&M University |accessdate=2010-10-21}} ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== {{commonscat-inline|Bauhinia lunarioides|''Bauhinia lunarioides''}} {{wikispecies-inline|Bauhinia lunarioides|''Bauhinia lunarioides''}} [[Category:Bauhinia|lunarioides]] [[Category:Plants described in 1878]] [[Category:Trees of Coahuila]] [[Category:Trees of Nuevo León]] [[Category:Trees of the South-Central United States]] {{Caesalpinioideae-stub}}

13.text:
{{italic title}}
{{Taxobox
| name               = River birch
| image              = RiverBirchBark01.JPG
| image_caption      = The bark of a young river birch
| status             = G5
| status_system      = TNC
| regnum             = [[Plant]]ae
| unranked_divisio   = [[Angiosperms]]
| unranked_classis   = [[Eudicots]]
| unranked_ordo      = [[Rosids]]
| ordo               = [[Fagales]]
| familia            = [[Betulaceae]]
| genus              = ''[[Birch|Betula]]''
| subgenus           = ''[[Betula classification#Subgenus Neurobetula – Costate birches|Neurobetula]]''
| species            = '''''B. nigra'''''
| binomial           = ''Betula nigra''
| binomial_authority = [[Carl Linnaeus|L.]]
| range_map          = Betula nigra range map 1.png
| range_map_caption  = Natural range of ''Betula nigra''
}}

'''''Betula nigra''''' ('''black birch''', '''river birch''', '''water birch''') is a [[species]] of [[birch]] native to the Eastern United States from New Hampshire west to southern Minnesota, and south to northern Florida and west to Texas. It is one of the few heat-tolerant birches in a family of mostly cold-weather trees which do not thrive in USDA Zone 6 and up. ''B. nigra'' commonly occurs in [[flood plain]]s and/or [[swamp]]s.<ref name=fna>{{EFloras|1|233500258|Betula nigra}}</ref>

==Description==
It is a [[deciduous]] [[tree]] growing to {{convert|25-30|m|ft|round=5|sp=us}} with a trunk {{convert|50|to|150|cm|in|round=10|sp=us}} in diameter, often with multiple trunks. The [[bark]] is variable, usually dark gray-brown to pinkish-brown and scaly, but in some individuals, smooth and creamy pinkish-white, exfoliating in curly papery sheets. The twigs are glabrous or thinly hairy. The [[leaf|leaves]] are alternate, ovate, {{convert|4-8|cm|in|frac=4|sp=us}} long and {{convert|3-6|cm|in|frac=4|sp=us}} broad, with a serrated margin and five to twelve pairs of veins. The [[flower]]s are wind-pollinated [[catkin]]s {{convert|3-6|cm|frac=4|in|sp=us}} long, the male catkins pendulous, the female catkins erect. The [[fruit]] is unusual among birches in maturing in late spring; it is composed of numerous tiny winged seeds packed between the catkin bracts.<ref name=fna /><ref name=usda>{{Silvics |volume=2 |genus=Betula |species=nigra |first=H. E. |last=Grelen }}</ref>

== Cultivation and uses ==
While its native habitat is wet ground, it will grow on higher land, and its bark is quite distinctive, making it a favored ornamental tree for [[landscape architecture|landscape use]]. A number of [[cultivar]]s with much whiter bark than the normal wild type have been selected for garden planting, including 'Heritage' and 'Dura Heat'; these are notable as the only white-barked birches resistant to the [[bronze birch borer]] ''Agrilus anxius'' in warm areas of the southeastern United States of America.<ref name=harlow>Harlow, W. M., & Harrar, E. S. (1969). ''Textbook Of Dendrology'' 5th ed., LOC# 68-17188</ref>
[[File:River Birch Trunk.JPG|thumb|Trunk of a River Birch]]
[[File:River Birch Middle.JPG|thumb|Middle of the tree]]
[[File:River Birch Seeds.JPG|thumb|River Birch Leaves & Seeds]]

[[Native Americans in the United States|Native Americans]] used the boiled [[sap]] as a [[Sugar substitute|sweetener]] similar to [[maple syrup]], and the inner bark as a survival food. It is usually too contorted and knotty to be of value as a [[timber]] tree.<ref name=harlow />

== Essential oils ==
The [[essential oil]]s derived from leaves, inner bark, and buds of ''B. nigra'' are mostly composed of [[eugenol]], [[linalool]], [[palmitic acid]], and [[heptacosane]] with many more compounds in smaller concentrations.<ref name="oils">{{cite journal|last1=Woods|first1=Katherine E|last2=Chhetri|first2=Bhuwan|last3=Jones|first3=Chelsea|title=Bioactivities and Compositions of Betula nigra Essential Oils|journal=Journal of Medicinally Active Plants|date=October 2013|volume=2|issue=1|url=http://scholarworks.umass.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=1057&context=jmap|accessdate=30 July 2016}}</ref> The combined essential oils are [[phytotoxic]] to [[lettuce]] (''Lactuca sativa'') and [[perennial ryegrass]] (''Lolium perenne'') seedlings. They have also demonstrated [[insecticide|insecticidal]], [[nematicide|nematicidal]], and [[antibacterial]] properties.<ref name="oils" />

14.text:
{{Taxobox | name = Blue spruce
''Picea pungens'' | status = LC | status_system = IUCN3.1 | status_ref =  {{IUCN |assessor=A. Farjon |id=42333 |version=2014.3 |year=2011 |title=''Picea pungens'' |accessdate=10 December 2014}} | image = Picea pungens tree.jpg | regnum = [[Plant]]ae | divisio = [[Pinophyta]] | classis = [[Pinophyta|Pinopsida]] | ordo = [[Pinales]] | familia = [[Pinaceae]] | genus = ''[[spruce|Picea]]'' | species = '''''P. pungens''''' | binomial = ''Picea pungens'' | binomial_authority = [[George Engelmann|Engelm.]] | range_map = Picea pungens range map.png }} The '''blue spruce''', '''green spruce''',{{cite web|url=http://hvp.osu.edu/pocketgardener/source/description/pi_ngens.html|title=''Picea pungens'': Blue Spruce, Colorado Blue Spruce, or Green Spruce (Pinaceae - Pine Family)}} '''white spruce''',{{cite web|title=Blue spruce, ''Picea pungens'' Engelm., Plant Symbol = PIPU|url=http://plants.usda.gov/plantguide/pdf/pg_pipu.pdf|publisher=USDA NRCS}} '''Colorado spruce''', or '''Colorado blue spruce''', with the scientific name '''''Picea pungens''''', is a [[species]] of [[Picea|spruce]] tree. It is [[native plant|native]] to the [[Rocky Mountains]] of the United States. Its natural range extends from northern New Mexico through Colorado and Utah to Wyoming and into far SW Montana, but it has been widely introduced elsewhere and is used as an ornamental tree in many places far beyond its native range. The blue spruce has blue coloured needles and is a coniferous tree. ==Description== In the wild, ''Picea pungens'' grows to about {{convert|23|m|ft|0|abbr=on}}, but when planted in parks and gardens it seldom exceeds {{convert|15|m|ft|0|abbr=on}} tall by {{convert|5|m|ft|0|abbr=on}} wide. It is a columnar or conical [[evergreen]] [[pinophyta|conifer]] with densely growing horizontal branches. It has scaly grey bark on the trunk with yellowish-brown branches. Waxy grey-green leaves, up to {{convert|3|cm|0|abbr=on}} long, are arranged radially on the shoots which curve upwards. The pale brown cones are up to {{convert|10|cm|0|abbr=on}} long.{{cite book|title=RHS A-Z encyclopedia of garden plants|year=2008|publisher=Dorling Kindersley |location=United Kingdom |isbn=1405332964 |pages=1136}}[http://plants.usda.gov/java/profile?symbol=PIPU&mapType=nativity&photoID=pipu_001_ahp.jpg USDA] Accessed 2012-12-01{{cite book |title = Michigan Trees: A Guide to the Trees of Michigan and the Great Lakes Region |last = Barnes |first = Burton V. |author2=Warren J. Wagner Jr. |series = Biological Science Series |publisher = University of Michigan Press |date = September 15, 1981 |isbn = 978-0-472-08018-2}}{{cite book |title=Trees and Bushes |last=Vedel |first=H. |last2=Lange |first2=J. |year=1962 |publisher=Methuen & Co |isbn=978-0416617801 |pages=119–120 }} The [[Botanical name#Binary name|specific epithet]] ''pungens'' means "sharply pointed", referring to the leaves.{{cite book|last=Harrison|first=Lorraine|title=RHS Latin for gardeners|year=2012|publisher=Mitchell Beazley|location=United Kingdom|isbn=9781845337315|pages=224}} The blue spruce is the State Tree of [[Colorado]].{{cite web |url = http://www.usna.usda.gov/Gardens/collections/statetreeflower.html |title = State Trees & State Flowers |publisher = [[United States National Arboretum]] |date = June 11, 2009 |accessdate = 2010-05-26}} ==Cultivation== ''Picea pungens'' and its many [[cultivar]]s are often grown as [[ornamental tree]]s in gardens and parks.[http://www.conifers.org/pi/Picea_pungens.php Conifers.org] . accessed 1.12.2012 It is also grown for the [[Christmas tree]] industry. [[File:2015-05-18 13 01 32 Blue Spruce new growth along Terrace Boulevard in Ewing, New Jersey.jpg|thumb|left|'Mission Blue' blue spruce new growth in spring]] ===Pests and diseases=== The blue spruce is attacked by two species of ''[[Adelges]]'', an aphid-like insect that causes galls to form. [[Nymph (biology)|Nymphs]] of the [[pineapple gall adelgid]] form galls at the base of twigs which resemble miniature pineapples and those of the [[Gall adelgid|Cooley's spruce gall adelgid]] cause cone-shaped galls at the tips of branches. The larva of the [[spruce budworm]] eat the buds and growing shoots while the [[spruce needle miner]] hollows out the needles and makes them coalesce in a webbed mass. An elongated white [[scale insect]], the [[Chionaspis pinifoliae|pine needle scale]] feeds on the needles causing fluffy white patches on the twigs and aphids also suck sap from the needles and may cause them to fall and possibly dieback. Mites can also infest the blue spruce, especially in a dry summer, causing yellowing of the oldest needles.{{cite web |url=http://edis.ifas.ufl.edu/st453 |title=''Picea pungens'': Colorado Spruce |author1=Gilman, Edward F. |author2=Watson, Dennis G. |date=2011-05-01 |work=EDIS |publisher=IFAS Extension Service: University of Florida |accessdate=2013-10-06}}{{cite web |url=http://www.ext.colostate.edu/pubs/insect/05514.html |title=Scale Insects Affecting Conifers |author=Cranshaw, W. S. |date=2013-06-13 |work= |publisher=Colorado State University Extension |accessdate=2013-10-05}} Another insect pest is the [[Dendroctonus rufipennis|spruce beetle]] (''Dendroctonus rufipennis'') which bores under the bark. It often first attacks trees which have blown over by the wind and when the larvae mature two years afterwards, a major outbreak occurs and vast numbers of beetles attack nearby standing trees.{{cite web |url=http://www.ext.colostate.edu/pubs/columngw/gr120421.html |title=Spruce Beetle Threatens High Country Spruce Forests |author=Ciesla, Bill |date=2013-04-19 |publisher=Colorado State University Extension |accessdate=2013-10-05}} The blue spruce is susceptible to several needle casting diseases which cause the needles to turn yellow, mottled or brown before they fall off. Various rust diseases also affect the tree causing yellowing of the needles as well as needle fall. [[Canker]] caused by ''[[Cytospora]]'' attacks one of the lower branches first and progressively makes its way higher up the tree. The first symptom is the needles turning reddish-brown and falling off. Meanwhile, patches of white [[resin]] appear on the bark and the branch eventually dies. ===Cultivars=== [[File:Picea pungens 'Glauca globosa' in Autumn.JPG|thumb|Foliage of the cultivar 'Glauca globosa']] Common cultivars (those marked {{smallcaps|agm}} have gained the [[Royal Horticultural Society]]'s [[Award of Garden Merit]]):- *'Glauca Globosa'{{smallcaps|agm}}{{cite web|title=RHS Plant Selector - ''Picea pungens'' 'Globosa'|url=http://apps.rhs.org.uk/plantselector/plant?plantid=1465|accessdate=27 May 2013}} - shrub from {{convert|3|-|5|ft|m}} in height[http://www.missouribotanicalgarden.org/gardens-gardening/your-garden/plant-finder/plant-details/kc/c825/picea-pungens-glauca-globosa.aspx Missouri Botanical Garden: ''Picea pungens'' 'Glauca Globosa'] *'Fat Albert' - compact perfect cone to {{convert|10|ft|m}} of a silver blue color[http://www.missouribotanicalgarden.org/gardens-gardening/your-garden/plant-finder/plant-details/kc/e660/picea-pungens-fat-albert.aspx Missouri Botanical Garden: ''Picea pungens'' Fat Albert] *'Glauca Jean's Dilly' - shrub from {{convert|3|-|6|ft|m}} in height[http://www.missouribotanicalgarden.org/gardens-gardening/your-garden/plant-finder/plant-details/kc/a421/picea-glauca-jean's-dilly.aspx Missouri Botanical Garden: ''Picea pungens'' 'Glauca Jean's Dilly'] *'Glauca Pendula' - drooping branches, spreads to about {{convert|8|ft|m}} wide by {{convert|4|ft|m}} tall[http://www.finegardening.com/plantguide/picea-pungens-glauca-pendula-colorado-blue-spruce.aspx Fine Gardening Plant Guide: Picea pungens ‘Glauca Pendula'] *'Hoopsii' {{smallcaps|agm}}{{cite web|title=RHS Plant Selector - ''Picea pungens'' 'Hoopsii'|url=http://apps.rhs.org.uk/plantselector/plant?plantid=1466|accessdate=27 May 2013}} *'Koster'{{cite web|title=RHS Plant Selector - ''Picea pungens'' 'Koster'|url=http://apps.rhs.org.uk/plantselector/plant?plantid=1467|accessdate=27 May 2013}} *'Baby Blue Eyes'{{cite web|title=Missouri Botanical Garden - ''Picea pungens 'Baby Blueeyes'| url=http://www.missouribotanicalgarden.org/gardens-gardening/your-garden/plant-finder/plant-details/kc/d137/picea-pungens-baby-blueeyes.aspx}}{{cite web|title=Washington State University - ''Picea pungens 'Baby Blueeyes'| url=http://www.pnwplants.wsu.edu/PlantDisplay.aspx?PlantID=243}} *'Baby Blue' {{cite web|title=West Montrose Farms Ltd - ''Picea pungens 'Baby Blue'| url=http://www.babybluespruce.com/}} ==Uses== The [[Navajo people|Navajo]] and [[Keresan languages|Keres]] Native Americans used this tree as a traditional [[medicinal plant]] and a ceremonial item, and twigs are given as gifts to bring good fortune. In traditional medicine, an infusion of the needles is used to treat colds and settle the stomach. This liquid is also used externally for rheumatic pains. Early people used their wood for building.[http://herb.umd.umich.edu/herb/search.pl?searchstring=Picea+pungens U. Michigan-Dearborn: Ethnobotany] Accessed 2012-12-01 ==Gallery== File:Picea pungens2.jpg|Mature cone File:Picea Pungens Young Cones.jpg|Immature cone File:Picea_pungens_Hoopsii201601.jpg|Hoopsii File:Picea pungens 'Koster' Lappen nursery.jpg|Koster File:Picea pungens Globosa2.jpg|Globosa File:Picea pungens Montgomery.jpg|Montgomery File:Fat Albert Colorado spruce.jpg|Fat Albert ==See also== *[[Pungenin]] ==References== {{reflist|32em}} ==External links== {{sister project links|Picea pungens}} *[http://plants.usda.gov/java/profile?symbol=PIPU&mapType=nativity&photoID=pipu_001_ahp.jpg USDA Plant Profile for ''Picea pungens'' (blue spruce)] *[http://www.conifers.org/pi/Picea_pungens.php Conifers.org: Picea pungens (blue spruce) description] *[http://www.wildflower.org/plants/result.php?id_plant=PIPU Lady Bird Johnson Wildflower Center NPIN] — Native Plant Information Network *[http://www.plantmaps.com/nrm/picea-pungens-blue-spruce-native-range-map.php Interactive Distribution Map of ''Picea pungens''] *[http://calphotos.berkeley.edu/cgi/img_query?query_src=photos_index&where-taxon=Picea+pungens ''Picea pungens''] — U.C. 15.text:
{{italic title}}
{{Taxobox
| name               = Bitternut hickory
| image              = Carya cordiformis.jpg
| image_caption      = Bitternut hickory foliage
| regnum             = [[Plant]]ae
| unranked_divisio   = [[Angiosperms]]
| unranked_classis   = [[Eudicots]]
| unranked_ordo      = [[Rosids]]
| ordo               = [[Fagales]]
| familia            = [[Juglandaceae]]
| genus              = ''[[Carya]]''
| species            = '''''C. cordiformis'''''
| binomial           = ''Carya cordiformis''
| binomial_authority = ([[Friedrich Adam Julius von Wangenheim|Wangenh.]]) [[Karl Koch (botanist)|K.Koch]]
| range_map          = Carya cordiformis range map 1.png
| range_map_caption  = Natural range
}}

'''''Carya cordiformis''''', the '''bitternut hickory''',<ref>{{PLANTS|id=CACO15|taxon=Carya cordiformis|access-date=1 October 2016}}</ref> also called bitternut or swamp hickory, is a large pecan hickory with commercial stands located mostly north of the other pecan hickories. Bitternut hickory is cut and sold in mixture with the true hickories. It is the shortest-lived of the hickories, living to about 200 years.<ref>{{Silvics |volume=2 |genus=Carya |species=cordiformis |first=H. Clay |last=Smith |access-date=14 December 2009}}</ref>

== Description ==
[[File:BitternutTwig.jpg|thumb|left|Twig of a bitternut]]

It is a large [[deciduous]] [[tree]], growing up to {{convert|35|m|ft|sp=us|abbr=on}} tall (exceptionally to {{convert|47|m|ft|disp=or|abbr=on}}), with a trunk up to {{convert|1|m|ftin|abbr=on}} diameter. The [[leaf|leaves]] are {{convert|15|-|30|cm|in|0|abbr=on}} long, pinnate, with 7–11 leaflets, each leaflet lanceolate, {{convert|7|-|13|cm|in|frac=4|abbr=on}} long, with the apical leaflets the largest but only slightly so. The [[flower]]s are small wind-pollinated [[catkin]]s, produced in spring. The [[fruit]] is a very bitter [[nut (fruit)|nut]], {{convert|2|-|3|cm|in|frac=4|abbr=on}} long with a green four-valved cover which splits off at maturity in the fall, and a hard, bony shell. Another identifying characteristic is its bright sulfur-yellow winter bud.

It is closely related to the [[pecan]], sharing similar leaf shape and being classified in the same section of the genus ''Carya'' sect. ''Apocarya'', but unlike the pecan, it does not have edible nuts. It is most readily distinguished from the pecan by the smaller number of leaflets, with many leaves having only 7 leaflets (rarely fewer than 9, and often 11–13, in the pecan). [[Hybrid (biology)|Hybrids]] with the pecan are known, and named ''Carya'' × ''brownii''. A hybrid between the shagbark hickory (''C. ovata'') is also recognized, and is known as Laney's hickory (''Carya'' ×''laneyi'').<ref>http://www.freefictionbooks.org/books/n/18194-northern-nut-growers-association-report-of-the-pro?start=97</ref>
[[File:Carya cordiformis NRCS-1.jpg|thumb|right|Bitternut leaf]]

== Habitat ==
[[File:Carya cordiformis leaves.jpg|thumb|left|Branch of a bitternut hickory with developing nuts]]
Bitternut hickory grows in moist mountain valleys along streambanks and in swamps. Although it is usually found on wet bottom lands, it grows on dry sites and also grows well on poor soils low in nutrients. The species is not included as a titled species in the Society of American Foresters forest cover types because it does not grow in sufficient numbers.

== Range ==
[[File:Bitternutrangemap.jpg|thumb|left|US range map of ''Carya cordiformis'']]

Bitternut hickory grows throughout the eastern United States from southwestern New Hampshire, Vermont, Maine, and southern Quebec; west to southern Ontario, central Michigan, and northern Minnesota; south to eastern Texas; and east to northwestern Florida and Georgia. It is most common, however, from southern New England west to Iowa and from southern Michigan south to Kentucky. It is probably the most abundant and most uniformly distributed of all the hickories.

== Uses ==
Bitternut is used for lumber and pulpwood. Because bitternut hickory wood is hard and durable, it is used for furniture, paneling, dowels, tool handles and ladders. Like other hickories, the [[wood]] is used for [[smoking (food)|smoking]] [[meat]], and by [[Indigenous peoples of the Americas|Native Americans]] for making [[bow (weapon)|bows]]. Bitternut hickory seeds and its bark are eaten by wildlife.
