26.text:
{{taxobox |image = Ebenopsis ebano fruit.jpg |image_caption = fruit |regnum = [[Plant]]ae |unranked_divisio = [[Angiosperms]] |unranked_classis = [[Eudicots]] |unranked_ordo = [[Rosids]] |ordo = [[Fabales]] |familia = [[Fabaceae]] |genus = ''[[Ebenopsis]]'' |species = '''''E. ebano''''' |binomial = ''Ebenopsis ebano'' |binomial_authority = ([[Jean-Louis Berlandier|Berland.]]) [[Rupert Charles Barneby|Barneby]] & [[James Walter Grimes|J.W.Grimes]] |synonyms = ''[[Acacia]] flexicaulis'' [[George Bentham|Benth.]]
''[[Chloroleucon]] ebano'' (Berland.) [[Maria de Lourdes Rico|L.Rico]]
''[[Mimosa]] ebano'' Berland.
''[[Pithecellobium]] ebano'' (Berland.) [[Cornelius Herman Muller|C.H.Müll.]]
''Pithecellobium flexicaule'' (Benth.) [[John Merle Coulter|J.M.Coult.]]
''[[Zygia]] flexicaulis'' (Benth.) [[George Bishop Sudworth|Sudw.]]{{cite web |url=http://www.ars-grin.gov/cgi-bin/npgs/html/taxon.pl?405171 |title=Genus: ''Ebenopsis ebano'' (Berland.) Barneby & J.W.Grimes |work=Germplasm Resources Information Network |publisher=United States Department of Agriculture |date=2002-06-28 |accessdate=2009-11-25}} |range_map = Pithecellobium flexicaule range map.jpg |range_map_caption = Natural range |}} '''''Ebenopsis ebano''''' is a species of [[flowering plant]] in the [[pea]] family, [[Fabaceae]], that is native to the coastal plain of southern [[Texas]] in the [[United States]] and eastern [[Mexico]].{{cite web |url=http://www.wildflower.org/plants/result.php?id_plant=EBEB |title=''Ebenopsis ebano'' (Texas Ebony) |work=Native Plant Database |publisher=Lady Bird Johnson Wildflower Center|accessdate=2009-07-06}} It is commonly known as '''Texas Ebony''' or '''Ébano''' (in [[Spanish language|Spanish]]). ==Description== Texas Ebony is a small, [[evergreen]] [[tree]] that reaches a height of {{convert|7.6|-|9.1|m|ft|abbr=on}} and a crown width of {{convert|1.8|-|4.6|m|ft|abbr=on}}.{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=AyWkIsLDca8C&dq |title=Trees and Shrubs for the Southwest: Woody Plants for Arid Gardens |first=Mary |last=Irish |publisher=Timber Press |year=2008 |isbn=978-0-88192-905-8 |pages=178–179}} [[File:TexasEbony.JPG|thumb|Texas Ebony (Chloroleucon Ebano)]] ==Habitat and range== The range of ''E. ebano'' stretches from [[Laredo, Texas|Laredo]] and [[Corpus Christi, Texas]]{{cite web |url=http://www.plants.usda.gov/java/profile?symbol=EBEB |title=''Ebenopsis ebano'' (Berl.) Barneby & Grimes Texas ebony |work=The PLANTS Database |publisher=United States Department of Agriculture |accessdate=2010-11-25}} south through the states of [[Tamaulipas]], [[Nuevo León]], [[San Luis Potosí]], [[Veracruz]], [[Campeche]], and [[Yucatán (state)|Yucatán]] in [[Mexico]].{{cite web |url=http://www.conafor.gob.mx:8080/documentos/docs/13/919Ebenopsis%20ebano%20.pdf |title=''Ebenopsis ebano'' (Berl.) Britton et Rose |work=Reforestación: Fichas Técnicas |publisher=[[CONAFOR]] |language=Spanish |accessdate=2009-07-09}} It can be found in the [[Tamaulipan matorral]],{{cite journal |url=http://www.inecol.edu.mx/myb/resumeness/13.1/MB_2007_13-1_099-117.pdf |first=Jaime F. |last=García Pérez |author2=Óscar Aguirre Calderón |author3=Eduardo Estrada Castillón |author4=Joel Flores Rivas |author5=Javier Jiménez Pérez |author6= Enrique Jurado Ybarra |title=Germinación y establecimiento de plantas nativas del matorral tamaulipeco y una especie introducida en un gradiente de elevación |journal=Madera y Bosques |volume=13 |issue=1 |year=2007 |pages=99–117 |language=Spanish}} [[Tamaulipan mezquital]],{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=JsuiJEwOIJUC |first=David Lewis |last=Lentz |title=Imperfect Balance: Landscape Transformations in the Precolumbian Americas |publisher=Columbia University Press |isbn=978-0-231-11157-7 |page=79 |year=2000}} [[Veracruz dry forests]], and [[Yucatán dry forests]] ecoregions.{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=yxhFZ4erCj8C |first=Les |last=Beletsky |title=Southern Mexico: the Cancún Region, Yucatán Peninsula, Oaxaca, Chiapas, and Tabasco |publisher=Interlink Books |year=2006 |isbn=978-1-56656-640-7 |page=23}} Its habitat extends from sea level to {{convert|1000|m|ft|abbr=on}}, averages {{convert|20|to|27|C|F|abbr=on}} in temperature, and receives a mean of {{convert|900|mm|in|abbr=on}} of annual rainfall. ==Uses== Texas Ebony is cultivated in [[xeriscaping]] for its dense foliage and fragrant [[flower]]s.{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=W-qD3bHUnakC |first=George Oxford |last=Miller |title=Landscaping with Native Plants of the Southwest |publisher=MBI Publishing Company |isbn=978-0-7603-2968-9 |page=63 |date=2007-03-15}} It is also used in [[bonsai]].{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=_pBWYeemKYcC |first=Robert |last=Mahler |author2=Julian Velasco |title=Growing Bonsai Indoors |editors=Pat Lucke Morris; Sigrun Wolff Saphire |publisher=Brooklyn Botanic Garden |year=2008 |isbn=978-1-889538-42-6 |pages=48–49}} ==Ecology== ''E. ebano'' is a [[Host (biology)|host]] plant for the [[caterpillar]]s of the Coyote Cloudywing (''[[Achalarus toxeus]]''){{cite web |url=http://www.butterfliesandmoths.org/species?l=1945 |title=Coyote Cloudywing ''Achalarus toxeus'' (Plötz, 1882) |publisher=Butterflies and Moths of North America |accessdate=2010-03-30}} and ''[[Sphingicampa]] [[Sphingicampa blanchardi|blanchardi]]''.{{cite web |url=http://www.butterfliesandmoths.org/species?l=3339 |title=Sphingicampa blanchardi ''Sphingicampa blanchardi'' |publisher=Butterflies and Moths of North America |accessdate=2010-03-30}} The seedpods host the [[bean weevil]]s ''[[Stator (genus)|Stator]] [[Stator beali|beali]]'' and ''[[Stator limbatus|S. limbatus]]''. Despite the native range of Texas Ebony overlapping with that of the latter, ''S. limbatus'' only feeds upon it in locales where it is grown as an ornamental and is not native.{{cite journal |url=http://www.sekj.org/PDF/anzf43/anzf43-239.pdf |first=Charles W. |last=Fox |title=Colonization of a new host by a seed-feeding beetle: Genetic variation, maternal experience, and the effect of an alternate host |journal=Annales Zoologici Fennici |volume=43 |year=2006 |pages=239–247}} ''E. ebano'' is also a preferred host of the [[epiphyte]] Bailey's Ball Moss (''[[Tillandsia baileyi]]'').{{cite journal |url=http://nativeplantproject.com/SABALS/SABAL0509.pdf |first=Sue |last=Sill |title=''Tillandsia baileyi'' rose - Texas’s Disappearing Native Air-Plant |journal=The Sabal |publisher=Native Plant Project |volume=26 |issue=5 |date=May 2009 |pages=1–5}} ==References== {{commons category}} {{wikispecies}} {{reflist}} ==External links== *{{cite web |url=http://aggie-horticulture.tamu.edu/ornamentals/natives/pithecellobiumflexicaule.htm |title=Texas Ebony, Ebano, Ebony Blackbeard, Ebony Apes-earring ''Pithecellobium flexicaule'' |work=Benny Simpson's Native Trees of Texas |publisher=Texas A&M University}} *{{cite web |url=http://esp.cr.usgs.gov/data/atlas/little/pithflex.pdf |format=PDF |title=Pithecellobium flexicaule |work=Digital Representations of Tree Species Range Maps from "Atlas of United States Trees" by Elbert L. Little, Jr. (and other publications) |publisher=United States Geological Survey |accessdate=}} [[Category:Mimosoideae]] [[Category:Plants described in 1996]] [[Category:Trees of the Yucatán Peninsula]] [[Category:Trees of Campeche]] [[Category:Trees of Nuevo León]] [[Category:Trees of Tamaulipas]] [[Category:Trees of the South-Central United States]] [[Category:Trees of Veracruz]] [[Category:Garden plants of North America]] [[Category:Plants used in bonsai]]
26.title: Ebenopsis ebano

27.text:
{{taxobox |image =Ehretia anacua flowers.jpg |image_caption = |regnum = [[Plant]]ae |unranked_divisio = [[Flowering plant|Angiosperms]] |unranked_classis = [[Eudicots]] |unranked_ordo = [[Asterids]] |ordo = (unplaced) |familia = [[Boraginaceae]] |genus = ''[[Ehretia]]'' |species = '''''E. anacua''''' |binomial = ''Ehretia anacua'' |binomial_authority = ([[Manuel de Mier y Terán|Terán]] & [[Jean-Louis Berlandier|Berland.]]) [[Ivan Murray Johnston|I.M.Johnst.]] |synonyms = ''Ehretia elliptica'' [[Augustin Pyramus de Candolle|DC.]]
''Gaza anacua'' Terán & Berland.{{cite web |url=http://www.ars-grin.gov/cgi-bin/npgs/html/taxon.pl?14894 |title=''Ehretia anacua'' (Terán & Berland.) I. M. Johnst. |work=Germplasm Resources Information Network |publisher=United States Department of Agriculture |date=2001-03-28 |accessdate=2009-11-25}} |range_map = Ehretia anacua range map.png |range_map_caption = Natural range |}} '''''Ehretia anacua''''' is medium-sized tree found in eastern [[Mexico]] and southern [[Texas]] in the United States. It is a member of the [[borage]] family, [[Boraginaceae]]. One of its common names, '''anacua''', is derived from the [[Mexican Spanish]] word ''anacahuite'', as is that of the related ''[[Cordia boissieri]]'', the ''anacahuita''.{{cite web |url=http://www.wildflower.org/plants/result.php?id_plant=ehan |title=''Ehretia anacua'' (Teran & Berl.) I.M. Johnston |work=Native Plant Information Network |publisher=Lady Bird Johnson Wildflower Center |accessdate=2009-12-10}} That word in turn is derived from the [[Nahuatl]] words ''[[Amatl|āmatl]]'', meaning "paper," and ''quatitl'', meaning "tree,"{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=82U_AAAAYAAJ |title=The Garden of Chaparral: Plants of the Lower Rio Grande Valley |first=Elizabeth M. |last=Riess |publisher=Vantage Press |year=1958 |page=127}} possibly referring to the bark. It is also known as '''knockaway''', a corruption of anacua, and '''sandpaper tree'''. ==Description== Anacua reaches a height of {{convert|20|-|45|ft|m|abbr=on}} and a diameter of {{convert|0.3|m|ft|abbr=on}},{{cite web|url=http://www.enature.com/fieldguides/detail.asp?fotogID=1342&curPageNum=50&recnum=ts0719 |title=Anacua ''Ehretia anacua'' |work=Field Guides |publisher=eNature |accessdate=2009-09-29 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110614152208/http://www.enature.com/fieldguides/detail.asp?fotogID=1342&curPageNum=50&recnum=ts0719 |archivedate=2011-06-14 |df= }} often producing [[Vegetative reproduction|suckers]] or multiple trunks. The [[bark]] is reddish-brown to gray with narrow furrows and peeling scales. The dark green [[Leaf|leaves]] are {{convert|3|-|8|cm|in|abbr=on}} and {{convert|2|-|4|cm|in|abbr=on}} wide and elliptical or ovate. Their upper surfaces are remarkably rough, feeling like low-grade [[sandpaper]]. Anacua is a partial [[evergreen]], replacing some of the leaves in early spring. Abundant white [[flower]]s form in [[panicle]]s or [[Inflorescence|cymes]]{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=IbouuNpSCHUC |title=Plants of the Texas Coastal Bend |first=Roy |last=Lehman |author2=Ruth O'Brien |author3=Tammy White |publisher=Texas A&M University Press |year=2005 |isbn=978-1-58544-408-3|page=111}} {{convert|5|-|7.5|cm|in|abbr=on}} in length at the ends of twigs, making trees appear to be covered in snow when in bloom from spring to summer. Flowers are {{convert|8|mm|in|abbr=on}} wide and have 5 [[Petal#Corolla|corolla]] lobes. The [[fruit]]s are spherical [[drupe]]s{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Wp7JFnRUaXAC& |title=Trees of Central Texas |first=Robert A. |last=Vines |publisher=University of Texas Press |year=1984 |isbn=978-0-292-78058-3 |page=349}} 8 mm in diameter and yellowish-orange. The drupes contain two stones, each with two [[seed]]s. In addition to being edible by humans, the drupes are eaten by [[mammal]]s and [[bird]]s such as the [[clay-colored thrush]].{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=shL2DmZCwh8C&dq |title=Chasing Birds Across Texas: a Birding Big Year |first=Mark Thomas |last=Adams |author2=Brush Freeman |publisher=Texas A&M University Press |year=2003 |isbn=978-1-58544-296-6 |page=36}} The lifespan of an Anacua is at least 50 years.{{cite web |url=http://www.valleyproud.org/PDFs/08_Tree_Guide_07.pdf |title=A Guide to Growing Healthy Trees in the Lower Rio Grande Valley of Texas |publisher=Valley Proud Environmental Council |year=2007 |accessdate=2009-12-10}} ==Habitat== Anacua is found on dry hillsides as a [[shrub]], but reaches tree size in the moist soils of [[riparian zone]]s and [[floodplain]]s. It can be found at elevations from sea level to {{convert|1000|ft|m|abbr=on}}. ==Ecology== The leaves of ''E. anacua'' are the sole food source of the Texas tortoise beetle (''[[Coptocycla]] [[Coptocycla texana|texana]]'').{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=sO6ax1TtnzEC& |title=Invertebrates of Central Texas Wetlands |first=Stephen Welton |last=Taber |author2=Scott B. Fleenor |publisher=Texas Tech University Press |year=2005 |isbn=978-0-89672-550-8 |pages=147–148}} ==References== {{Commons category}} {{Wikispecies}} {{reflist}} ==External links== *{{cite web |url=http://esp.cr.usgs.gov/data/atlas/little/ehreanac.pdf |format=PDF |title=Ehretia anacua |work=Digital Representations of Tree Species Range Maps from "Atlas of United States Trees" by Elbert L. Little, Jr. (and other publications) |publisher=United States Geological Survey |accessdate=}} [[Category:Ehretia|anacua]] [[Category:Trees of Mexico]] [[Category:Trees of the South-Central United States]] [[Category:Trees of Chiapas]] [[Category:Trees of Coahuila]] [[Category:Trees of Hidalgo (state)]] [[Category:Trees of Nuevo León]] [[Category:Trees of Querétaro]] [[Category:Trees of San Luis Potosí]] [[Category:Trees of Tamaulipas]] [[Category:Trees of Veracruz]] [[Category:Flora of Texas]] [[Category:Plants described in 1924]]
27.title: Ehretia anacua

28.text:
{{italic title}}
{{taxobox
|name = ''Eysenhardtia orthocarpa''
|regnum = [[Plant]]ae
|unranked_divisio = [[Angiosperms]]
|unranked_classis = [[Eudicots]]
|unranked_ordo = [[Rosids]]
|ordo = [[Fabales]]
|familia = [[Fabaceae]]
|genus = ''[[Eysenhardtia]]''
|species = '''''E. orthocarpa'''''
|binomial = ''E. orthocarpa''
|binomial_authority = ([[Asa Gray|A.Gray]]) [[Sereno Watson|S.Watson]]
}}

'''''Eysenhardtia orthocarpa''''' is a species of small [[flowering plant|flowering tree]], (a kidneywood) in the [[legume]] family, [[Fabaceae]]. Its range is at the northern region of the [[Sierra Madre Occidental]] cordillera of eastern [[Sonora]]; it is also in central Sonora,<ref>Little, ''Atlas of United States Trees, Volume 3, Minor Western Hardwoods'', Map 72-N, Map 72-W, '''''Eysenhardtia polystachya'''''.</ref> with the species ranging into southeast [[Arizona]] and the extreme southwest, bootheel region of [[New Mexico]],<ref>Little, Map 72-N, Map 72-W, '''''Eysenhardtia polystachya'''''.</ref> the entire [[sky island]] region at the northern cordillera called [[Madrean Sky Islands]].

==Range==

The range in central Sonora is the eastern [[Sonoran Desert]], with the desert extending into southeast Arizona. The species avoids the hotter, and lower elevation desert region west-northwestwards in Arizona; in Sonora it also avoids the hot [[Gran Desierto de Altar]] that lies to the northwest, at the eastern shore of the [[Gulf of California]].<ref>Little, Map 72-N, Map 72-W, '''''Eysenhardtia polystachya'''''.</ref>

===Ranges of 3 Mexican species===
The range of ''E. polystachya'', (Ortega) Sarg. in Vol. 3, Minor Western Hardwoods, Little,<ref>Little, Map 72-N, Map 72-W, '''Eysenhardtia polystachya'''.</ref> shows the [[Mexican Plateau]] range of "kidneywood" from Chihuahua-Coahuila-Nuevo León-Tamalulipas south to Hidalgo in the [[Sierra Madre Oriental]], in the southeast, and to Pacific Coast western [[Oaxaca]] at the south.

On the map, '''''E. orthocarpa''''' is a [[disjunct distribution|disjunct]] population of the Sonoran-Arizona-New Mexico group. Of note ''E. Texana'' ([[George Heinrich Adolf Scheele|Scheele]]), lies intersecting the range ''E. polystachya'' to the northeast in southeast Chihuahua-Coahuila-Nuevo León;<ref>Little, Map 71, '''''[[Eysenhardtia texana]]'''''.</ref> there, it is the continuation of the species ''E. polystachya'' northeastwards into [[Texas]], but as the species ''[[Eysenhardtia texana]]''.

The resolution of the three groups are thus ''orthocarpa'' in the northwest, ''texana'' in the northeast, and ''polystachya'' in the rest of central and southern Mexico.

29.text:
{{italic title}}
{{taxobox
|name = ''Eysenhardtia texana''
|image = Eysenhardtia texana.jpg
|status = G5
|status_system = TNC
|regnum = [[Plant]]ae
|unranked_divisio = [[Angiosperms]]
|unranked_classis = [[Eudicots]]
|unranked_ordo = [[Rosids]]
|ordo = [[Fabales]]
|familia = [[Fabaceae]]
|genus = ''[[Eysenhardtia]]''
|species = '''''E. texana'''''

|binomial_authority = [[George Heinrich Adolf Scheele|Scheele]]

}}

'''''Eysenhardtia texana''''', commonly known as '''Texas kidneywood''', '''bee-brush''', or '''vara dulce''',<ref name="NPIN">{{cite web |url=http://www.wildflower.org/plants/result.php?id_plant=EYTE |title=''Eysenhardtia texana'' Scheele Texas kidneywood, Kidneywood, Bee-Brush, Vara dulce|work=Native Plant Information Network |publisher=Lady Bird Johnson Wildflower Center}}</ref> is a species of small [[flowering plant|flowering tree]] in the [[legume]] family, [[Fabaceae]]. It is found from south-central Texas south to northern [[San Luis Potosí]] in the [[Rio Grande Valley]] region of south Texas–[[Northeastern Mexico]], and the species ranges into the eastern [[Chihuahuan Desert]] areas of [[Coahuila]].<ref>Little, ''Atlas of United States Trees, Volume 3, Minor Western Hardwoods'', Map 71, ''Eysenhardtia texana''.</ref>

==Distribution==
The [[contiguous]] range of Texas kidneywood covers the three neighboring Mexican states of [[Coahuila]], [[Nuevo Leon]], and [[Tamaulipas]] in northeast Mexico, the [[Rio Grande]] valley, from [[Big Bend National Park|Big Bend]] southeastwards, but not the coastal Gulf of Mexico areas, only 25–50 miles inland. Part of the range extends southwards into extreme northern [[San Luis Potosí]],<ref>Little, Map 71, ''Eysenhardtia texana''.</ref> and some isolated locales towards east-central and southern Texas.

30.text:
{{citations needed|date=November 2013}}
[[File:Fatwood firestarters.jpg|thumb|Slivers of fatwood, used for starting fires.]]
[[File:Olaus Magnus - About Lighting and Torches of Kindling.jpg|thumb|Using fatwood lighters while working in [[Olaus Magnus]]' ''Historia de gentibus septentrionalibus'' 1555]]
[[File:Kienspanhalter Niederrhein 18-19 Jh.JPG|thumb|Fatwood holder made of clay with fatwood stump, lower Rhine area, Germany, 18th or 19th century]]
[[File:Stickstake, Kaälsjö socken, Halland.JPG|thumb|Holder for kindling stick, Källsjö parish, Halland - [[Nordiska museet]], Stockholm]]
'''Fatwood''', also known as "fat lighter," "lighter wood," "rich lighter," "pine knot," <ref>{{cite news|title=An Awesome Pine Knot Wood Spirit|url=http://www.stixandstoneswoodcarving.com/carving-awesome-pine-knots|accessdate=17 March 2016|work=stixandstoneswoodcarving}}</ref> "lighter knot," "heart pine" or "lighter'd"{{sic}}, is derived from the [[Heartwood#Heartwood and sapwood|heartwood]] of [[pine]] trees. This resin-impregnated [[heartwood]] becomes hard and rot-resistant. The [[Tree stump|stump]] (and [[tap root]]) left in the ground after a tree has fallen or has been cut is an excellent source of fatwood. Other locations, such as the joints where limbs intersect the trunk, can also be harvested.  Although most resinous pines can produce fatwood, in the southeastern United States the wood is commonly associated with [[Pinus palustris|longleaf pine]] (''Pinus palustris''), which historically was highly valued for its high [[Pitch (resin)|pitch]] production.

==History==
The commercial use of fatwood from stumps stemmed from its use to make [[Pitch (resin)|pitch]] and [[pine tar]]. In 1648, a company was formed in [[Sweden]] called ''Norrländska Tjärkompaniet'' (The Wood Tar Company of North Sweden), and was given exclusive export rights[for pinetar - see separate topic- not fatwood] by the [[King of Sweden]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.maritime.org/conf/conf-kaye-tar.htm |title=Pine Tar; History And Uses |publisher=Maritime.org |date=1997-07-07 |accessdate=2012-11-09}}</ref>

==Composition==
Coniferous tree sap is a [[Viscosity|viscous]] [[liquid]], that contains [[terpene]], a [[Volatility (chemistry)|volatile]] [[hydrocarbon]]. Over time the [[evaporation]] of the terpene changes the state of the sap; it slowly gets thicker until it hardens into [[resin]]. New fatwood leaks the sticky sap, while in aged fatwood the sap has hardened and is no longer sticky. At every stage of the aging process, fatwood will burn readily, even when wet.

==Wood kindling and tinder==
Because of the flammability of terpene, fatwood is prized for use as kindling in starting fires. It lights quickly even when wet, is very wind resistant, and burns hot enough to light larger pieces of wood. A small piece of fatwood can be used many times to create tinder by shaving small curls and using them to light other larger tinder. In [[Louisiana]] "fatwood" is known as "rich lighter" and cut slivers are what is referred to as "kindling" because of the abundance{{clarification needed|date=December 2016}}. The pitch-soaked wood produces an oily, sooty smoke, and it is recommended{{by whom?|date=December 2016}} that one should not cook on a fire until all the fatwood has completely burned out.  The smoke produced by "fatwood" is considered{{by whom?|date=December 2016}} to be an excellent bug (especially [[mosquito]]) [[Insect repellent|repellent]] (although this is unproven).

==Distribution==
There are between 105 and 125 [[species]] classified as [[resin]]ous [[Pine|pine trees]] around the world. Species usable for fatwood are distributed across a range including Eurasia, where they range from the Canary Islands, Iberian Peninsula and Scotland east to the Russian Far East. From the Philippines, Norway, Finland and Sweden (Scots Pine), and eastern Siberia (Siberian Dwarf Pine), and south to northernmost Africa. From the Himalaya and Southeast Asia, with one species (Sumatran Pine) just crossing the Equator in Sumatra,. In North America, they range from 66°N in Canada (Jack Pine), to [[Central America]] to 12°N in Nicaragua (Caribbean Pine). The highest diversity in the genus occurs in Mexico and California. In the sub-tropics of the Southern Hemisphere, including Chile, Brazil, South Africa, Australia, Argentina and New Zealand, where the trees are not [[indigenous (ecology)|indigenous]] but were introduced. Anywhere there is a pine tree or pine [[Tree stump|stump]], there can be fatwood that can be found on top of the ground, but is more concentrated and preserved in stumps.

===The United States===
In the United States the pine tree, ''[[Pinus palustris]]'', known as the Longleaf pine, once covered as much as  {{convert|90000000|acre|km2}} but due to [[clear cutting]] was reduced by between 95% and 97%. The trees grow very large (up to 150 feet), taking 100 to 150 years to mature and can live up to 500 years. The wood was prized and cutting resulted in many hundreds of thousands of stumps that are very resinous, do not rot, and eventually become fatwood. This ushered in a new industry for many years. There is still a market for the wood, but supplies are less abundant. Due to the length of growing time, the ''[[Pinus taeda]]'', also called the Loblolly pine, replaced it for commercial replanting, with a maturity of only 38 to 45 years.

==Industrial uses==
Industrial uses for fatwood include production of [[turpentine]]; when fatwood is cooked down in a fire kiln, the heavier resin product that results is [[pine tar]]. The [[steam]] that vaporizes from this process is turned into a liquid that becomes turpentine.

===Other uses===
Tree resins or by-products are used in many different things to include;
*Household chemicals especially for cleaning such as turpentine and pine oil.
*Nail polish
*medical to include dental
*Cutler's resin is still used in making knife handles.

{{Commons category|Fraxinus americana}}
'''''Fraxinus americana''''' ('''white ash''' or '''American ash''') is a species of ''[[Fraxinus|ash tree]]'' native to eastern and central [[North America]]. It is found in [[mesophytic]] [[hardwood]] [[forest]]s from [[Nova Scotia]] west to [[Minnesota]], south to northern [[Florida]], and southwest to eastern [[Texas]]. Isolated populations have also been found in western [[Texas]], [[Wyoming]] and [[Colorado]], and the species is reportedly naturalized in [[Hawaii]].<ref name=grin>{{GRIN|316687|Fraxinus americana}}</ref><ref>[http://apps.kew.org/wcsp/namedetail.do?name_id=369468 Kew World Checklist of Selected Plant Families,  ''Fraxinus americana'']</ref><ref>{{BONAP|ref|genus=Fraxinus|species=americana}}</ref>

== Characteristics ==
The name White Ash derives from the [[glaucous]] undersides of the leaves. It is similar in appearance to the [[Green Ash]], making identification difficult. The lower sides of the leaves of White Ash are lighter in color than their upper sides, and the outer surface of the twigs of White Ash may be flaky or peeling. Green Ash leaves are similar in color on upper and lower sides, and twigs are smoother. Despite some overlap, the two species tend to grow in different locations as well; White Ash is a forest tree that commonly occurs alongside [[Sugar Maple]] while Green Ash is a [[pioneer species]] that inhabits [[riparian zones]] and disturbed areas.<ref name=ncp>Common Trees of the North Carolina Piedmont: [http://www.ibiblio.org/openkey/intkey/web/FRAM2.htm ''Fraxinus americana'']</ref><ref name=nb>New Brunswick tree and shrub: [http://scf.rncan.gc.ca/subsite/mx-212/whiteash ''Fraxinus americana'']</ref>

[[File:2015-10-21 10 57 30 White Ash foliage during autumn along Pennington Road (New Jersey Route 31) in Ewing, New Jersey.jpg|thumb|left|Autumn foliage]]

== Cultivation and uses ==

White ash is one of the most used trees for everyday purposes and, to keep up with high demand, is cultivated almost everywhere it can be. The wood is white and quite dense (within 20% of 670 kg/m3),<ref name="White Ash">[http://www.nichetimbers.co.uk/north-american-hardwood/ash/ White Ash], ''Niche Timbers''. Retrieved on 2009-07-24.</ref> strong, and straight-grained. It is the timber of choice for production of [[baseball bat]]s and tool handles. The wood is also favorable for furniture and [[Wood flooring|flooring]]. Woodworkers use the timber mainly for interior uses due to high perishability in contact with ground soil.<ref name="White Ash" /> It is also used to make [[lobster trap]]s. Since the 1950s, it has also become a popular choice for solid [[electric guitar]] bodies.<ref name="Tech Talk: Ash and Alder">[http://www2.fender.com/experience/tech-talk/tech-talk-ash-and-alder/]</ref> It makes a very servicable [[longbow]] if properly worked. The wood was used in ceiling fan blades from the 1970s through the mid-1980s, though cane was sometimes simulated with plastic then. It is no longer used for ceiling fan blades in most countries.

White Ash is not seen in cultivation as often as Green Ash due to its preference for undisturbed forest sites away from urban pollution and soil compaction, but sometimes has been planted for its consistently reliably autumn colors, which typically are bright orange and red hues as opposed to other species of ash that produce a uniform yellow color.

A related species, Biltmore Ash, is sometimes treated as a variety of White Ash. However, other taxonomists argue that Biltmore Ash is its own species (''Fraxinus biltmoreana'').<ref>Nesom, G.L. (2010) "Fraxinus biltmoreana and Fraxinus smallii (Oleaceae): forest trees of the eastern United States". ''Phytoneuron'' 2010-51: 1-30</ref><ref>Weakley (2015) ''Flora of the Southern and Mid-Atlantic States''. University of North Carolina Herbarium, Chapel Hill, NC</ref>

== Emerald ash borer ==
{{Main|Emerald ash borer}}
The emerald ash borer (''Agrilus planipennis''), also commonly known by the [[acronym]] EAB, is a green [[beetle]] native to Asia.

In [[North America]] the [[emerald ash borer]] is an invasive species, highly destructive to ash trees in its introduced range. The damage of this insect rivals that of [[Chestnut blight]] and [[Dutch Elm Disease]].<ref>{{cite book|author=Bruce Schlink|title=Americans Held Hostage by the Environmentalist Movement|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=7mkXBaIFpuAC&pg=PA494&lpg=PA4940|year=2012|publisher=Dorrance Publishing|page=494|isbn=978-1-4349-7536-2}}</ref> To put its damage in perspective, the number of [[chestnuts]] killed by the [[Chestnut blight]] was around 3.5 billion chestnut trees while there are 3.5 billion ash trees in [[Ohio]] alone. [[Dutch Elm Disease]] killed only 200 million elm trees while EAB threatens 7.5 billion ash trees in the United States. The insect threatens the entire North American genus ''Fraxinus'', while past invasive tree pests have only threatened a single species within a genus. Since its accidental introduction into the United States and Canada in the 1990s, and its subsequent detection in 2002, it has spread to eleven states and adjacent parts of Canada. It has killed at least 50 million ash trees so far and threatens to kill most of the ash trees throughout North America. The green ash and the black ash trees are affected. White ash is also killed rapidly, but usually only after green and black ash trees are eliminated. Blue ash displays some resistance to the emerald ash borer by forming callous tissue around EAB galleries; however, they are usually killed. White ash has been less affected by emerald ash borer due to its small population (unlike its cousin, ''F. americana'' is not commonly seen in cultivation) compared to green ash, which was planted in huge numbers as an ornamental.<ref>[http://joa.isa-arbor.com/request.asp?JournalID=1&ArticleID=3011&Type=2 Andrea C. Anulewicz, Deborah G. McCullough, and David L. Cappaert. 2007. Emerald Ash Borer ''(Agrilus planipennis)'' Density and Canopy Dieback in Three North American Ash Species. Arboriculture & Urban Forestry 2007. 33(5):338–349.]</ref><ref>[http://emeraldashborer.info/ Emerald Ash Borer, United States Department of Agriculture, National Forest Service Forest Service and Michigan State University]</ref>

'''''Fraxinus anomala''''' is a species of [[ash tree]] known by the common name '''single-leaf ash'''. It is native to the [[southwestern United States]] and northern [[Mexico]], where it grows in a number of habitats including [[Deserts and xeric shrublands|desert scrub]] and [[chaparral]]. It is unusual in the genus in that some (though not all) specimens have simple leaves instead of the pinnate leaves more characteristic of the group.

==Description==
''Fraxinus anomala'' is a deciduous [[shrub]] or small tree approaching maximum heights of five to six meters. The leaf may be simple or it may be compound, composed of up to five leaflets which look like individual leaves. Each leaflet is oval-shaped to round and may have teeth along the edges. The nondescript brownish flowers lack petals. The fruit is a flat [[Samara (fruit)|samara]] up to two centimeters long and one wide, green when young and tan to brown when mature. The samaras hang in bunches.

==Distribution==
In [[Arizona]], singleleaf ash is found along the [[Arizona transition zone]] of the [[Mogollon Rim]]. In northern Arizona's [[Grand Canyon]], the range extends down the main canyons from southern and southeastern [[Utah]], its major range area, where the [[Canyon Lands]] also show the range entering upper reaches of river basins flowing from western [[Colorado]] – [[Colorado River|Colorado]] and [[Dolores River]]s; also the shorter [[Yellowjacket River|Yellowjacket]] and [[McElmo River]]s in Colorado's extreme southwest.<ref>Little. ''Atlas of United States Trees, Volume 3, Minor Western Hardwoods'', Map 75, ''Fraxinus anomala''.</ref> In the [[Mojave Desert]] of [[California]] it is found in the [[sky island]] [[California interior chaparral and woodlands|chaparral and woodland]] [[habitat]]s. Minor locales also occur in southern [[Nevada]] and southern [[Wyoming]].<ref>Little. Map 75, ''Fraxinus anomala''.</ref><ref>[http://bonap.net/MapGallery/County/Fraxinus%20anomala.png Biota of North America Program, ''Fraxinus anomala'' ]</ref>

'''''Fraxinus caroliniana''''', commonly known as the '''pop ash''', '''Florida ash''', '''swamp ash''', '''Carolina ash''', or '''water ash''', is a species of [[Fraxinus|ash]] tree native from [[Cuba]] through the subtropical southeastern United States from southern [[Virginia]] to [[Texas]]. It was originally described by the botanist [[Philip Miller]]. It is a small tree about 40 ft. Leaves are compound, opposite, 7–12 in long, leaflets 5–7 in, ovate to oblong, coarsely serrate or entire, 3–6 in long, 2–3 in wide. Fruit is frequently 3-winged (samara) with flat seed portion; seed sometimes a bright violet color. It is the smallest of eastern North American ash species, wood light, soft, weak, 22 lbs/cu/ft. Typical to coastal swamps and subtropical lowlands.

'''''Fraxinus pennsylvanica''''' ('''green ash''' or '''red ash''')<ref name=usfs /> is a species of [[ash tree|ash]] native to eastern and central [[North America]], from [[Nova Scotia]] west to southeastern [[Alberta]] and eastern [[Colorado]], south to northern [[Florida]], and southwest to [[Oklahoma]] and eastern [[Texas]]. It has spread and become naturalized in much of the western United States and also in Europe from [[Spain]] to [[Russia]].<ref name=grin>{{GRIN|306|Fraxinus pennsylvanica}}</ref><ref>[http://apps.kew.org/wcsp/namedetail.do?name_id=370006 Kew World Checklist of Selected Plant Families, ''Fraxinus pennsylvanica'']</ref><ref>{{BONAP|ref|genus=Fraxinus|species=pennsylvanica}}</ref>

Other names more rarely used include downy ash, swamp ash and water ash.

== Description ==
[[File:Green Ash Fraxinus pennsylvanica Bark 2000px.jpg|left|thumb|Bark]]
''Fraxinus pennsylvanica'' is a medium-sized [[deciduous]] [[tree]] reaching {{convert|12|–|25|m|ft|0|abbr=on}} (rarely to {{convert|45|m|ft|disp=or|abbr=on}}) tall with a trunk up to {{convert|60|cm|in|0|abbr=on}} in diameter. The [[bark]] is smooth and gray on young trees, becoming thick and fissured with age. The winter buds are reddish-brown, with a velvety texture. The [[leaf|leaves]] are {{convert|15|–|30|cm|in|0|abbr=on}} long, pinnately compound with seven to nine (occasionally five or eleven) leaflets, these {{convert|5|–|15|cm|in|0|abbr=on}} (rarely {{convert|18|cm|in|frac=4|disp=or|abbr=on}}) long and {{convert|1.2|–|9|cm|in|frac=16|abbr=on}} broad, with serrated margins and short but distinct, downy [[petiolule]]s a few millimeters long. They are green both above and below. The autumn color is golden-yellow and depending on the climate, Green Ash's leaves may begin changing color the first week of September.{{where|reason=Temperature regimes vary widely across the green ash's range.|date=September 2016}} The [[flower]]s are produced in spring at the same time as the new leaves, in compact [[panicle]]s; they are inconspicuous with no petals, and are wind-pollinated. The [[fruit]] is a [[Samara (fruit)|samara]] {{convert|2.5|-|7.5|cm|in|frac=8|abbr=on}} long comprising a single [[seed]] {{convert|1.5|–|3|cm|in|frac=8|abbr=on}} long with an elongated apical wing {{convert|2|–|4|cm|in|frac=4|abbr=on}} long and {{convert|3|–|7|mm|in|frac=32|abbr=on}} broad.<ref name=ncp>Common Trees of the North Carolina Piedmont: [http://www.ibiblio.org/openkey/intkey/web/FRPE.htm ''Fraxinus pennsylvanica'']</ref><ref name=nopd>Northern Ontario Plant Database: [http://www.northernontarioflora.ca/description.cfm?speciesid=1000494 ''Fraxinus pennsylvanica'']</ref><ref name=vplants>Virtual Herbarium of the Chicago Region: [http://www.vplants.org/plants/species/species.jsp?gid=17021 ''Fraxinus pennsylvanica'']</ref><ref name=obs>Oklahoma Biological Survey: [http://www.biosurvey.ou.edu/shrub/fram2.htm ''Fraxinus pennsylvanica'']</ref>

It is sometimes divided into two [[variety (botany)|varieties]], ''Fraxinus pennsylvanica'' var. ''pennsylvanica'' (red ash) and ''Fraxinus pennsylvanica'' var. ''lanceolata'' (Borkh.) Sarg. (syn. var. ''subintegerrima'' (Vahl) Fern.; green ash) on the basis of the hairless leaves with narrower leaflets of the latter, but the two intergrade completely, and the distinction is no longer upheld by most botanists.<ref name=grin />

== Ecology ==
[[File:Fraxinus pennsylvanica.jpg|left|thumb|Bark and leaf]]
It is the most widely distributed of all the American ashes, although its range centers on the Midwestern US and Great Plains. A pioneer species, it naturally grows along streambanks and disturbed areas. The large seed crops provide food to many kinds of wildlife.<ref name=usfs>{{Silvics |first=Harvey E. |last=Kennedy, Jr. |volume=2 |genus=Fraxinus |species=pennsylvanica}}</ref>

Green ash is threatened by the [[emerald ash borer]], a [[beetle]] introduced accidentally from [[Asia]] to which it has no natural resistance.<ref name=eab>Emerald ash borer: [http://www.emeraldashborer.info/ EAB website]</ref> A common garden experiment showed that green ash is killed readily when exposed to emerald ash borer, while the Asian species [[Fraxinus mandschurica|''F. mandschurica'']] shows resistance against emerald ash borer.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Rebek|first1=Eric J.|last2=Herms|first2=Daniel A.|last3=Smitley|first3=David R.|title=Interspecific Variation in Resistance to Emerald Ash Borer (Coleoptera: Buprestidae) Among North American and Asian Ash (''Fraxinus'' spp.)|journal=Environmental Entomology|date=1 February 2008|volume=37|issue=1|pages=242–246|doi=10.1603/0046-225X(2008)37[242:IVIRTE]2.0.CO;2|pmid=18348816}}</ref> The [[United States Forest Service]] has discovered small numbers of green ash in the wild that have remained healthy after emerald ash borer swept through the population.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Knight|first1=Kathleen S.|title=Dynamics of surviving ash (Fraxinus spp.) populations in areas long infested by emerald ash borer (Agrilus planipennis)|journal=Proceedings of the fourth international workshop on the genetics of host-parasite interactions in forestry: Disease and insect resistance in forest trees|date=2012|pages=143–152|url=http://www.nrs.fs.fed.us/pubs/44120|display-authors=etal}}</ref> The possibility of these trees possessing [[Genetics|genetic]] resistance to the beetle is currently being investigated with the hope that green ash could be restored using the surviving trees.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Koch|first1=J. L.|last2=Carey|first2=D. W.|last3=Mason|first3=M. E.|last4=Poland|first4=T. M.|last5=Knight|first5=K. S.|title=Intraspecific variation in Fraxinus pennsylvanica responses to emerald ash borer (Agrilus planipennis)|journal=New Forests|date=21 June 2015|volume=46|issue=5–6|pages=995–1011|doi=10.1007/s11056-015-9494-4}}</ref>

The spread of emerald ash borer was facilitated by the extensive use of green ash as an ornamental tree in the central US following the loss of [[American elm]]s in the 1950s-60s due to [[Dutch elm disease]]. That epidemic was the result of a similar overuse of elms in urban environments, leading to a [[monoculture]] that lacked any disease or pest resistance. Scientifically for red ash this is because modern cultivars utilized regionally were parented from sometimes only four individual trees selected for unique traits and male seedless flowering. Proclaiming a harsh lesson learned, cities like Chicago did not replace dead elms with a 1:1 ash:elm ratio. Instead, Norway, silver, red and sugar maples, honey locust, linden/basswood, redbud, crabapples and hackberry, among others, were also utilized during this recovery period and in new urban and suburban areas. Fortunately, with these additional species, many cities were able to reduce the percent of ash and other species to much lower levels (20% average) than during the Dutch elm disease era where from 56% to 100% of the trees were elm.

Both American elm and green ash were extremely popular due to rapid growth and tolerance of urban pollution and road salt, so many housing developments in [[Michigan]] were lined from end to end with ashes, a result of which the beetles had an enormous food supply to boost their population well above Infestation thresholds. The tree was also extensively propagated and sold by local nurseries. According to the American Nursery Industry, "Back in the late 1980s, Dr. Frank Santamour Jr., then a research geneticist with the U.S. National Arboretum, proposed the 10-20-30 formula for diversity in the urban forest, limiting the plantings in a community to no more than 10 percent within a single species, 20 percent within a genus and 30 percent within a family."" Because of EAB today, many communities  are using a more strict 20 -10-5 rule.

The emerald ash borer proved to be a far worse and potentially more serious threat than epidemics of the past such as chestnut blight and Dutch elm disease because those diseases spread at a slower rate, only affected one species, and did not kill the trees before they could attain reproductive maturity. Many areas have banned the sale of ash seedlings in nurseries, although seeds may be sold as they are not a vector for the insect.

== Uses ==
{{Refimprove section|date=July 2015}}

=== Urban ornamental trees ===
[[File:2014-10-29 13 12 58 Green Ash foliage during autumn coloration in Ewing, New Jersey.JPG|thumb|right|Autumn leaf color]]
Green ash is one of the most widely planted [[ornamental plant|ornamental trees]] throughout the [[United States]] and much of [[Canada]] but mostly [[Alberta]], including in western areas where it is not native. It is also widely planted in [[Argentina]]. It is very popular due to its good form and resistance to disease. About 40% of boulevard trees in [[Edmonton, Alberta]] are green ash.<ref>Edmonton: [http://www.rewedmonton.ca/content_view_rew?CONTENT_ID=1214 trees]</ref>

For the last two centuries [[American elm]] and ash, which both belong to the ancient Elm-Ash-Cottonwood Bottomland ecosystem,<ref>{{cite web|last1=Cook|first1=Bill|title=Forest management guidelines for Michigan|url=http://michigansaf.org/Business/MSAFguide-2010/1-4a-Wetland.html|website=Michigan SAF Home Page|publisher=Michigan Society of American Foresters|accessdate=5 July 2015}}</ref> achieved distinction as North America's two most popularly planted urban species, used primarily for their superior survival traits and slowly maturing 180-300 year majestic natural beauty. Today used as living national monuments, the National Park Service is protecting [[Thomas Jefferson]]'s 200-year-old planted example, and [[George Washington]]'s 250-year-old [[white ash]] which has a 600-year possible lifespan.{{citation needed|date=July 2015}} Green ash had been widely used as a primary ornamental and long lived monument tree until the elm fad of the 1880s, and regained top position once again after [[Dutch elm disease]] arrived.{{citation needed|date=July 2015}}

Other continents learned of American ash species' urban survivability and unique beauty through the worldwide popularity of Midwestern Prairie style ecology and architectural movement. Modernizing cities in [[Russia]] and [[China]] then began using imported green ash a century ago to line streets and landscape new public parks.{{citation needed|date=July 2015}} When one Chinese city's original collection, which had survived into late 1980's suddenly all died, city fathers used trees by sending them back to America as wooden crates containing Chinese made parts supplying the American auto industry.{{citation needed|date=July 2015}} Advantages of green ash include its tolerance of harsh urban environmental conditions, ease of propagation, and (in eastern North America) its value for wildlife as a native [[keystone species]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Ash Tree Identification|url=http://www.nyis.info/?action=eab_ash_tree_identification|website=New York Invasive Species Information|publisher=Cornell University Cooperative Extension|accessdate=5 July 2015}}</ref>

=== Other uses ===
Green ash [[wood]] is similar in properties to [[Fraxinus americana|white ash]] wood, and is marketed together as "white ash". The commercial supply is mostly in the South. It is very popular, used in making [[electric guitar]]s because it can be somewhat lighter than white ash without sacrificing too much in tone. It has a bright sound with long sustain, plus the wood grain is aesthetically desirable to many guitar players. [[Gibson]], [[Fender Musical Instruments Corporation|Fender]], [[Ibanez]], [[Warwick (company)|Warwick]], M2Guitars and many other [[luthier]]s use ash in the construction of their guitars.

|status_ref = <ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.natureserve.org/explorer/servlet/NatureServe?sourceTemplate=tabular_report.wmt&loadTemplate=species_RptComprehensive.wmt&selectedReport=RptComprehensive.wmt&summaryView=tabular_report.wmt&elKey=SYN.105038&paging=home&save=true&startIndex=1&nextStartIndex=1&reset=false&offPageSelectedElKey=SYN.105038&offPageSelectedElType=species_synonymn&offPageYesNo=true&post_processes=&radiobutton=radiobutton&selectedIndexes=SYN.105038 |title=''Guajacum angustifolium'' - Engelm. Texas Guaiacum |work=NatureServe Explorer |publisher=NatureServe |accessdate=2009-11-28}}</ref>
|image = Guaiacum angustifolium.jpg
|regnum = [[Plant]]ae
|unranked_divisio = [[Flowering plant|Angiosperms]]
|unranked_classis = [[Eudicots]]
|unranked_ordo = [[Rosids]]
|ordo = [[Zygophyllales]]

|species = '''''G. angustifolium'''''
|binomial = ''Guaiacum angustifolium''
|binomial_authority = [[George Engelmann|Engelm.]]
|synonyms = ''[[Porlieria]] angustifolia'' <small>(Engelm.) [[Asa Gray|A.Gray]]</small><ref name="GRIN">{{cite web |url=http://www.ars-grin.gov/cgi-bin/npgs/html/taxon.pl?18045 |title=Taxon: ''Guaiacum angustifolium'' Engelm. |work=Germplasm Resources Information Network |publisher=United States Department of Agriculture |date=2004-04-01 |accessdate=2009-11-28}}</ref>
|range_map =  Guaiacum angustifolium range map.jpg
|range_map_caption = Natural range
|}}

'''''Guaiacum angustifolium''''' is a species of [[flowering plant]] in the [[Tribulus terrestris|caltrop]] [[Family (biology)|family]], [[Zygophyllaceae]]. Common names include '''Texas guaiacum''', '''Texas lignum-vitae''', '''soapbush''' and '''huayacán'''. It is native to southern and western [[Texas]]<ref>{{cite web |url=http://aggie-horticulture.tamu.edu/ornamentals/nativeshrubs/guaiacumangusti.htm |title=Guayacan, Guajacum, Soapbush, Texas Porlieria |work=Texas Native Plants Database |publisher=[[Texas A&M University]] |accessdate=2009-01-29}}</ref> in the [[United States]] and northern [[Mexico]].<ref name="GRIN"/> The specific name is derived from the [[Latin]] words ''angustus'', meaning "narrow," and ''folius'', meaning "leaf."<ref>{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=u2n5vusQ1DEC& |title=Etymological Dictionary of Succulent Plant Names |first=Urs |last=Eggli |author2=Leonard E. Newton |publisher=Birkhäuser |year=2004 |isbn=978-3-540-00489-9 |page=11}}</ref>

==Description==
Texas lignum-vitae is a many branched [[shrub]] or small [[tree]], reaching a height of {{convert|7|m|ft|abbr=on}}.<ref name="Richardson">{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=vF_1X65cDxYC&dq |title=Plants of the Rio Grande Delta |first=Alfred |last=Richardson |publisher=University of Texas Press |year=1995 |isbn=978-0-292-77070-6 |page=123}}</ref> 
This [[evergreen]] has a dense [[Canopy (biology)|canopy]] and short lateral branches.<ref name="TARE">{{cite web |url=http://uvalde.tamu.edu/herbarium/guan.htm |title=Guayacan Soap-bush ''Guaiacum angustifolium'' Engelm |work=Native Plants of South Texas |publisher=Texas AgriLife Research and Extension at Uvalde |accessdate=2009-12-07}}</ref>
===Leaves===
[[Leaf|Leaves]] are {{convert|1|-|3|cm|in|abbr=on}} long, [[Phyllotaxis|opposite]] and [[pinnate]]ly compound, with four to eight pairs of [[leaflet (botany)|leaflets]]. The dark green, leathery, linear to linear-spatulate leaflets are {{convert|5|-|16|mm|in|abbr=on}} long and {{convert|2|-|3|mm|in|abbr=on}} wide. Leaflets fold themselves at night and when exposed to hot sunlight.
===Flowers===
The small blue to purple [[flower]]s are {{convert|12|-|22|mm|in|abbr=on}} in diameter. They have five [[sepal]]s, five [[petal]]s around {{convert|1|cm|in|abbr=on}} in length, and ten [[stamen]]s.<ref name="Powell">{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=dgm6yecY5D8C&dq |title=Trees and Shrubs of the Trans-Pecos and Adjacent Areas |first=A. Michael |last=Powell |publisher=University of Texas Press |year=1998 |isbn=978-0-292-75147-7 |pages=203–204}}</ref> The blooming period lasts from March until September,<ref name="Mielke">{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=7KFT2hGIFPMC&dq |title=Native Plants for Southwestern Landscapes |first=Judy |last=Mielke |publisher=University of Texas Press |year=1993 |isbn=978-0-292-75147-7|page=158}}</ref> with flowers appearing after rain.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.dendro.cnre.vt.edu/dendrology/syllabus2/factsheet.cfm?ID=884 |title=soapbush Zygophyllaceae ''Guaiacum angustifolium'' Engelm. |work=VTreeID |publisher=Virginia Polytechnic Institute and State University |accessdate=2010-10-04}}</ref> 
===Fruit===
The fruit is a flat, leathery [[Capsule (fruit)|capsule]] {{convert|1|-|2|cm|in|abbr=on}} in diameter with one to two lobes, sometimes as many as four. [[Dehiscence (botany)|Dehiscent]] [[locule]]s contain a single shiny, [[bean]]-like [[seed]] that is usually bright red.<ref name="Powell"/>

==Uses==
Like other species in its [[Guaiacum|genus]], the [[Lignum vitae|wood]] of ''G. angustifolium'' has extreme hardness and density and will sink in water. The [[Wood#Heartwood and sapwood|sapwood]] is creamy yellow, while the [[Wood#Heartwood and sapwood|heartwood]] is dark purple-brown.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.texasbeyondhistory.net/ethnobot/images/guayacan.html |title=Guayacán ''Guaiacum angustifolium'' Engelm. |work=Ethnobotany of the Lower Pecos Canyonlands |publisher=Texas Beyond History |accessdate=2009-12-07}}</ref> The wood is used for fence posts, tool handles, and [[firewood]]. Root extracts are used to treat [[rheumatism]] and [[sexually transmitted disease]]s.<ref name="TARE"/> [[Soap]] can be made from the root bark because it contains [[saponin]]; historically soap made in this way would be used to wash [[wool]].<ref name="Irish">{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=AyWkIsLDca8C&dq |title=Trees and Shrubs for the Southwest: Woody Plants for Arid Gardens |first=Mary |last=Irish |publisher=Timber Press |year=2008 |isbn=978-0-88192-905-8 |pages=205–206}}</ref> The [[flower]]s are [[List of honey plants|valued]] by [[Beekeeping|beekeepers]] for their consistent [[nectar]] production.<ref>{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=JpllAAAAMAAJ&vq |first=Frank Chapman |last=Pellett |title=American Honey Plants |publisher=American Bee Journal |year=1920 |page=237}}</ref> Texas lignum-vitae is cultivated as an [[Ornamental plant|ornamental]] because of its [[drought tolerance]], dense foliage, compact size, gnarled branches, and fragrant flowers.<ref name="Mielke"/> It is used in [[hedge]]s, [[Garden design#Rock garden|rock gardens]], and [[xeriscaping]].<ref name="TARE"/>

==Ecology==
''Guaiacum angustifolium'' is a [[Host (biology)|host]] plant for the [[caterpillar]]s of the lyside sulphur (''[[Kricogonia lyside]]'').<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.butterfliesandmoths.org/species?l=1446 |title=Lyside Sulphur ''Kricogonia lyside'' (Godart, 1819) |publisher=Butterflies and Moths of North America |accessdate=2009-11-28}}</ref> The leaves contain 16-18% crude protein and are browsed by [[White-tailed deer]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://ckwri.tamuk.edu/research-programs/south-texas-natives/native-plant-list/shrubs/guayacan/ |title=Guayacan (''Guajacum angustifolium'') |work=Native Plant List |publisher=[[Caesar Kleberg]] Wildlife Research Institute |accessdate=2010-08-20}}</ref>

==Conservation==
Like other members of its genus, the international trade of Texas lignum-vitae is restricted by [[CITES]] [[CITES#Appendix II|Appendix II]]. Only seeds, pollen, and finished products ready for retail sale may be legally exported.<ref name="CITES">{{cite web |url=http://www.unep-wcmc.org/isdb/CITES/Taxonomy/tax-species-result.cfm/isdb/CITES/Taxonomy/tax-species-result.cfm?displaylanguage=eng&Genus=%25Guaiacum%25&source=plants&Species=angustifolia&Country= |title=''Guaiacum angustifolia'' Engelm. |work=UNEP-WCMC Species Database: CITES-Listed Species |publisher=CITES |accessdate=2010-10-04}}</ref>

'''''Halesia diptera''''' ('''two-wing silverbell''' or '''two-winged snowdrop tree''') is a species in the family [[Styracaceae]], native to the southeastern [[United States]] from [[South Carolina]] and [[Florida]] west to eastern [[Texas]].<ref name=grin>Germplasm Resources Information Network: [http://www.ars-grin.gov/cgi-bin/npgs/html/taxon.pl?318114 ''Halesia diptera'']</ref> It is cultivated as an [[ornamental tree]].

==Description==
It is a large [[shrub]] or small [[tree]] reaching 4-8 m tall. The [[leaf|leaves]] are [[deciduous]], 6-12 cm long and 4-7 cm broad. The [[flower]]s are white, 2-2.5 cm long, produced in clusters of 3-6 together. The [[fruit]] is a dry (non-fleshy) [[drupe]] with two wings down the sides; this distinguishes it from the other species of ''[[Halesia]]'', which have four wings on the fruit.<ref name=rhs>Huxley, A., ed. (1992). ''New RHS Dictionary of Gardening''. Macmillan ISBN 0-333-47494-5.</ref>

==Varieties==
There are two varieties:<ref name=grin/>
*''Halesia diptera'' var. ''diptera''
*''Halesia diptera'' var. ''magniflora'' R.K.Godfrey
[[File:Isola Bella (75).JPG|thumb|left|Mature tree in flower]]

{{Italic title}}
{{taxobox
|name = ''Ilex cassine''
|image = Ilex-cassine-new-hanover-co-nc-29aug2009-P1210171-cwcook.jpg
|image_alt = Ilex cassine leaves and immature fruits
|regnum = [[Plantae]]
|unranked_divisio = [[Angiosperms]]
|unranked_classis = [[Eudicots]]
|unranked_ordo = [[Asterids]]
|ordo = [[Aquifoliales]]
|familia = [[Aquifoliaceae]]
|genus = ''[[Holly|Ilex]]''
|species = '''''I. cassine'''''
|binomial = ''Ilex cassine''
|binomial_authority = [[Carl Linnaeus|L.]]<ref name=grin>{{cite web |url=http://www.ars-grin.gov/cgi-bin/npgs/html/taxon.pl?19681 |title=Taxon: ''Ilex cassine'' L. |work=Germplasm Resources Information Network |publisher=United States Department of Agriculture |date=1999-04-19 |accessdate=2011-09-20}}</ref>
|range_map =  Ilex cassine range map 4.png
|range_map_caption = Natural range in United States
}}

'''''Ilex cassine''''' is a [[holly]] native to the southeastern coast of [[North America]], in the [[United States]] from [[Virginia]] to southeast [[Texas]], in [[Mexico]] in [[Veracruz]], and in the [[Caribbean]] on [[the Bahamas]], [[Cuba]], and [[Puerto Rico]]. It is commonly known as '''dahoon holly'''<ref name=grin/> or '''''cassena''''', the latter derived from the [[Timucua language|Timucua]] name for ''[[Ilex vomitoria|I. vomitoria]]''.<ref name="Austin">{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=eS7lX_rC3GEC |first=Daniel F. |last=Austin |title=Florida Ethnobotany |publisher=CRC Press |year=2004 |isbn=978-0-8493-2332-4 |pages=590–591}}</ref>

It is a large [[shrub]] or small [[tree]] growing to 10-13 m tall. The [[leaf|leaves]] are [[evergreen]], 6-15 cm long and 2-4 cm broad, glossy dark green, entire or with a few small spines near the apex of the leaf. The [[flower]]s are white, with a four-lobed corolla. The [[fruit]] is a red [[drupe]], 5-6 mm in diameter, containing four [[seed]]s.<ref name=flh>Florida Department of Environmental Protection: [http://www.dep.state.fl.us/water/wetlands/delineation/featuredplants/ilex.htm Florida's Hollies]</ref><ref name=rhs>Huxley, A., ed. (1992). ''New RHS Dictionary of Gardening''. Macmillan ISBN 0-333-47494-5.</ref><ref>[http://www.cnr.vt.edu/dendro/dendrology/syllabus/factsheet.cfm?ID=462 Ilex cassine Fact Sheet<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>

As with other hollies, it is [[plant sexuality|dioecious]] with separate male and female plants. Only the females have berries, and a male [[pollenizer]] must be within range for [[bee]]s to [[pollination|pollinate]] them.

There are three [[variety (botany)|varieties]]:<ref name=grin/>
*''Ilex cassine'' var. ''cassine'' (United States, Caribbean)
*''Ilex cassine'' var. ''angustifolia'' <small>Aiton.</small> (United States)
*''Ilex cassine'' var. ''mexicana'' <small>(Turcz.) Loes.</small> (Mexico)

==Cultivation==
Ilex cassine is grown in warmer climates as an [[ornamental plant]] for the attractive bright red berries set against the glossy green leaves. It is known to grow to 30 feet tall. Its original range was close to the coast, but the range has been extended by planting.

==References==
{{reflist}}

==External links==
{{commonscat-inline|Ilex cassine|''Ilex cassine''}}

38.text:
{{taxobox |image = Ilex decidua (USDA).jpg |regnum = [[Plant]]ae |unranked_divisio = [[Flowering plant|Angiosperms]] |unranked_classis = [[Eudicots]] |unranked_ordo = [[Asterids]] |ordo = [[Aquifoliales]] |familia = [[Holly|Aquifoliaceae]] |genus = ''[[Holly|Ilex]]'' |species = '''''I. decidua''''' |binomial = ''Ilex decidua'' |binomial_authority = [[Thomas Walter (botanist)|Walter]] |synonyms = ''Ilex curtissii'' (Fern.) Small
''Ilex decidua'' Walter [[var.]] ''curtissii'' Fern. | range_map=Ilex decidua map.png |}} '''''Ilex decidua''''' ('''meadow holly''', also called '''"possumhaw"''', '''"deciduous holly"''' or '''"swamp holly"''') is a species of [[holly]] native to the [[United States]]. ==Description== [[File:Ilex decidua 1.JPG|thumb|left|Leaves of ''Ilex decidua'']] Distinguishing features of this species are [[crenate]] [[leaf]] margins and [[fruit]]ing [[Pedicel (botany)|pedicels]] that are 2–8 mm long.{{cite book|last=Duncan|first=Wilbur H. and Marion B. Duncan|title=Trees of the Southeastern United States|publisher=The [[University of Georgia Press]]|location=[[Athens, Georgia]]|year=1988|pages=304–305|isbn=0-8203-1469-2}} Its "distinctive leaf shape... is less variable than other species of holly".{{cite book|last=Brown|first=Claud L.|author2=L. Katherine Kirkman|title=Trees of Georgia and Adjacent States|publisher=[[Timber Press]]|location=[[Portland, Oregon|Portland]], [[Oregon]]|year=1990|pages=178–179|isbn=0-88192-148-3}} Leaves are [[obovate]],{{cite web|url=http://www.wildflower.org/plants/result.php?id_plant=ILDE|title=NPIN: ''Ilex decidua'' (Possumhaw)|accessdate=2009-07-14}} simple, alternating, [[deciduous]], and grow to 2.5-7.5 cm long. [[Drupe]] fruits are red (or rarely yellow), shiny, and [[globose]] (spherical, or nearly so), with a diameter of 4–8 mm. The pulp is bitter; they contain 3-5 seeds and mature in autumn. Slender [[twig]]s are [[Glabrousness|glabrous]] and silvery gray, with numerous [[spur shoots]], pointed lateral buds, and [[acuminate]] scales. [[Bark]] is "light brown to gray" in color and may be smooth or "warty and roughened". ==Distribution and ecology== [[File:Ilex decidua drawing.jpg|thumb|left|Drawing of ''Ilex decidua'']] ''Ilex decidua'' is a common plant, growing in the US in [[Alabama]], [[Arkansas]], [[Washington, D.C.]], [[Florida]], [[Georgia (U.S. state)|Georgia]], [[Illinois]], [[Indiana]], [[Kansas]], [[Kentucky]], [[Louisiana]], [[Maryland]], [[Missouri]], [[Mississippi]], [[North Carolina]], [[Oklahoma]], [[South Carolina]], [[Tennessee]], [[Texas]], and [[Virginia]].{{cite web|url=http://plants.usda.gov/java/profile?symbol=ILDE|title=PLANTS Profile for ''Ilex decidua'' (possumhaw)|work=[[Natural Resources Conservation Service]]|publisher=[[United States Department of Agriculture]]|accessdate=2009-07-14}} It grows in the northern [[Mexico]] states of [[Chihuahua (state)|Chihuahua]] and [[Coahuila]].{{cite web|url=http://www.ars-grin.gov/cgi-bin/npgs/html/taxon.pl?19700|title=''Ilex decidua'' information from NPGS/GRIN|work=Germplasm Resources Information Network - (GRIN) [Online Database]|publisher=USDA, ARS, [[National Genetic Resources Program]], [[National Germplasm Resources Laboratory]], [[Beltsville, Maryland]]|accessdate=2009-07-14}} It prefers land in [[floodplain]]s and the margins of swamps or lakes, and grows at elevations up to about 360 m. Other plant species with which possumhaw is associated include water tupelo (''[[Nyssa aquatica]]''), overcup oak (''[[Quercus lyrata]]''), bald cypress (''[[Taxodium distichum]]''), sycamore (''[[Platanus occidentalis]]'') and hackberry (''[[Celtis]]'' spp.).{{cite web |url=http://www.dep.state.fl.us/water/wetlands/delineation/featuredplants/ilex.htm |title=FDEP Featured Plant: Florida Hollies |publisher=Florida Department of Environmental Protection |accessdate=2009-07-14}} The fruits attract [[songbird]]s. [[Deer]] browse on young twigs. ==Human use== [[File:Ilex decidua berries.jpg|thumb|right|''Ilex decidua'' with red "berries"]] Because of the attractive [[Berry (botany)#Fruits not botanical berries|"berries"]], the tree is used as a winter [[ornamental plant]], and [[branch]]es are collected for use as [[Christmas decoration]]s. The wood is not useful commercially because of the tree's small size. ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== {{commonscat-inline|Ilex decidua|''Ilex decidua''}} {{wikispecies-inline|Ilex decidua|''Ilex decidua''}} *[http://www.cnr.vt.edu/dendro/dendrology/syllabus/factsheet.cfm?ID=163 Dendrology at Virginia Tech:''Ilex decidua''] *[http://www.ces.ncsu.edu/depts/hort/consumer/factsheets/trees-new/ilex_decidua.html NC State University: ''Ilex decidua''] {{DEFAULTSORT:Ilex decidua}} [[Category:Ilex|decidua]] [[Category:Ornamental trees]] [[Category:Trees of the Southeastern United States]] [[Category:Trees of Chihuahua (state)]] [[Category:Trees of Coahuila]] [[Category:Trees of the North-Central United States]] [[Category:Trees of the Southern United States]] [[Category:Trees of the South-Central United States]] [[Category:Trees of the Northeastern United States]] [[Category:Trees of the Great Lakes region (North America)]]

39.text:
{{Italic title}}
{{taxobox
|name = ''Ilex vomitoria''
|image = Ilex vomitoria.jpg
|image_caption = Foliage and fruit
|regnum = [[Plantae]]
|unranked_divisio = [[Angiosperms]]
|unranked_classis = [[Eudicots]]
|unranked_ordo = [[Asterids]]
|ordo = [[Aquifoliales]]
|familia = [[Aquifoliaceae]]
|genus = ''[[Holly|Ilex]]''
|species = '''''I. vomitoria'''''
|binomial = ''Ilex vomitoria''
|binomial_authority = [[Daniel Solander|Sol.]] ex [[William Aiton|Aiton]]
|range_map =  Ilex vomitoria range map.jpg
|range_map_caption = Natural range
}}

'''''Ilex vomitoria''''', commonly known as '''yaupon''' or '''yaupon holly''', is a species of [[holly]] that is native to southeastern [[North America]].<ref name=grin>{{cite web |url=http://www.ars-grin.gov/cgi-bin/npgs/html/taxon.pl?19791 |title=Taxon: ''Ilex vomitoria'' Sol. ex Aiton |work=Germplasm Resources Information Network |publisher=United States Department of Agriculture |date=2011-05-09 |accessdate=2011-09-19}}</ref> The word ''yaupon'' was derived from its [[Catawban languages|Catawban]] name, ''yopún'', which is a diminutive form of the word ''yop'', meaning "tree".{{cn|date=March 2017}} Another common name, '''cassina''', was borrowed from the [[Timucua language]]<ref>{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=83CIggbRi8YC |first=Charles L. |last=Cutler |title=O Brave New Words!: Native American Loanwords in Current English |publisher=University of Oklahoma Press |year=2000 |isbn=978-0-8061-3246-4 |pages=10, 163, 215}}</ref> (despite this, it usually refers to ''[[Ilex cassine]]'').

==Description==
Yaupon holly is an [[evergreen]] [[shrub]] or small [[tree]] reaching 5–9 meters tall, with smooth, light gray bark and slender, hairy shoots. The [[leaf|leaves]] are alternate, ovate to elliptical with a rounded apex and crenate or coarsely serrated margin, 1–4.5 cm long and 1–2 cm broad, glossy dark green above, slightly paler below. The [[flower]]s are 5–5.5 mm diameter, with a white four-lobed corolla. The [[fruit]] is a small round, shiny, and red (occasionally yellow) [[drupe]] 4–6 mm diameter containing four pits, which are dispersed by [[bird]]s eating the fruit. The species may be distinguished from the similar ''Ilex cassine'' by its smaller leaves with a rounded, not acute apex.<ref name=usda>{{cite web |title=Yaupon ''Ilex vomitoria'' |work=USDA Plant Guide |format=PDF |url=http://plants.usda.gov/factsheet/pdf/fs_ilvo.pdf}}</ref><ref name=fdep>{{cite web |title=Florida's Hollies |publisher=Florida Department of Environmental Protection |url=http://www.dep.state.fl.us/water/wetlands/delineation/featuredplants/ilex.htm}}</ref><ref name=usmil>{{cite book |last1=Martin |first1=C.O. |last2=Mott |first2=S.P. |chapter=Section 7.5.10 Yaupon (''Ilex vomitoria'') |title=U.S. Army Corps of Engineers Wildlife Resources Management Manual |publisher=U.S. Army Engineer Waterways Experiment Station |location=Vicksburg, MS |year=1997 |id=Technical Report EL-97-16 |url=http://el.erdc.usace.army.mil/elpubs/pdf/trel97-16.pdf |format=PDF}}</ref><ref name=obs/><ref name=bioimages>Bioimages: [http://www.cas.vanderbilt.edu/bioimages/species/ilvo.htm ''Ilex vomitoria'']</ref>

==Habitat and range==
''I. vomitoria'' occurs in the [[United States]] from [[Maryland]] south to [[Florida]] and west to [[Oklahoma]] <ref name=obs>{{cite web |title=''Ilex vomitoria'' |publisher=Oklahoma Biological Survey |url=http://www.biosurvey.ou.edu/shrub/ilvo.htm}}</ref> and [[Texas]]. A [[Disjunct distribution|disjunct population]] occurs in the [[Mexico|Mexican]] state of [[Chiapas]].<ref name=grin/> It generally occurs in coastal areas in well-drained sandy soils, and can be found on the upper edges of brackish and [[salt marsh]]es, sandy [[Hammock (ecology)|hammocks]], coastal [[sand dune]]s, inner-dune depressions, [[sandhill]]s, maritime forests, nontidal forested wetlands, well-drained forests and pine [[flatwood]]s.<ref name=usda/>

==Ecology==
[[Image:Eastern Bluebird-27527.jpg|thumb|left|200px|<center>An [[eastern bluebird]] eating the bright red berries from an ''Ilex vomitoria''.</center>]]
The fruit are an important food for many birds, including [[Florida duck]], [[American black duck]], [[mourning dove]], [[ruffed grouse]], [[bobwhite quail]], [[wild turkey]], [[northern flicker]], [[sapsucker]]s, [[cedar waxwing]], [[eastern bluebird]], [[American robin]], [[gray catbird]], [[northern mockingbird]], and [[white-throated sparrow]]. Mammals that eat the fruit include [[nine-banded armadillo]], [[American black bear]], [[gray fox]], [[raccoon]] and [[skunk]]s. The foliage and twigs are browsed by [[white-tailed deer]].<ref name=usda/>

==Cultivation and uses==
[[Indigenous peoples of the Americas|Native Americans]] used the leaves and stems to brew a [[tea]], commonly thought to be called ''asi'' or [[black drink]] for male-only purification and unity rituals. The ceremony included [[vomiting]], and Europeans incorrectly believed that it was ''Ilex vomitoria'' that caused it (hence the [[Botanical name|Latin name]]). The active ingredients, like those of the related [[yerba mate]] and [[guayusa]] plants, are actually [[caffeine]] and [[theobromine]],<ref>{{cite news |author=Wilford, JN |title=Ancient Energy Boost, Brewed From Toasted Leaves and Bark |newspaper=New York Times  |date=8 August 2012 |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/08/07/science/ancient-caffeinated-8216black-drink8217-was-made-with-holly-analysis-finds.html?_r=0}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Crown PL, Emerson TE, Gu J, Hurst WJ, Pauketat TR, Ward T |title=Ritual Black Drink consumption at Cahokia |journal=Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U.S.A. |volume=109 |issue=35 |pages=13944–9 |date=August 2012 |pmid=22869743 |pmc=3435207 |doi=10.1073/pnas.1208404109 |url=http://www.pnas.org/cgi/pmidlookup?view=long&pmid=22869743}}</ref> and the vomiting either was  learned or resulted from the great quantities in which they drank the beverage coupled with fasting.<ref name=usda/><ref name=hudson>Hudson, C. M. (1976). ''The Southeastern Indians''. University of Tennessee Press ISBN 0-87049-248-9.</ref>  Others believe the Europeans improperly assumed the [[black drink]] to be the tea made from ''Ilex vomitoria'' when it was likely an entirely different drink made from various roots and herbs and did have emetic properties.<ref name=gibbons>{{cite book |author=Gibbons, E. |title=Stalking the Blue-eyed Scallop |publisher=David McKay |year=1964 |isbn=0-911469-05-2 }}</ref>

===Ornamental===
''Ilex vomitoria'' is a common landscape plant in the Southeastern United States.  The most common cultivars are slow-growing shrubs popular for their dense, evergreen foliage and their adaptability to pruning into [[hedge]]s of various shapes. These include:
*'Folsom Weeping' – weeping cultivar
*'Grey's Littleleaf'/'Grey's Weeping' – weeping cultivar
*'Nana'/'Compacta' – dwarf female clone usually remaining below 1 m in height.
*'Pride of Houston' – female clone similar to type but featuring improvements in form, fruiting, and foliage.
*'Schilling's Dwarf'/'Stokes Dwarf' – dwarf male clone that grows no more than 0.6 m tall and 1.2 m wide.<ref>{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Q1_fAywb_bkC& |first=Harrison Leigh |last=Flint |title=Landscape Plants for Eastern North America |edition=2 |publisher=John Wiley and Sons |year=1997 |isbn=978-0-471-59919-7 |pages=282–283}}</ref>
*'Will Flemming' – male clone featuring a columnar growth habit.

==See also==
* ''[[Yerba maté|Ilex paraguariensis]]'' or {{lang|es|''yerba mate''}} – a caffeinated holly native to subtropical South America.
* ''[[Ilex guayusa]]'' or guayusa – a caffeinated holly native to the Ecuadorian Amazon Rainforest.
* [[Kuding]] – a Chinese tisane made from ''I. kudingcha''
