'''''Quercus emoryi''''', the '''Emory oak''', is a species of [[oak]] common in [[Arizona]] (including inside [[Saguaro National Park]]), [[New Mexico]] and western [[Texas]] (including inside [[Big Bend National Park]]), United States, and northern Mexico ([[Sonora]], [[Chihuahua (state)|Chihuahua]], [[Coahuila]] (including [[Maderas del Carmen|Parque Nacional Maderas del Carmen]]), [[Durango (state)|Durango]], [[Nuevo León]], and [[San Luis Potosí]]).<ref>[http://swbiodiversity.org/seinet/taxa/index.php?taxon=3234&taxauthid=1 SEINet, Southwestern Biodiversity, Arizona chapter]</ref><ref>[http://bonap.net/MapGallery/County/Quercus%20emoryi.png Biota of North America Program 2014 county distribution map]</ref> It typically grows in dry [[hill]]s at moderate altitudes.

''Quercus emoryi'' is an evergreen tree in the [[List of Quercus species#Section Lobata|red oak]] group, retaining its leaves through the winter until the new leaves are produced in spring, and is a large [[shrub]] or small [[tree]] from {{convert|5|–|17|m|ft|sp=us}} tall. The [[leaf|leaves]] are {{convert|3|–|6|cm|in|round=0.5|abbr=on}} long, entire or wavy-toothed, leathery, dark green above, paler below. The [[acorn]]s are {{convert|1.5|–|2|cm|in|abbr=on}} long, blackish-brown, and mature in 6–8 months from pollination; the kernel is sweet, and is an important food for many [[mammal]]s and [[bird]]s.<ref>[http://www.efloras.org/florataxon.aspx?flora_id=1&taxon_id=233501028 Flora of North America: ''Quercus emoryi'']</ref>

The tree is named after the [[United States Army]] surveyor, Lieutenant [[William Hemsley Emory]], who surveyed the area of west Texas where it was discovered in 1846.

'''''Quercus grisea''''', commonly known as the '''gray oak''', '''shin oak''' or '''scrub oak''', is a North American species [[deciduous]] or [[evergreen]] shrub or medium-sized tree in the [[List of Quercus species#Section Quercus|white oak group]]. It is native to the mountains of the southwestern United States and northern Mexico.<ref name=FNA>[http://www.efloras.org/florataxon.aspx?flora_id=1&taxon_id=233501041 Flora of North America]</ref> It hybridizes with four other oak species where the ranges of each overlap, the [[Quercus arizonica|Arizona white oak]] ''(Q. arizonica)'', the [[Quercus gambelii|Gambel oak]] ''(Q. gambelii)'', the [[Quercus mohriana|Mohr shin oak]] ''(Q. mohriana)'' and the [[Quercus pungens|sandpaper oak]] ''(Q. pungens)''.<ref name=FE>[http://www.fs.fed.us/database/feis/plants/tree/quegri/all.html US Forest Service Fire Ecology]</ref>

==Distribution==
The gray oak grows in the mountains of the southwestern United States (western [[Texas]], [[New Mexico]], [[Arizona]], [[Colorado]], and the [[Oklahoma Panhandle]]) and northern [[Mexico]] ([[Sonora]], [[Sinaloa]], [[Chihuahua (state)|Chihuahua]], [[Durango]], [[Coahuila]], [[San Luis Potosí]], [[Zacatecas]], [[Hidalgo (state)|Hidalgo]]). Through generally scarce, it is common in the [[Trans-Pecos]] region of Texas.<ref name=FE/><ref>[http://bonap.net/MapGallery/County/Quercus%20grisea.png Biota of North America Program 2014 county distribution map]</ref><ref>[http://swbiodiversity.org/seinet/taxa/index.php?taxon=3238&taxauthid=1 SEINet, Southwestern Biodiversity, Arizona chapter]</ref>

==Description==
''Quercus grisea'' may grow as a multi-stemmed shrub in drier situations but where the rainfall is sufficient, it grows into a medium size tree of up to about twenty meters (67 feet) with an irregular crown of twisted branches. The trunk is up to 60 cm (2 feet) in diameter with light gray bark which is fissured and cracked into small plates. The twigs are stout and a light reddish-brown, covered with grayish down. The leaves are alternate, leathery, long ovate, entire or with a few coarse teeth. They are grayish-green above and felted beneath and may fall in times of winter drought. The male catkins are yellowish-green and the female flowers are in small spikes growing in the leaf axils and appear in spring at the same time as the new leaves. The acorn cups are scaly, covered with fine hairs, and half as long as the acorns which grow singly or in pairs and are light brown.<ref name=FE/><ref>[http://www.dendro.cnre.vt.edu/dendrology/syllabus2/factsheet.cfm?ID=625 Virginia Tech: Gray oak] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110509065322/http://www.dendro.cnre.vt.edu/dendrology/syllabus2/factsheet.cfm?ID=625 |date=May 9, 2011 }}</ref><ref name=FNA/>

==Habitat==
The gray oak occurs from 4,000 to 9,000 feet (1200-2700 meters) above sea level, growing in valleys and on ridges, on rocky slopes and on the banks of streams. It flourishes in semi-arid conditions characterized by mild winters, dry springs and hot summers. It can spread [[Asexual reproduction|asexually]] through the sprouting of root suckers and may form thickets. It grows in association with other [[Quercus|oaks]], species of [[juniper]], [[Pinus cembroides|Mexican pinyon]] ''(Pinus cembroides)'', [[Pinus edulis|pinyon pine]] ''(Pinus edulis)'', [[Fendlera rupicola|fendlerbush]] ''(Fendlera rupicola)'', [[Salvia ramosissima|bushy sage]] ''(Salvia ramosissima)'', [[Arbutus xalapensis|Texas madrone]] ''(Arbutus xalapensis )'', [[Mahonia fremontii|Fremont barberry]] ''(Mahonia fremontii)'', [[Artemisia ludoviciana|Louisiana sagewort]] ''(Artemisia ludoviciana)'' and [[Yucca elata|soaptree yucca]] ''(Yucca elata)''.<ref name=FE/><ref name=FNA/>

86.text:
{{italic title}}
{{taxobox
|name = Shinnery oak
|image = Quercushavardii.jpg
|status = G4
|status_system = TNC
|regnum = [[Plant]]ae
|unranked_divisio = [[Angiosperms]]
|unranked_classis = [[Eudicots]]

|genus = ''[[Oak|Quercus]]''

|species = '''''Q. havardii'''''<ref name=Flora>[http://www.efloras.org/florataxon.aspx?flora_id=1&taxon_id=233501042 Flora of North America. Quercus havardii. Havard oak.]</ref>
|binomial = ''Quercus havardii''
|binomial_authority = [[Per Axel Rydberg|Rydberg]]
|range_map = Quercus havardii range map 1.png
|range_map_caption = Natural range of ''Quercus havardii''
|}}

'''''Quercus havardii''''' (common names include '''shinnery oak''', '''shin oak''' and '''Havard oak''') is a deciduous, low-growing, thicket-forming shrub that occupies some 2 to 3 million hectares in the southern [[Great Plains]] of [[North America]].<ref name=Peterson>{{cite news|accessdate=2009-07-07|url=http://www.treesearch.fs.fed.us/pubs/6048|author1=Peterson, Roger S. |author2=Boyd, Chad S. |year=1998|title=Ecology and management of sand shinnery communities: a literature review. Gen. Tech. Rep. RMRS-GTR-16. |publisher=Fort Collins, CO: U.S. Department of Agriculture, Forest Service, Rocky Mountain Research Station}}</ref> Clones may reach hundreds to thousands of years old, although aboveground stems typically live only 11 to 15 years. Shinnery oak stems are usually 1–2 m tall and codominate the plant community with mid- and tall-grasses which are usually taller than the oaks.

The [[specific name (botany)|specific epithet]] honors U.S. Army surgeon and botanist [[Valery Havard]], who contributed much to the knowledge of southwestern plants. The word "shinnery" seems to be derived from ''chêne'' (French for oak), and not from the height of the plant.<ref name=OK>[http://www.biosurvey.ou.edu/shrub/quha3.htm Oklahoma Biological Survey. ''Quercus havardii Rydb.'']</ref>

==Description==
'''Form:''' A low shrub to 2 m or occasionally a small tree, ''Q. havardii''  forms large clonal thickets by extending [[rhizome]]s through the sandy soil where it is usually found.<ref name=Gucker>{{cite news|accessdate=2009-07-07|url=http://www.fs.fed.us/database/feis/plants/shrub/quehav/all.html |author=Gucker, Corey L. 2006. |title=Quercus havardii. In: Fire Effects Information System|publisher= U.S. Department of Agriculture, Forest Service, Rocky Mountain Research Station, Fire Sciences Laboratory}}</ref>  Rhizomes range from 3–15 cm in diameter and are concentrated in upper 60 cm of soil, although penetration depths of 9 m has been reported.  Lateral roots and woody rhizomes are widespread near the soil surface. Ninety percent or more of shinnery oak's biomass is under ground, and fortuitous root grafting is common. These underground stems commonly spread to form plants 3 to 15 m or more in diameter.  Single clones are reported to cover up to 81 ha and to achieve ages over 13,000 years.<ref name=Peterson/>

'''Flowers:'''  Shinnery oak is monoecious with both female and male flowers borne separately on the same plant.<ref name=Flora/>  Male [[catkins]] are densely flowered, 1.5-3.8 cm long, and hang downward. Female catkins are 3–7 mm long, contain 1 to 5 flowers, and are usually axillary on young shoots.  Shinnery oaks are wind pollinated, and flowering occurs in the spring.

'''Acorns:''' Acorns develop in 1 year, maturing in the autumn.  Acorns occur alone or in clusters of 2 or 3, and are 12–25 mm long by 14–18 mm wide. A scaly cup covers about 1/3 to 1/2 of the nut.  On average, acorn crops are produced in 3 out of 10 years.<ref name=Gucker/>

'''Foliage:'''  The leathery, highly variable leaves are grey green to olive green, have a lustrous upper surface, and are whitish and densely hairy below.   Leaves are [[Leaf#Arrangement on the stem|alternate]], [[Leaf#Divisions of the lamina (blade)|simple]], with variable [[Leaf shape|shape]] (oblong, ovate, or elliptical), and with wavy or shallowly lobed margins.  Length is 2 to 8 cm and width 2 to 4 cm.<ref name=OK/>

'''Twigs:'''  Twigs are brown or grayish, 1-2.5 mm diameter, glabrous or densely covered with short grayish or yellowish hairs, that are lost with age. Buds are dark red-brown, somewhat spherical, about 2 mm long, and sparsely pubescent.

'''Bark:'''  Bark on the larger stems is light gray and scaly.

==Taxonomy==
Shinnery oak populations in Utah and Arizona are considered a variety of shinnery oak ([[Quercus havardii var. tuckeri|''Quercus havardii'' var. ''tuckeri'']]) by some taxonomists.  However, [[introgression]] of shinnery oak with Gambel oak (''[[Quercus gambelii]]'') and perhaps shrub live oak (''[[Quercus turbinella]]'') make taxonomic identification of these populations difficult.<ref name=Gucker/>

Shinnery oak hybridizes with Mohr oak (''[[Quercus mohriana]]'') and post oak (''[[Quercus stellata]]''). Post oak × shinnery oak hybrids are likely to be a result of post oak's historic range, which extended more westerly than it does today. Mohr oak × shinnery oak hybrids are restricted to habitats intermediate to those occupied by the two species. Mohr oak inhabits limestone soils, and shinnery oak occurs on deep sand soils.

==Native range==
Shinnery oak is native to western [[Oklahoma]], west [[Texas]], eastern [[New Mexico]], and 2 isolated populations in southwest [[Kansas]].<ref name=KANU>[http://www.nhm.ku.edu/herbarium/ R.L. McGregor Herbarium. ''Quercus havardii Rydb.'' herbarium records]</ref> A variety also occurs in northeastern [[Arizona]] and southeastern [[Utah]].<ref>[http://www.efloras.org/object_page.aspx?object_id=6796&flora_id=1 Flora of North America. Quercus havardii: Range Map.]</ref> Sandy plains, sand dunes, and sand hills of the southern Great Plains are typical habitat.

==Management==
A majority of shinnery oak occurs on private land used for agriculture and/or livestock production. It is considered undesirable on grazing lands, because it competes with better livestock forage and its buds and leaves are toxic to cattle for several weeks in spring. In addition, where cotton is grown near shinnery oak, [[Boll Weevil|boll weevils]] overwinter in the oak litter and infest nearby cotton fields in spring.  Thus, most research and other human effort concerning shinnery oak have been devoted to its eradication.

The use of chemical and mechanical control methods has been extensive, making it likely that shinnery oak's distribution is decreasing.  Most authorities do not recommend complete eradication of shinnery oak, indicating that forage production is typically greater if some shinnery oak remains in the community.  Stocking rates and rotational grazing patterns exist that reduce the incidence of shinnery oak poisoning of cattle.  Excessive control of shinnery oak is controversial because it can open sandy soils to wind erosion and can conflict with wildlife-habitat quality.<ref name=Peterson/>

Shinnery oak sprouts prolifically from rhizomes soon after fire.  Researchers described the communities as "extremely fire hardy".<ref name=Gucker/>

[[File:Quercus havardii resprouting.jpg|thumb|Quercus havardii resprouting]]

==Uses==
Because shinnery oak thrives in a harsh environment, it functions as a sand dune stabilizer, protecting sandy soils from wind erosion.   It also provides diverse wildlife species cover and food. [[Collared peccaries]], [[lesser prairie-chicken]]s, [[northern bobwhite]]s, and many other wildlife species eat shinnery oak acorns.  [[White-tailed deer|Deer]], [[pronghorn]], and [[packrat|southern plains woodrat]]s browse shinnery oak.  Shinnery oak habitats are used by [[black-tailed jackrabbit]]s, [[desert cottontail]]s, [[eastern cottontail]]s, [[wild turkey]]s, [[western box turtle]]s, a diversity of arthropods, approximately 25 [[snake]] species, and approximately 10 [[lizard]] species, including the endangered sand dune lizard (''[[Sceloporus arenicolus]]'').<ref name=Peterson/>

Many game species also rely on shinnery oak.  [[Scaled quail]] and northern bobwhites use shinnery oak habitats extensively, and shinnery oak habitats are considered "the principal home for white-tailed deer in the southern Great Plains".<ref name=Peterson/>

Shinnery oak provides rich habitat for wildlife compared with the surrounding [[Shortgrass prairie|shortgrass plains]].  Maintaining wildlife habitat and improving vegetation for livestock grazing are often in conflict, and should be carefully considered before undertaking control of shinnery oak.

'''''Quercus hypoleucoides''''', the '''silverleaf oak''' or the '''whiteleaf oak''' is a North American species of trees or shrubs in the [[Fagaceae|beech family]]. It grows in the southwestern United States and northern Mexico.<ref>[http://bonap.net/MapGallery/County/Quercus%20hypoleucoides.png Biota of North America Program 2014 county distribution map]</ref><ref name=z>[http://swbiodiversity.org/seinet/taxa/index.php?taxon=3241&taxauthid=1 SEINet, Southwestern Biodiversity, Arizona chapter]</ref>

''Quercus hypoleucoides'', though usually seen as a shrub, can be found to be a full-sized tree, 30 feet (9 meters) tall in areas where it receives lots of water. ''Quercus hypoleucoides'' can be distinguished from other oaks by its lanceolate leaves which are dark green on top but silver white on the lower surface.<ref name="CarterJack">{{cite book|last=Carter|first=Jack L.|title=Common Southwestern Native Plants: An Identification Guide|year=2003|publisher=Mimbres|location=Silver City, NM|page=144|author2=Martha A. Carter |author3=Donna J. Stevens |chapter=Shrubs}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Vascular Plants of the Gila Wilderness|url=http://www.wnmu.edu/academic/nspages/gilaflora/quercus_hypoleucoides.html|publisher=Western New Mexico University|accessdate=10 April 2012}}</ref>

== Description ==

''Quercus hypoleucoides'' produces its flowers in the spring as most plants do.<ref name="efloras">{{cite web|title=Silverleaf Oak|url=http://www.efloras.org/florataxon.aspx?flora_id=1|work=Flora of North America|publisher=EFloras}}</ref> It grows in warm regions and is used as an ornamental due to its unusual foliage.<ref>{{cite web|title=Quercus Hypoleucoides A. Camus|url=http://www.wildflower.org/plants/result.php?id_plant=QUHY|work=[[Lady Bird Johnson Wildflower Center]]|publisher=[[The University of Texas at Austin]]|accessdate=10 April 2012}}</ref> Its species name, hypoleucoides, means "white underneath" and also happens to be the main way that it is distinguished from other oak trees. This species has acorns which are eaten by both squirrels and birds and even at times by humans. However before it is safe for people to eat, the tannic acid must first be leached out due to its toxic qualities.<ref name="CarterJack" />

* Bark: Is dark gray in color. It is thin with shallow, lighter-colored fissures and narrow ridges.<ref name="efloras"/>
* Twig: Reddish brown in color and are broadly triangular with a sharp point. Are slender to moderate, generally with white fuzz. The end buds are clustered.<ref name="efloras"/>
* Leaves: Are alternate, evergreen, simple, and narrowly oblong to lanceolate. They are usually 2 to 4 inches (5–10 cm) long, with edges revolute. Occasionally there are a few shallow teeth, a narrow pointed tip, and a leathery texture. They are usually a shiny yellow-green on top and white or silvery on the bottom.<ref name="efloras"/>
* Fruits: Oblong acorn that is 1/2 to 3/4 inch long. The cap is scaly bowl-shaped and covers 1/3 of the nut which ripens in 1 (or 2 seasons), maturing in early fall.<ref name="efloras"/>
* Flowers: ''Quercus hypoleucoides'' is a [[monoecious]] plant and therefore both male and female flowers grow on the same plant. This is opposed to dioecious plants where male flowers and female flowers grow on separate trees. The male flowers form long drooping catkins that are yellow-green in color. The female flowers have very small spikes in leaf axils that appear with the leaves.<ref name="efloras"/>
* Form: Though usually found as a shrub, given enough moisture it can become a medium sized tree that reaches up to 60 feet (18 meters) tall with a spreading round crown.<ref>{{cite web|title=Silverleaf Oak Fagaceae Quercus Hypoleucoides A. Camus|url=http://dendro.cnre.vt.edu/dendrology/syllabus2/factsheet.cfm?ID=626|work=VT Forest Biology and Dendrology|publisher=[[Virginia Tech]] Department of Forest Resources and Environmental Conservation}}</ref>

== Distribution ==
''Quercus hypoleucoides'' is commonly found in moist canyons and on ridges.<ref name="efloras" /> It also is found in coniferous forests and high elevated lands from 5,000 to 8,000 feet (1500–2400 meters) above sea level.<ref name="CarterJack" /> Mountains of southern Arizona and New Mexico such as the [[Santa Catalina Mountains]] and the [[Chiricahua Mountains]], for example, have a pin-oak woodland at an elevation of roughly 5700 to 7200 feet (1710–2160 meters). Here, ''Quercus hypoleucoides'' can be found as well as other species of oak trees such as the ''[[Quercus arizonica]]'', ''[[Quercus emoryi|Q. emoryi]]'', and ''[[Quercus rugosa|Q. rugosa]]''.<ref>{{cite book|last=Peet|first=Robert K.|title=North American Terrestrial Vegetation|year=2000|publisher=Cambridge University Press|location=Cambridge, U.K.|pages=75–121|edition=2|editor=Michael G. Barbour, W. D. Billings|chapter=Forests and Meadows of the Rocky Mountains}}</ref>

Specimens have also been collected south of the international frontier, in [[Sonora]], [[Chihuahua (state)|Chihuahua]], [[Coahuila]], and [[Sinaloa]].<ref name=z/>

== Fire ecology ==
''Quercus hypoleucoides'' is a vigorous post-fire resprouter and will form a multi-stem shrub in areas of repeated fire.
<ref>{{Cite journal
| last1 = Schwilk | first1 = D.W..
| last2 = Gaetani   | first2 = M.
| last3 = Poulos | first3 = H.M
| date = 2013
| title = Oak bark allometry and fire survival strategies in the Chihuahuan Desert Sky Islands, Texas, USA
| journal = PLoS One
| doi = 10.1371/journal.pone.0079285
| volume = 8
| issue = 11
| url = http://journals.plos.org/plosone/article?id=10.1371/journal.pone.0079285
}}</ref>

[[File:Quercus hypoleucoides resprouting following fire.jpg|thumb|Quercus hypoleucoides resprouting following fire]]

== Uses ==
''Quercus hypoleucoides'' is has been used for ornamental purposes. Its leaves have a unique contrast due to the very white, silver color of the bottom. Its acorns are a source of food for squirrels and birds. The taller trees also help to provide shade for animals below who need to get away from the strong rays of the sun.

'''''Quercus laceyi''''', the '''Lacey oak''', is a small to medium-size [[deciduous]] [[oak]] tree which is native to northeastern Mexico ([[Coahuila]] and [[Nuevo León]]) and to the [[Texas Hill Country]] in central [[Texas]] in the United States.<ref name=mmmnm/><ref name=mnmmmmm>Nixon, K. C. and C. H. Muller. 1992. The taxonomic resurrection of ''Quercus laceyi'' Small (Fagaceae). Sida 15: 57-69.</ref>

''Quercus laceyi'' seldom grows more than 35 feet (11 meters) tall, and has a stocky trunk. Its blue-green leaves are oblong and shallowly lobed to unlobed, but shade leaves can be deeply lobed; they most often turn yellow or brown in autumn.<ref name=mmmnm>[http://www.efloras.org/florataxon.aspx?flora_id=1&taxon_id=233501053 Flora of North America: ''Quercus laceyi'']</ref><ref>[http://www.biodiversitylibrary.org/page/728926#page/428/mode/1up Small, John Kunkel  1901.  Bulletin of the Torrey Botanical Club 28(6): 358]</ref>

;Taxonomy
''Quercus laceyi'' has been often confused with ''[[Quercus glaucoides]]'', which is an evergreen oak native to central and southern Mexico.<ref name=mnmmmmm/>

[[File:Quercus laceyi range map 1.png|thumb|300px|left|Distribution map of ''Quercus laceyi''— in Texas and northeastern Mexico]]

'''''Quercus marilandica''''' ('''blackjack oak''') is a small [[oak]], one of the [[list of Quercus species#Section Lobatae|red oak group]] ''Quercus'' sect. ''Lobatae''. It is native to the eastern and central United States, from [[Long Island]] to [[Florida]], west as far as [[Texas]], [[Oklahoma]], and [[Nebraska]]. There are reports of a few isolated populations in southern [[Michigan]], but these appear to represent introductions.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://esp.cr.usgs.gov/data/atlas/little/quermari.pdf | title = Quercus marilandica Range Map | accessdate = 2008-03-05 | publisher = [[United States Geological Survey]]}}</ref><ref>[http://bonap.net/MapGallery/County/Quercus%20marilandica.png Biota of North America Program 2014 county distribution map]</ref>

[[Image:Lewis County Blackjack Oak.JPG|left|thumb|Blackjack oak leaves]]
[[Image:Oak-Stump-9832.jpg|left|thumb|Blackjack oak stump, approx. 75 years old]]
''Quercus marilandica'' is a small [[deciduous]] [[tree]] growing to {{convert|15|m|ft|abbr=off|sp=us}} tall, with bark cracked into rectangular black plates with narrow orange fissures. The [[leaf|leaves]] are {{convert|7|-|20|cm|in|round=0.5|abbr=on}} long and broad, and typically flare from a tapered base to a broad three-lobed bell shape with only shallow indentations. They are dark green and glossy above, pubescent underneath, and often remain attached to the twigs through the winter after turning colors from red to brown in the fall. The [[acorn]] is small, {{convert|12|-|20|mm|in|abbr=on}} long and {{convert|10|-|18|mm|in|abbr=on}} broad; like other red oaks, it takes 18 months to mature.<ref>[http://www.efloras.org/florataxon.aspx?flora_id=1&taxon_id=233501060 Flora of North America, ''Quercus marilandica'' Münchhausen, 1770. Blackjack oak ]</ref>

==Habitat and distribution==

The blackjack oak grows in poor, thin, dry, rocky or sandy soils where few other woody plants can thrive, usually on low ground, from sea level up to approximately {{convert|2800|ft|m|abbr=off|sp=us}} in altitude. Some say that it does not have the beautiful form of many oaks, but is nonetheless a valuable tree for growing in problem sites.<ref>[http://www.ingentaconnect.com/content/saf/jof/1942/00000040/00000003/art00011?crawler=true]</ref> Some say that the tree is "tough but ugly," but also underappreciated.<ref>[http://www.uaex.edu/yard-garden/resource-library/plant-week/blackjack-oak.aspx]</ref><ref>[http://www.tallahassee.com/story/life/home-garden/2017/01/12/blackjack-oak-grows-hardscrabble-habitat/96497394/]</ref> At times the tree has even been actively eradicated to provide more room for trees deemed to be more commercially valuable.<ref>[https://archive.org/stream/sproutingofblack137clar/sproutingofblack137clar_djvu.txt]</ref>

It is sometimes an understory tree in pine stands on sandy knolls in the southeastern USA. Along the coastal plain of [[New Jersey]] the probability of finding this species is increased in relatively sunny, open areas such as those near coastal salt marshes. It often occurs near [[Scarlet Oak|scarlet]] and [[post oak]]s as well as [[pitch pine]]; understory companions include [[winged sumac]], [[bracken]], [[sweetfern]], and [[bayberry]], and can be found as far north as parts of Ohio,<ref>[http://www.oplin.org/tree/fact%20pages/oak_blackjack/oak_blackjack.html]</ref> New York,

A variety, ''Quercus marilandica'' Münchhausen var. ''ashei'' [[George Bishop Sudworth|Sudworth]] (D. M. Hunt 1989), grows in the western portions of its range—northern [[Texas]], [[Oklahoma]], and into southern [[Kansas]]. In this area, blackjack, along with [[post oak]], forms a semi-savanna area composed of forested strips intermixed with prairie grass glades along the eastern edge of the southern [[Great Plains]]. This semi-savanna is known as the [[Cross Timbers]].<ref>[http://www.biosurvey.ou.edu/posters/CrossTimbersEcoregion.html]</ref><ref>[http://www.forestry.ok.gov/post-oak-blackjack-forest]</ref><ref>[http://texnat.tamu.edu/library/symposia/brush-sculptors-innovations-for-tailoring-brushy-rangelands-to-enhance-wildlife-habitat-and-recreational-value/oak-ecology/]</ref> Scrub forms of ''Q. marilandica'' dominate on many [[chert]] glades along with ''[[Quercus stellata|Q.stellata]]'' in Arkansas' Ozark plateau.<ref>C.Michael Hogan. 2012. [http://www.eoearth.org/article/Oak ''Oak''. Encyclopedia of Earth. Eds. A. Dawson and C.J. Cleveland. Encyclopedia of Earth. National Council for Science and the Environment. Washington DC] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130523173442/http://www.eoearth.org/article/Oak |date=May 23, 2013 }}</ref>

The Blackjack Oak sometimes hybridizes with the Bear Oak ([[Quercus ilicifolia]]), forming a hybrid known as [[Q. X brittonii]].<ref>[http://eol.org/pages/1151451/details]</ref>

Blackjacks in the Cross Timbers can grow from {{convert|50|to|60|ft|m}} high with a trunk diameter of {{convert|16|in|cm}}, but seldom reach more than {{convert|40|ft|m}}. The leaves are from {{convert|4|to|10|in|cm}} in length and about the same width. Blackjack acorns provide food for both whitetail deer and wild turkey. Blackjacks may, however, cause [[tannic acid]] poisoning in cattle.

==Uses==
The [[wood]] is very dense and produces a hot flame when burned, which functions as an excellent source of heat for [[barbecue]]s and wood-burning stoves. However, the wood is not desirable for wood [[fireplace]]s because the heat causes popping, thereby increasing the risk of house fires.<ref>Stephan L. Hatch and Jennifer Pluhar (eds.). Texas Range Plants. College Station: Texas A&M University Press, 1999. ISBN 0-89096-538-2</ref>

Traditionally blackjack wood is used as both a fuel and smoke wood for [[barbecue in Oklahoma]].

'''''Quercus mohriana''''', commonly known as the '''Mohr oak''', '''shin oak''' or '''scrub oak''', is a North American  [[evergreen]] shrub or small tree in the [[List of Quercus species#Section Quercus|white oak group]] and is native to the south-central United States and north-central Mexico.<ref name=FNA>[http://www.efloras.org/florataxon.aspx?flora_id=1&taxon_id=233501063 Flora of North America, ''Quercus mohriana'']</ref><ref name=m>[http://bonap.net/MapGallery/County/Quercus%20mohriana.png Biota of North America Program 2014 county distribution map]</ref>  The species [[Scientific names|epithet]] ''mohriana'' honors the pharmacist and botanist [[Charles Mohr]] of Alabama.<ref>[http://www.biosurvey.ou.edu/shrub/qumo.htm Oklahoma Biological Survey]</ref>

==Distribution==
The Mohr oak is abundant in western [[Texas]]. It also grows in [[Oklahoma]], [[New Mexico]] and [[Coahuila]].<ref name=FNA/><ref name=m/>

==Description==
The Mohr oak can be a  small tree up to six meters (20 feet) high or a large thicket-forming shrub. The bark is light brown, rough and deeply furrowed. The twigs are yellowish or whitish, with short velvety hairs, becoming smooth with age. The buds are dark red-brown, sparsely covered with hairs. The leaves are shiny, leathery, dark blue-gray and densely covered with light gray hairs underneath.<ref name=TNP/> They have entire margins and are occasionally toothed. The [[inflorescence]], which appears in spring, is reddish. There are female catkins with one to three flowers and male catkins with numerous flowers. The acorn cups are deep and the acorns grow singly or in pairs and are light brown, broadly ovoid with a rounded apex.<ref name=FNA/>

==Habitat==
The preferred habitat of this oak is on dry limestone or calcareous slopes at a height of between 600 and 2500 meters (2000-8300 feet) above sea level, in [[chaparral]] and desert scrub [[savanna]].<ref name=FNA/>  It thrives in regions that receive less than twenty five inches (63 cm) of annual rainfall.<ref name=TNP>[http://aggie-horticulture.tamu.edu/ornamentals/natives/quercusmohriana.htm Texas Native Plants]</ref> It grows in association with true mountain-mahogany ''[[Cercocarpus montanus]]'', desert ceanothus ''[[Ceanothus greggii]]'', the sandpaper oak ''[[Quercus pungens]]'', oneseed juniper ''[[Juniperus monosperma]]'', cane cholla ''[[Opuntia imbricata]]'', purplefruited pricklypear ''[[Opuntia phaeacantha]]'', Mexican buckeye ''[[Ungnadia speciosa]]'', Texas persimmon ''[[Diospyros texana]]'', hairy tridens ''[[Erioneuron pilosum]]'' and plateau oak ''[[Quercus fusiformis]]''.<ref>Texas Parks and Wildlife Department. 1992. Plant communities of Texas (Series level): February 1992. Austin, TX: Texas Parks and Wildlife Department, Texas Natural Heritage Program. 38 p.</ref>

'''''Quercus nigra''''', the '''water oak''', is an [[oak]] in the [[List of Quercus species#Section Lobatae|red oak]] group (''Quercus'' sect. ''Lobatae''), native to the eastern and south-central [[United States]], found in all the coastal states from [[New Jersey]] to [[Texas]], and inland as far as [[Oklahoma]], [[Kentucky]], and southern [[Missouri]].<ref>[http://bonap.net/MapGallery/County/Quercus%20nigra.png Biota of North America Program 2014 county distribution map]</ref> It occurs in lowlands and up to 450 m (1500 ft) altitude.

==Description==
''Quercus nigra'' is a medium-sized [[deciduous]] [[tree]], growing to 30 m (100 ft)  tall with a trunk up to 1 m (3 ft) in diameter. Young trees have a smooth, brown bark that becomes gray-black with rough scaly ridges as the tree matures. The [[leaf|leaves]] are alternate, simple and tardily deciduous, remaining on the tree until mid-winter; they are 3–12 cm (1–5 in) long and 2–6 cm (1/2–2 in) broad, variable in shape, most commonly shaped like a spatula being broad and rounded at the top and narrow and wedged at the base. The margins vary, usually being smooth to shallowly lobed, with a bristle at the apex and lobe tips. The tree is easy to identify by the leaves, which have a lobe that looks as if a drop of water is hanging from the end of the leaf. The top of each leaf is a dull green to bluish green and the bottom is a paler bluish-green. On the bottom portion of the leaves, rusty colored hairs run along the veins. The [[acorn]]s are arranged singly or in pairs, 10–14 mm (1/3-1/2 in) long and broad, with a shallow cupule; they mature about 18 months after pollination in [[autumn|fall]] of second year.<ref>[http://www.efloras.org/florataxon.aspx?flora_id=1&taxon_id=233501067 Flora of North America: ''Quercus nigra'']</ref>

==Ecology==
[[Image:Quercus nigra.jpg|thumb|left|Water oak leaf cluster]]
Water oak serves the same ecological role as [[Salix babylonica#Horticultural selections and related hybrids|weeping willow]] and other wetland trees. It is adapted to wet, [[swamp]]y areas, such as along [[pond]]s and stream banks, but can also tolerate well-drained sites and even heavy, compacted soils. It grows in sandy soils, red clays, and old fields to the borders of [[swamp]]s, [[stream]]s, to [[bottomland]]s. Due to its ability to grow and reproduce quickly, the water oak is often the most abundant species in a stand of trees. The tree is relatively short-lived compared to other oaks and may live only 60 to 80 years. It does not compete well and does not tolerate even light shade. Water oak is frequently used to restore bottomland [[hardwood forest]]s on land that was previously cleared for agriculture or pine plantations. Minimum age for flowering and fruiting is 20 years and the tree produces heavy crops of acorns nearly every year. Water oak is not recommended as an ornamental due to being short-lived, disease-prone, and extremely messy.

[[Hybrid (biology)|Hybrids]] of water oak are known with southern red oak (''[[Quercus falcata]]''), bluejack oak (''[[Quercus incana]]''), turkey oak (''[[Quercus laevis]]''), blackjack oak (''[[Quercus marilandica]]''), willow oak (''[[Quercus phellos]]''), Shumard oak (''[[Quercus shumardii]]''), and black oak (''[[Quercus velutina]]'')

Water oak acorns are an important food for [[white-tailed deer]], [[eastern gray squirrel]], [[raccoon]], [[wild turkey]], [[mallard]], [[wood duck]], and [[bobwhite quail]]. In winter, deer will browse the buds and young twigs.

==Uses and history==
Water oak has been used for timber and for [[firewood|fuel]] by people in the southern states since the 17th century. The wood is generally sold as "red oak", mixed with the wood from other red oaks.

Other names include spotted oak, duck oak, punk oak, orange oak or possum oak.

'''''Quercus pungens''''', commonly known as the '''sandpaper oak''' or '''scrub oak''', is a North American species  [[evergreen]] or sub-evergreen shrub or small tree in the [[List of Quercus species#Section Quercus|white oak group]]. There is one recognised variety, ''Quercus pungens var. vaseyana'', the '''Vasey shin oak'''.<ref name=USDA>[http://www.fs.fed.us/database/feis/plants/tree/quepun/all.html USDA Forest Service: Quercus pungens]</ref> Sandpaper oak hybridizes with gray oak, ''[[Quercus grisea]]'', in the Guadalupe Mountains of New Mexico and Texas.<ref>Gehlbach, Frederick R. 1967. Vegetation of the Guadalupe Escarpment, New Mexico-Texas. Ecology. 48(3): 404-419.</ref>

==Distribution==
Sandpaper and Vasey shin oaks are abundant in the [[Edwards Plateau]] and the [[Trans-Pecos]] region of [[Texas]]. They also occur in the [[Guadalupe Mountains]] and westward to the mountains of southeastern [[Arizona]] and southwestern [[New Mexico]], and in northern and eastern Mexico ([[Chihuahua (state)|Chihuahua]], [[Coahuila]], [[Durango]], [[Nuevo León]], and [[Veracruz]]).<ref name=USDA/><ref>[http://bonap.net/MapGallery/County/Quercus%20pungens.png Biota of North America Program 2014 county distribution map]</ref><ref>[http://swbiodiversity.org/seinet/taxa/index.php?taxon=3246&taxauthid=1 SEINet, Southwestern Biodiversity, Arizona chapter]</ref>

==Description==
The sandpaper oak can be a small tree of up to 40 feet (12 meters) high or a large shrub that forms thickets. The bark is light brown and papery. The twigs are gray, with short velvety hairs, becoming smooth with age. The buds are dark red-brown, sparsely covered with hairs. The leathery leaves are semi-evergreen, being bright glossy green at first but turning darker with age. It is their rough texture, caused by minute persistent hair bases, that gives the tree its name of sandpaper oak. The [[inflorescence]], which appears in spring, is reddish, the female catkins having one to three flowers and the male catkins numerous flowers. The acorn cups are shallow and covered with dense gray hairs. The acorns grow singly or in pairs and are light brown, broadly ovoid with a rounded apex.<ref name=USDA/><ref name=FNA>[http://www.efloras.org/florataxon.aspx?flora_id=1&taxon_id=233501077 Flora of North America]</ref>

==Habitat==
The preferred habitat of these oaks is on dry limestone or igneous slopes at a height of 800-2000 meters (2660-6670 feet) above sea level, in [[chaparral]] and desert scrub [[savanna]], usually in communities of [[oak]], [[juniper]] and [[pinyon pine]].<ref name=USDA/> In the chaparral formations in the Guadalupe Mountains, it is one of the dominant species and is found growing alongside true mountain-mahogany, ''[[Cercocarpus montanus]]'' and desert ceanothus, ''[[Ceanothus greggii]]''. Other plants associated with it include the Mohr shin oak, ''[[Quercus mohriana]]'', oneseed juniper, ''[[Juniperus monosperma]]'', cane cholla, ''[[Opuntia imbricata]]'', purplefruited pricklypear, ''[[Opuntia phaeacantha]]'', Mexican buckeye, ''[[Ungnadia speciosa]]'', Texas persimmon, ''[[Diospyros texana]]'', hairy tridens, ''[[Erioneuron pilosum]]'' and plateau oak, ''[[Quercus fusiformis]]''.<ref>Texas Parks and Wildlife Department. 1992. Plant communities of Texas (Series level): February 1992. Austin, TX: Texas Parks and Wildlife Department, Texas Natural Heritage Program. 38 p.</ref>

 | range_map_caption   = Natural range

 | synonyms            = *''Quercus dumosa'' subsp. ''turbinella'' <small>(Greene) A.E.Murray 	</small>
*''Quercus dumosa'' var. ''turbinella'' <small>(Greene) Jeps.</small>
*''Quercus subturbinella'' <small>Trel.</small>
}}

'''''Quercus turbinella''''' is a North American species of [[oak]] known by the common names '''Turbinella oak''', '''Arizona shrub live oak''', and '''Gray shrub oak'''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://calphotos.berkeley.edu/cgi/img_query?where-genre=Plant&where-taxon=Quercus+turbinella|title=Calphotos photo gallery University of California}}</ref> It is native to northwestern [[Mexico]] and the southwestern United States<ref name=chiquito>Little. ''Atlas of United States Trees, Volume 3, Minor Western Hardwoods'', Map 147, ''Quercus turbinella''.</ref>

==Distribution==
''Quercus turbinella'' has been found in [[Baja California]], [[Sonora]], [[Arizona]], [[New Mexico]], [[Colorado]], [[Utah]], [[Nevada]], southern [[California]], and western [[Texas]].<ref>[http://bonap.net/MapGallery/County/Quercus%20turbinella.png Biota of North America Propgram 2014 county distribution map]</ref><ref>[http://www.calflora.org/cgi-bin/species_query.cgi?where-calrecnum=7008 Calflora taxon report, University of California, ''Quercus turbinella''  E. Greene, Grey oak, Sonoran scrub oak, shrub live oak ]</ref> It has to date not been found in [[Chihuahua (state)|Chihuahua]], but some of the known populations in Sonora and New Mexico lie only a few kilometers from the Chihuahuan border, so it is to be looked for in that state.<ref>[http://swbiodiversity.org/seinet/taxa/index.php?taxon=3272&taxauthid=1 SEINet, Southwestern Biodiversity, Arizona chapter] photos, description, interactive distribution map</ref> It grows in woodland, [[chaparral]], forest, and other habitat. It is most common in chaparral habitat in central [[Arizona]],<ref name=fs>[http://www.fs.fed.us/database/feis/plants/tree/quetur/all.html US Forest Service Fire Ecology]</ref> through the [[Arizona transition zone|transition zone]] of the [[Mogollon Rim]]–[[White Mountains (Arizona)|White Mountains]], but also southeast Arizona in the [[Madrean Sky Islands|Madrean Sky Island]] mountain ranges of [[sky island]]s.<ref name=chiquito/>

==Description== 
''Quercus turbinella'' is a [[shrub]] growing {{convert|2|-|5|m|ft|sp=us}} in height but sometimes becoming treelike and exceeding {{convert|6|m|ft|abbr=off|sp=us}}. The branches are gray or brown, the twigs often coated in short woolly fibers when young and becoming scaly with age. The thick, leathery evergreen leaves are up to {{convert|3|cm|in|abbr=off|sp=us}} long by {{convert|2|cm|in|abbr=on}} wide  and are edged with large, spine-tipped teeth. They are gray-green to yellowish in color and waxy in texture on the upper surfaces, and yellowish and hairy or woolly and glandular on the lower surfaces. The males catkins are yellowish-green and the female flowers are in short spikes in the leaf axils, appearing at the same time as the new growth of leaves. The fruit is a yellowish brown [[acorn]] up to two centimeters long with a shallow warty cup about a centimeter wide.<ref>[http://www.dendro.cnre.vt.edu/dendrology/syllabus2/factsheet.cfm?ID=629 Virginia Tech: Shrub live oak] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110509061012/http://www.dendro.cnre.vt.edu/dendrology/syllabus2/factsheet.cfm?ID=629 |date=May 9, 2011 }}</ref> This oak reproduces [[sexual reproduction|sexually]] via its acorns if there is enough moisture present, but more often it reproduces [[vegetative reproduction|vegetatively]] by sprouting from its [[rhizome]] and root crown.<ref name=fs/><ref>[http://www.efloras.org/florataxon.aspx?flora_id=1&taxon_id=233501092 Flora of North America, ''Quercus turbinella'' Greene, 1889. Sonoran scrub oak ]</ref>

''Quercus turbinella'' easily [[Hybrid (biology)|hybridizes]] with other oak species, including ''[[Quercus gambelii]]'' and ''[[Quercus grisea|Q. grisea]]''.<ref name=fs/> Many species of animals use it for food, with wild and domesticated [[ungulate]]s browsing the foliage and many birds and mammals eating the acorns.<ref name=fs/> Animals also use the shrub as cover, and [[Cougar|mountain lions]] hide their kills in the thickets.<ref name=fs/>

'''''Salix bonplandiana''''' ('''Bonpland willow'''), (Span.: ''ahuejote'', ''sauce'', ''ahujote'', and ''huejote''),<ref>[http://www.jornada.unam.mx/2003/09/29/eco-f.html City trees, (www.jornada.unam.mx);]</ref> is a [[perennial]] species of [[willow]] [[tree]] native to southern and southwest [[Mexico]] and extending into central [[Guatemala]];<ref>Little, ''Atlas of United States Trees, Volume 3, Minor Western Hardwoods'', Map 166-SW, Map 166-N ''Salix bonplandiana''.</ref> in western Mexico it is a tree of the [[Sierra Madre Occidental]] cordillera, but also occurring in other small locales, for example [[Baja California Sur]], northern [[Sonora]], [[San Luis Potosi]], etc. A core [[disjunct distribution|disjunct]] area occurs in central and southeast [[Arizona]], in advantageous locales, especially associated with higher elevations and water.<ref>Little, Map 166-SW, Map 166-N ''Salix bonplandiana''.</ref>

==Distribution==
In Mexico, the Bonpland willow is associated with the Pacific Coast, and in southern Mexico, the range extends into internal mountain areas of Pacific, central-southwest [[Guatemala]]. Across southern Mexico, it is a species of the [[Trans-Mexican Volcanic Belt]],<ref>Little, Map 166-SW, Map 166-N ''Salix bonplandiana''.</ref>  and has its range extension on the Pacific, west from the west of the Volcanic Belt, and then north into the [[Sierra Madre Occidental]] cordillera. In the cordillera, the range ends in southwest [[Chihuahua (state)|Chihuahua]], but is disjunct in a large area of central [[Arizona]], the [[Mogollon Rim]]–[[White Mountains (Arizona)]] and extending into the [[Madrean Sky Islands]] southeastwards, including mountain-related isolated locales in the [[New Mexico Bootheel|bootheel of extreme southwest]] [[New Mexico]].<ref>Little, Map 166-SW, Map 166-N ''Salix bonplandiana''.</ref>

===Identical ranges of ''S. bonplandiana'', ''S. taxifolia''===
Both ''S. bonplandiana'', and ''[[Salix taxifolia|S. taxifolia]]'' have identical ranges; both species range from the Trans-Mexican Volcanic Belt southward, on an imaginary centerline into central [[Guatemala]]. Each is on the Pacific Coast, but leave the [[wildlife corridor|coastal strip]] before the range extension into central Guatemala. Both have their [[disjunct distribution|disjunct]] ranges in Arizona, both being in the [[Madrean Sky Islands]] region. Both also range into [[Baja California Sur]], but ''S. taxifolia'' only at the extreme south.<ref>Little, Maps 166-N & 183-N; Maps 166-SW & 183-SW, ''S. bonplandiana'', ''S. taxifolia''.</ref> (''S. bonplandiana'' also occurs in Arizona, in the Mogollon Rim–White Mountains regions.)

The other differences between the two are ''S. taxofolia'' occurs in minor locales of the [[Sierra Madre Oriental]] cordillera, and ''S. bonplandiana'' occurs in the Sierra Madre Occidental cordillera northwest to southwest [[Durango]]. ''S. taxifolia'' occurs west of the Occidental cordillera in the south Pacific Coast north to southern [[Sinaloa]]–southwest Durango. ''B. bonplandiana'' has a few locales on the [[Mexican Plateau]], (with both occurring in central [[Chihuahua (state)|Chihuahua]], west of [[Chihuahua, Chihuahua]]).<ref>Little, Maps 166-N & 183-N; Maps 166-SW & 183-SW, ''S. bonplandiana'', ''S. taxifolia''.</ref> Other minor locale differences occur in central [[New Mexico]], far west [[Texas]], [[Coahuila]], [[Nuevo Leon]], and [[Tamaulipas]].

'''''Salix laevigata''''' ('''red willow''' or '''polished willow'''), is a species of [[willow]] native to the [[southwestern United States]]  and northern [[Baja California]].<ref name=Little>Little. ''Atlas of United States Trees, Volume 3, Minor Western Hardwoods'',  Map 176, ''Salix laevigata''.</ref>

==Biology==
The red willow is a small tree up to {{convert|45|ft|m|abbr=on}} in height. Like most other willows, it commonly grows along riverbanks and in other areas with high soil moisture.<ref>[http://ucjeps.berkeley.edu/cgi-bin/get_IJM.pl?tid=42850 The Jepson Manual.]</ref>

==Distribution==
The red willow occurs along the coast of Baja California and in California north to [[Cape Mendocino]]. It occurs east of the [[San Joaquin Valley]] in the lower elevation western foothills of the [[Sierra Nevada (U.S.)|Sierra Nevada]]; it is absent from the Central Valley itself.<ref name=Little/> Small occurrences can be found in [[Oregon]], [[Nevada]], and [[New Mexico]]. In [[Arizona]] it is found in the central [[Arizona transition zone|transition zone]] of the [[Mogollon Rim]] and in the central [[Grand Canyon]]. Its distribution extends to the [[Virgin River]] canyon of southwestern [[Utah]].<ref name=Little/>
==Ethnobotany==
The [[Kutenai language|Kutenai]] called red willow ''mukwuʔk'', and used it in basketry.<ref>{{Cite web
| title = FirstVoices: Ktunaxa words
| accessdate = 2012-07-10
| url = http://www.firstvoices.com/en/Ktunaxa/word/66bc5bf3920cac39/Red+Osier+-+Red+Willow
}}</ref>

'''''Salix taxifolia''''' ('''yewleaf''' or '''yew-leaf willow''') is a species of [[willow]] native to all of southern [[Mexico]], also Pacific Coast regions, north to [[Sinaloa]], and in the south Pacific Coast of Mexico into central [[Guatemala]]. Scattered populations are also reported from northern Mexico and from the US states of Texas, New Mexico, and Arizona.<ref name=Little-183>Elbert L. Little (1976), ''Atlas of United States Trees, Volume 3, Minor Western Hardwoods'', US Government Printing Office. Library of Congress No. 79-653298, Map 183-SW, Map 183-N, ''Salix taxifolia''.</ref><ref>[http://www.efloras.org/florataxon.aspx?flora_id=1&taxon_id=242445883 Flora of North America, vol 7 p 54].</ref><ref>Laferrière, Joseph E. 1994. Vegetation and flora of the Mountain Pima village of Nabogame, Chihuahua, Mexico. Phytologia 77:102-140.</ref>

It is a large [[shrub]] or [[tree]] with narrow linear leaves similar to those of a [[yew]] ([[Taxus]] spp.), thus its common name. Its range is similar to that of the Bonpland willow, ''[[Salix bonplandiana|S. bonplandiana]]''.

==Distribution==
The primary range of yewleaf willow is southern [[Mexico]] south of the [[Trans-Mexican Volcanic Belt]] and the Pacific coast region, then into Pacific coast–central [[Guatemala]].<ref name=Little-183/>

Besides the core range area, (of the northern Sierra Madre Occidentals) in Arizona–New Mexico and northeast Sonora,<ref name=Little-183/> two larger [[disjunct distribution|disjunct]] regions occur in west [[Texas]] and central [[Chihuahua (state)|Chihuahua]].<ref name=Little-183/> South of [[Chihuahua, Chihuahua]] it is found at the [[Conchos River]], and west of the city, a large area at the lake region. It also occurs in scattered, isolated locales of [[Durango]], [[Sinaloa]], and in the northeast at [[Nuevo Leon]] and [[Tamaulipas]]: also extreme southern [[Baja California Sur]], (west of Sinaloa-Durango across the [[Gulf of California]]).<ref name=Little-183/> Besides parts of the Sierra Madre Occidental, locales occur in the southern [[Sierra Madre Oriental]] cordillera, but also small isolated locales as far northeast as the northeast states.

Its range is similar to that of the Bonpland willow, ''[[Salix bonplandiana]]'', except ''S. bonplandiana'' covers almost the entire north-south extent of the Sierra Madre Occidentals; yewleaf is more intermittent in that range.

===Similar ranges of ''S. taxifolia'', ''S. bonplandiana''===
Both ''S. taxifolia'', and ''[[Salix bonplandiana|S. bonpandiana]]'' have identical ranges: both species range from the [[Trans-Mexican Volcanic Belt]] southward, on an imaginary centerline into central [[Guatemala]]. Each is on the Pacific Coast, but leave the [[wildlife corridor|coastal strip]] before the range into central Guatemala. Both have their [[disjunct distribution|disjunct]] ranges in Arizona, both being in the [[Madrean Sky Islands]] region. Both also range into [[Baja California Sur]], but ''S. taxifolia'' only at the extreme south.<ref Name=Little-166>Little (1976), Maps 166-N & 183-N; Maps 166-SW & 183-SW, ''S. bonplandiana'', ''S. taxifolia''.</ref> (''S. bonplandiana'' also occurs in Arizona, in the Mogollon Rim–White Mountains regions.)

The other differences between the two: ''S. taxofolia'' occurs in minor locales of the [[Sierra Madre Oriental]] cordillera, and ''S. bonplandiana'' occurs in the Sierra Madre Occidental cordillera northwest to southwest [[Durango]]. ''S. taxifolia'' occurs ''west'' of the Occidental cordillera in the south Pacific Coast north to southern [[Sinaloa]]–southwest Durango. ''B. bonplandiana'' has a few locales on the [[Mexican Plateau]], (with both occurring in central [[Chihuahua (state)|Chihuahua]], west of [[Chihuahua, Chihuahua]]).<ref name=Little-166/> Other minor locale differences occur in central [[New Mexico]], far west [[Texas]], [[Coahuila]], [[Nuevo Leon]], and [[Tamaulipas]].

|species = '''''S. berlandieri'''''

|range_map_caption = Range of ''Senegalia berlandieri''

'''''Senegalia berlandieri''''' ('''Berlandier Acacia''', '''Guajillo Acacia''', '''guajillo''', '''huajillo''') is a [[shrub]] native to the [[Southwestern United States]] and northeast [[Mexico]] that belongs to the subfamily [[Mimosoideae]] (wattles) of [[Fabaceae]] (legumes). It grows {{convert|1|to|5|m|ft}} tall, with [[blossom]]s that are spherical and white, occurring from February through April.<ref name ="npin">[http://wildflower.utexas.edu/plants/result.php?id_plant=ACBE University of Texas Native Plant Information Network]</ref>  The ''berlandieri'' epithet comes from the name of [[Jean-Louis Berlandier]],<ref>
{{cite book
  | last = Holloway
  | first = Joel Ellis
  | title = A Dictionary of Common Wildflowers of Texas & the Southern Great Plains
  | publisher = [[Texas Christian University Press]]
  | year = 2005
  | isbn = 3-540-63293-X }}
</ref> a [[France|French]] [[natural history|naturalist]] who studied [[wildlife]] native to [[Texas]] and [[Mexico]]. ''S. berlandieri'' contains a wide variety of [[alkaloid]]s and has been known to cause [[toxin|toxic]] reactions in [[domestic animal]]s such as [[goats]].<ref name = Clem>B.A. Clement, C. M. Goff and T. D. A. Forbes (1997). "Toxic amines and alkaloids from ''Acacia berlandieri''." ''Phytochem.'' '''46''' 249-254.</ref><ref>I. J. Pemberton, G. R. Smith, T. D. Forbes, and C. M. Hensarling (1993). "Technical note: an improved method for extraction and quantification of toxic phenethylamines from ''Acacia berlandieri''." ''J. Anim. Sci.'' '''71''' 467-70. http://www.journalofanimalscience.org/content/71/2/467.full.pdf</ref>

== Uses ==
''S. berlandieri'' is toxic to [[livestock]] and thus should not be used as [[forage]] or [[fodder]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://essmextension.tamu.edu/plants/toxics/detail.aspx?plantID=71 |work=Texas Toxic Plant Database |title=Guajillo |publisher=Texas A&M University}}</ref>
The honeybees use the flowers to make a honey that is as clear as water.<ref>p281 of "The ABC and XYZ of Bee Culture" by A. I. Root "HUAJILLA. (Zygia brevifolia, Sargent)</ref> This is a very important honey-plant, or tree, rather, in Texas, for the dry arid portions where there is little or no irrigation, and where nothing, in fact, grows except mesquite, catclaw, sage-brush, and other desert plants. The fact that it does not depend on irrigation, and needs only a scanty amount of rain early in the season, makes it most valuable to the bee-keeper in those regions where it grows and yields large quantities of beautiful water clear honey. Indeed, it is the finest produced in Texas, and is so nearly water white as to be almost as clear as pure water. It is at its very best in the region of Uvalde, Texas."<ref>A.I. Root and E.R. Root , (1910), "The ABC and XYZ of Bee Culture" https://archive.org/stream/abcxyzofbeecultu00root#page/281/mode/2up</ref>

== Alkaloids ==
''S. berlandieri'' contains a number of diverse [[alkaloid]]s, the most plentiful of which are [[N-Methylphenethylamine|''N''-methylphenethylamine]], [[tyramine]], and [[phenethylamine]].<ref name = Clem/> The total alkaloid content in dried leaves has been reported to be in the range 0.28-0.66%.<ref name="tax">{{cite book
  | last = Hegnauer
  | first = Robert mass
  | authorlink =
  | title = Chemotaxonomie der Pflanzen
  | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=9fDv1RYqIRkC&dq=chemotaxonomie+der+pflanzen&printsec=frontcover
  | publisher = [[Springer Science+Business Media]]
  | series =
  | year = 1994
  | doi =
  | page = 500
  | isbn = 3-7643-2979-3 }}</ref> In a recent study, researchers identified thirty-one alkaloids in samples of plant foliage, including trace amounts of four [[amphetamine]]s previously known only from laboratory synthesis: amphetamine, [[methamphetamine]], [[Hydroxyamfetamine|''para''-hydroxyamphetamine]] and [[para-Methoxyamphetamine|''para''-methoxyamphetamine]]. Other trace alkaloids include [[nicotine]], and [[mescaline]] (found in many [[Cactus|cacti]] but infrequently in other plants).<ref name = Clem/> The same group of researchers later reported finding most of the same alkaloids in ''[[Acacia rigidula|A. rigidula]]'', a related species also native to the Southwestern U.S.<ref>B. A. Clement, C. M. Goff, and T.D. A. Forbes (1998). "Toxic amines and alkaloids from ''Acacia rigidula''." ''Phytochem.'' '''49''' 1377-1380.</ref> There are no reports in the literature of these findings having been repeated, however, leading to the suggestion that they resulted from cross-contamination or were possibly artifacts of the analytical technique.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.cognitiveliberty.org/shulgin/adsarchive/acacia.htm |work=Ask Dr. Shulgin Online |title=Acacias and Natural Amphetamine |publisher=Center for Cognitive Liberty & Ethics |date=2001-09-26}}</ref>

100.text:
{{italic title}} {{taxobox |image = Acacia greggii thorns.jpg |status = G5 |status_system = TNC |regnum = [[Plant]]ae |unranked_divisio = [[Angiosperms]] |unranked_classis = [[Eudicots]] |unranked_ordo = [[Rosids]] |ordo = [[Fabales]] |familia = [[Fabaceae]] |genus = ''[[Senegalia]]'' |species = '''''S. greggii''''' |binomial = ''Senegalia greggii'' |binomial_authority = ([[Asa Gray|A.Gray]]) Britton & Rose |range_map = Acacia-greggii-range-map.png |range_map_caption = Global occurrence of ''S. greggii'' |range_map2 = Acacia greggii range map 1.png |range_map2_caption = ''S. greggii'' var. ''greggii'' natural range |range_map3 = Acacia wrightii range map 1.png |range_map3_caption = ''S. greggii'' var. ''wrightii'' natural range |subdivision_ranks = varieties |subdivision = *''Senegalia greggii'' var. ''arizonica'' Isely *''Senegalia greggii'' var. ''greggii'' (A. Gray) Britton & Rose |}} '''''Senegalia greggii''''' is a species of ''[[Senegalia]]'' native to the [[southwestern United States]] and northern [[Mexico]], from the extreme south of [[Utah]] (where, at 37°10' N it is the northernmost naturally occurring ''Senegalia'' species anywhere in the world{{citation needed|date=April 2013}}) south through southern [[Nevada]], southeast [[California]], [[Arizona]], [[New Mexico]] and western [[Texas]] to [[Baja California]], [[Sinaloa]] and [[Nuevo León]] in Mexico. Common names include '''catclaw acacia''', '''catclaw mesquite''', '''Gregg's catclaw''', '''paradise flower''', '''wait-a-minute bush''', and '''wait-a-bit tree'''; these names mostly come from the fact that the tree has numerous hooked '''prickles''' with the shape and size of a [[cat]]'s claw, that tend to hook onto passers-by; the hooked person must stop ("wait a minute") to remove the '''prickles''' carefully to avoid injury or shredded clothing. (Note: "cat's claw" is also used to refer to ''[[Uncaria tomentosa]]'', a woody vine found in the tropical jungles of South and Central America) The [[Botanical name|specific epithet]] ''greggii'' refers to [[Josiah Gregg]], author, explorer, and amateur naturalist of the [[Southwestern United States|American Southwest]] and northern Mexico. ==Ecology== ''Senegalia greggii'' is most common in [[Arroyo (creek)|arroyos]] where its roots have access to deep water. Its seeds require physical [[Scarification (botany)|scarification]] in order to germinate. This effectively prevents [[germination]] unless a [[flash flood]] disturbs the area and deposits enough water to increase the likelihood that seedlings will be able to establish deep enough roots to survive the dry season. Catclaw is fully [[drought]] [[deciduous]] and will usually lack [[Leaf|leaves]] for most of the year. ''S. greggii'' has [[Extrafloral nectary|extrafloral nectaries]], a trait shared with other senegalias. A tentative connection has been made between these glands and [[insect]]s that would suggest a [[Mutualism (biology)|mutualistic]] relationship (as found in other ''Senegalia'' species). [[Ant]]s are known to use the glands as a source of food and water, and may provide some defense for the plant against [[Herbivore|herbivorous]] insects. Like other arroyo trees in family [[Fabaceae]], ''S. greggii'' is frequently afflicted with Desert Mistletoe, ''[[Phoradendron]] [[Phoradendron californicum|californicum]]''. Unlike other legumes, ''S. greggii'' is not known to form [[root nodule]] associations with [[Nitrogen fixation|nitrogen-fixing]] [[Diazotroph|bacteria]]. It is argued that this species may be an example of an evolutionary [[anachronism]], in which the range and renewal of the species is limited due to the [[Quaternary extinction event#The Pleistocene or Ice Age extinction event|extinction]] of the mammalian [[megafauna]] responsible for [[Endozoochory|seed dispersal]]. Within this model, the scarification required to germinate the seeds would have occurred during the chewing and [[digestion]] of the fruit by a large [[mammal]], who later passes the seed intact some distance from the original tree. ==Description== [[Image:Acacia greggii1.jpg|thumb|200px|
''Senegalia greggii''
]] It is a large [[shrub]] or small [[tree]] growing to {{convert|10|-|15|m|ft|abbr=on}} tall with a trunk up to {{convert|20|-|30|cm|in|abbr=on}} diameter. The grey-green [[leaf|leaves]] are [[deciduous]], and bipinnate, divided into 1-3 pairs of pinnae, each pinna {{convert|2|-|3|cm|abbr=on}} long with 10-18 [[leaflet (botany)|leaflets]] that are {{convert|3|-|6|mm|in|abbr=on}}. Pinnae are most frequently in two pairs, with the proximal pair perpendicular to the petiolule and the distal pair forming a V at the tip. The blooms are produced in dense cylindrical spikes of numerous flowers, each individual flower with five cream colored {{convert|3|mm|in|adj=on|abbr=on}} [[petal]]s and numerous creamy yellow {{convert|6|mm|in|adj=on|abbr=on}} [[stamen]]s. The [[fruit]] is a flat, twisted [[legume]] (pod) {{convert|6|-|15|cm|in|abbr=on}} long, containing generally 3 to 5 hard, flattened, medium brown [[seed]]s. The seed pod is constricted between seeds (a [[loment]]), and [[seed dispersal]] occurs both through [[Dehiscence (botany)|dehiscence]] and breaks at these constrictions. ==Ethnobotany== ''Senegalia greggii'', even though it is used as [[Fodder|forage]] for livestock, contains a potentially poisonous [[cyanogenic glycoside]] called [[prunasin]].[http://www.ivis.org/special_books/Knight/chap1/ivis.pdf Plants Causing Sudden Death by A. P. Knight and R. G. Walter] Mature seeds are to be avoided, as the native people did. ''S. greggii'' young, unripe beans were gathered and eaten by desert [[Indigenous peoples of the Americas|tribes]] of [[North America]], including the [[Chemehuevi]] of the [[Southern Paiute]], the [[Pima people|Pima]], and the [[Cahuilla]]. The Cahuilla also ground the dried beans for mush and cakes, while the [[Havasupai]] ground it to make flour for bread. The [[Seri people|Seri]] ground the beans to meal then mixed it with water and sea lion oil for [[porridge]]. The [[Diegueno]] used ''S. greggii'' as food for domesticated animals. The Cahuilla and Pima used the fibers for sturdy construction material and firewood. The Havasupai split the twigs and used them for [[basketry]], but also used the twigs as a broom to brush off [[metate|metates]]. The O'odham (formerly called [[Tohono O'odham|Papago]]) used the broken twigs for baskets, and were curved to make intricate weaves in the baskets. The Pima used the dried bushes to pile them to make a brush fence. The branches were used to make cradle frames as well. The Tohono O'odham fitted the branches around deer hunters' heads to make a disguise, and the buds and blossoms were dried to make perfume sachets by the women. The sticks were also used to dislodge [[saguaro]] fruits from the [[cactus]] body, and rods were curved to flesh animal skins. The Akimel O'odham made bows out of the wood.{{cite web|title=Acacia greggii Gray|url=http://herb.umd.umich.edu/herb/search.pl|website=http://herb.umd.umich.edu/|accessdate=2015}} [[Image:Acacia-greggii-flower.jpg|thumb|200px|right|''Senegalia greggii'' Flower]] ==Some chemical compounds found in ''Senegalia greggii''== *[[Beta-methyl-phenethylamine]][http://uvalde.tamu.edu/pdf/chemtdaf.pdf Chemistry of Acacias from South Texas] *[[Catechin]] *[[Fisetin]] *[[Hordenine]] *[[Phenethylamine]] *[[Quercetin]] *[[Tyramine]] ==Gallery== Image:Acacia greggii branch.jpg|
''Senegalia greggii'' branch
Image:Acacia greggii seeds.jpg|

Basic Books:NY. * [http://ucjeps.berkeley.edu/cgi-bin/get_JM_treatment.pl?3691,3692,3699 Jepson Manual Treatment: ''Senegalia greggii'' (as ''Acacia greggii'')] * [http://www.fs.fed.us/database/feis/plants/shrub/acagre/botanical_and_ecological_characteristics.html U.S. Forest Service FEIS Database: ''Senegalia greggii'' (as ''Acacia greggii'')] * Lawor, Elizabeth Jane (1995). ''Archaeological Site-formation Processes Affecting Plant Remains in the Mojave Desert.''. '''''Sideroxylon celastrinum''''' is a species of [[flowering plant]] in the [[Manilkara zapota|sapodilla]] family, [[Sapotaceae]], that is native to [[Texas]]<ref name="GRIN"/> and [[Florida]]<ref>{{cite web |url=http://florida.plantatlas.usf.edu/Plant.aspx?id=2913 |first=R. P. |last=Wunderlin |author2=Hansen, B. F  |title=Sideroxylon celastrinum |work=Atlas of Florida Vascular Plants |publisher=Plantatlas.org |accessdate=2009-01-27}}</ref> in the [[United States]] south through [[Central America]] to northern [[Venezuela]] and [[Colombia]] in [[South America]]. Common names include '''saffron plum'''<ref>{{PLANTS|id=SICE2|taxon=Sideroxylon celastrinum|accessdate=14 November 2015}}</ref> and '''coma'''.<ref name="TPWD">http://www.tpwd.state.tx.us/publications/pwdpubs/media/pwd_bk_w7000_1675_07_11.pdf</ref><ref>http://woodsroamer.blogspot.com/2011/06/coma-brushland-fruit.html</ref> It is a spiny shrub or small tree that reaches a height of {{convert|2|-
|9|m|ft|abbr=on}}. The dark green leaves are alternate or fascicled at the nodes and oblanceolate to obovate. Greenish-white flowers are present from May to November and are followed by single-seeded, blue-black [[drupe]]s.<ref>{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=8cEq7weUPYYC |title=Trees, Shrubs, and Cacti of South Texas |first=J. H. |last=Everitt |author2=Dale Lynn Drawe |author3=Robert I. Lonard  |publisher=Texas Tech University Press |year=2002 |isbn=978-0-89672-473-0 |page=190}}</ref>

==Uses==
This plant is known as a first choice deer feed.<ref name="TPWD" />

==Synonyms==
*''Bumelia angustifolia'' <small>[[Thomas Nuttall|Nutt.]]</small>
*''Bumelia celastrina'' <small>[[Carl Sigismund Kunth|Kunth]]</small>
*''Bumelia celastrina'' var. ''angustifolia'' <small>(Nutt.) R.W.Long</small><ref name="ITIS">{{ITIS |id=505216 |taxon=''Sideroxylon celastrinum'' |accessdate=2011-10-07}}</ref>
*''Bumelia spiniflora'' <small>[[Alphonse Pyramus de Candolle|A.DC.]]</small><ref name="GRIN"/>

'''''Sideroxylon lanuginosum'''''<ref>[http://www.mobot.org/gardeninghelp/plantfinder/Plant.asp?code=M830 ''Sideroxylon lanuginosum'' at Missouri Botanical Garden]</ref> is a shrub or small tree of the family [[Sapotaceae]]. It is native to the [[Sun Belt]] and [[Midwestern United States|Midwest]] of the [[United States]]<ref name=PLANTS>{{PLANTS|id=SILA20|taxon=Sideroxylon lanuginosum|accessdate=14 November 2015}}</ref> as well as Northeastern [[Mexico]].<ref name="GRIN"/> Common names include '''gum bully''',<ref name=PLANTS/> '''black haw''', '''chittamwood''', '''chittimwood''', '''shittamwood''', '''false buckthorn''', '''gum bumelia''', '''gum elastic''', '''gum woolybucket''', '''woolybucket bumelia''', '''wooly buckthorn''', '''wooly bumelia''', '''ironwood''' and '''coma'''.

==Subspecies==

''lanuginosum'' at Oklahoma Biological Survey]</ref><ref>[http://edis.ifas.ufl.edu/ST103 ''Bumelia lanuginosa'' at University of Florida]</ref>
*''Sideroxylon lanuginosum'' ssp. ''oblongifolium'' <small>([[Thomas Nuttall|Nutt.]]) T.D.Penn.</small> (syn. ''Sideroxylon lanuginosum'' ssp. ''albicans'')
*''Sideroxylon lanuginosum'' ssp. ''rigidum'' <small>([[Asa Gray|A.Gray]]) T.D.Penn.</small><ref name="ITIS"/>
